question: Question 1 A [latex]4 \times 4[/latex] group pile, with each pile [latex]20\ \text{m}[/latex] long and [latex]500\ \text{mm}[/latex] in diameter, is installed in a square pattern in a clayey soil, as shown in the figure. The average unconfined compressive strength of the soil is [latex]100\ \text{kN/m}^2[/latex], and the adhesion factor is [latex]0.8[/latex]. Neglect the bearing at the tip of the piles. For a group efficiency factor of [latex]1.0[/latex], the centre to centre spacing(s) of the piles (in m) would be _______ (round off to two decimal places).

Question 2 A designer used plate load test to obtain the value of the bearing capacity factor [latex]N_\gamma[/latex]. A circular plate of [latex]1\ \text{m}[/latex] diameter was placed on the surface of a dry sand layer extending very deep beneath the ground. The unit weight of the sand is [latex]16.66\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex]. The plate is loaded to failure at a pressure of [latex]1500\ \text{kPa}[/latex]. Considering Terzaghi's bearing capacity theory, the bearing capacity factor [latex]N_\gamma[/latex] is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).

Question 3 The bank of a canal has the profile shown in the figure. The material is a homogeneous clay with a bulk unit weight of [latex]20\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex], undrained cohesion of [latex]30\ \text{kPa}[/latex] and it is fully saturated ([latex]\phi_u = 0[/latex]). For the trial slip circle shown, the area ABCDEA is [latex]150\ \text{m}^2[/latex] and the centroid is at P. A tension crack (DE) of [latex]2.5\ \text{m}[/latex] deep was also observed. Assume unit weight of water is [latex]9.81\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex] and consider 1 m run of the bank for the analysis. Considering the canal is empty and the tension crack is completely filled with water, the factor of safety against slope failure of the bank is ______ (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
We use the concept of moment equilibrium for the slip surface. Since [latex]\phi = 0[/latex] (undrained condition), we use the following formula for factor of safety:

[latex] FS = \frac{c \cdot L}{W \cdot \frac{h}{R} - u \cdot \frac{h_w}{R}} [/latex] Where: [latex]c = 30\ \text{kPa}[/latex] (undrained cohesion) [latex]A = 150\ \text{m}^2[/latex] (area of slip mass) [latex]\gamma = 20\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex] (bulk unit weight of clay) [latex]W = \gamma \cdot A = 20 \cdot 150 = 3000\ \text{kN}[/latex] [latex]u = \gamma_w = 9.81\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex] [latex]R = 14\ \text{m}[/latex] (radius of slip circle) [latex]h = h_{\text{cg}} = 2.5\ \text{m}[/latex] (vertical distance of CG from center) [latex]h_w = 2.5\ \text{m}[/latex] (depth of water in tension crack) [latex]L = \text{length of arc} = \theta \cdot R[/latex] (We don't have [latex]\theta[/latex], but can use total resisting moment and driving moment instead) Resisting moment: [latex] M_R = c \cdot A \cdot R = 30 \cdot 150 \cdot R = 4500R [/latex] Driving moment (including water pressure in tension crack): Weight moment: [latex] M_W = W \cdot h = 3000 \cdot 2.5 = 7500 [/latex] Water moment in tension crack (triangular pressure distribution): [latex] p = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \gamma_w \cdot h_w^2 = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 9.81 \cdot (2.5)^2 = 30.65 [/latex] (acting at [latex]\frac{1}{3} \cdot 2.5 = 0.833\ \text{m}[/latex] from bottom) So moment due to water: [latex] M_u = 30.65 \cdot 0.833 \approx 25.53 [/latex] Total driving moment: [latex] M_D = 7500 + 25.53 = 7525.53 [/latex] Now, factor of safety: [latex] FS = \frac{M_R}{M_D} = \frac{4500R}{7525.53} [/latex] Substitute [latex]R = 14\ \text{m}[/latex]:

[latex] FS = \frac{4500 \cdot 14}{7525.53} = \frac{63000}{7525.53} \approx \boxed{1.07} [/latex]

question: Question 4 In the context of shear strength of soil, which of the following statements is/are CORRECT?
solution: Statement (A): This is correct. The unconfined compression test is a UU triaxial test with zero confining pressure. Statement (B): This is incorrect. For rapid construction in clay, there is no drainage. So, shear parameters from UU or CU tests are used, not from CD tests. Statement (C): This is correct. Vane shear test is suitable for determining the in situ undrained strength of saturated clays. Statement (D): This is correct. In a UU test, the total stress parameters are used, and the angle of internal friction [latex]\phi[/latex] is taken as zero.

options.A:
The unconfined compression test is a special case of the unconsolidated-undrained 
(UU) triaxial tests.
options.B:
The shear strength parameters obtained from the consolidated-drained (CD) triaxial 
tests should be used to analyse rapid construction in clay.
options.C:
Vane shear test is commonly used for determining in situ undrained strength of 
saturated clay soils.
options.D:
In an unconsolidated-undrained (UU) triaxial tests, the angle of internal friction ([latex] \phi [/latex]) 
is equal to zero.

question: Question 5 For a partially saturated soil deposit at a construction site, water content (w) is 15%, degree of saturation (S) is 67%, void ratio (e) is 0.6 and specific gravity of solids in the soil ([latex]G_s[/latex]) is 2.67. Consider unit weight of water as [latex]9.81\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex]. To fully saturate [latex]5\ \text{m}^3[/latex] of this soil, the required weight of water (in kN) will be ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: [latex]w = 15% = 0.15[/latex] [latex]S = 67% = 0.67[/latex] [latex]e = 0.6[/latex] [latex]G_s = 2.67[/latex] [latex]V = 5\ \text{m}^3[/latex] [latex]\gamma_w = 9.81\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex] To fully saturate the soil, we need to bring degree of saturation [latex]S[/latex] from 0.67 to 1.00. Volume of voids per unit volume of soil: [latex]V_v = \frac{e}{1 + e} = \frac{0.6}{1 + 0.6} = 0.375[/latex] So in 5 m? of soil, total void volume: [latex]V_{v,\text{total}} = 0.375 \times 5 = 1.875\ \text{m}^3[/latex] Currently 67% of voids are filled with water, so water volume present: [latex]V_{w,\text{present}} = 0.67 \times 1.875 = 1.25625\ \text{m}^3[/latex] To fully saturate: Required water volume = [latex]V_{w,\text{required}} = 1.875 - 1.25625 = 0.61875\ \text{m}^3[/latex] Weight of required water: [latex]W_w = \gamma_w \times V_{w,\text{required}} = 9.81 \times 0.61875 = 6.07\ \text{kN}[/latex] Rounded to nearest integer: [latex]\boxed{6\ \text{kN}}[/latex]

question: Question 6 A 6 m thick clay stratum has drainage at both its top and bottom surface due to the presence of sand strata. The time to complete 50% consolidation is 2 years. The coefficient of volume change ([latex]m_v[/latex]) is [latex]1.51 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{m}^2/\text{kN}[/latex] and unit weight of water ([latex]\gamma_w[/latex]) is [latex]9.81\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex]. The coefficient of permeability (in m/year) is ______ (round off to three decimal places).

Question 7 From a flow-net diagram drawn under a concrete dam, following information are obtained: (i) The head difference between upstream and downstream side of the dam is [latex]9m[/latex]. (ii) The total number of equipotential drops between upstream and downstream side of the dam is [latex]10[/latex]. (iii) The length of the field nearest to the toe of the dam in the downstream side is [latex]1m[/latex]. If the soil below the dam is having a saturated unit weight of [latex]21 kN/m^3[/latex] and unit weight of water is [latex]9.81 kN/m^3[/latex], then the factor of safety against the quick condition will be ______ (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Step 1: Calculate the head drop per potential drop. [latex] \Delta h = \frac{H}{N_d} = \frac{9}{10} = 0.9\ \text{m} [/latex] Step 2: Hydraulic gradient at the toe (critical point): [latex] i = \frac{\Delta h}{\text{length of field}} = \frac{0.9}{1} = 0.9 [/latex] Step 3: Critical hydraulic gradient [latex]i_c[/latex] is given by: [latex] i_c = \frac{\gamma_{\text{sat}} - \gamma_w}{\gamma_w} = \frac{21 - 9.81}{9.81} = \frac{11.19}{9.81} \approx 1.14 [/latex] Step 4: Factor of Safety against piping (quick condition): [latex] FS = \frac{i_c}{i} = \frac{1.14}{0.9} \approx \boxed{1.27} [/latex] Answer: [latex]\boxed{1.27}[/latex]

question: Question 8 Which of the following statements is/are INCORRECT ?
solution: Statement (A): Effective stress is given by: [latex]\sigma' = \sigma - u[/latex] Where [latex]\sigma[/latex] is total stress and [latex]u[/latex] is pore water pressure. As the groundwater table goes deeper, pore water pressure acting on the soil decreases, which leads to an increase in effective stress - not a decrease. This statement is incorrect. Statement (B): Bulking of sand occurs when moisture forms a thin film around sand particles due to surface tension and capillary action. This causes an increase in volume. This statement is correct. Statement (C): In liquefied soil, the pore water pressure equals the total stress, so the effective stress becomes nearly zero: [latex]\sigma' = \sigma - u \approx 0[/latex] This statement is correct. Statement (D): The earth pressure at a point in soil can be less than, equal to, or even greater than the vertical effective stress depending on the condition (at-rest, active, or passive). For example, in passive earth pressure condition: [latex]\sigma_h = K_p \cdot \sigma_v[/latex] where [latex]K_p > 1[/latex] Hence, horizontal pressure can be greater than vertical effective stress. This statement is incorrect.

options.A: As the depth of the ground water table from the ground surface increases, the effective stress in the soil decreases.
options.B: Bulking of the moist sand is due to the capillary action in the sand.
options.C: The effective stress in a liquefied soil is almost zero.
options.D: The earth pressure at any point in the soil, under all conditions, is always smaller than the vertical effective stress at that point.

question: Question 9 The most suitable test for measuring the permeability of clayey soils in the laboratory is ______.
solution: Step 1: Understand the nature of clayey soils. Clayey soils have very low permeability due to their fine particles and low void ratio. Step 2: Choose a test suitable for measuring low permeability. The Constant Head Test is suitable for coarse-grained soils like sand and gravel. The Pumping Out Test is a field test and not used in typical lab permeability tests for clays. The Hydrometer Test is used to determine particle size distribution, not permeability. The Falling Head Test is appropriate for soils with low permeability, like clay. Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{\text{Option (D) - Falling head test}} [/latex]

question:
Question 10 Two soils of permeabilities [latex]k_{1}[/latex] and [latex]k_{2}[/latex] are placed in a horizontal flow apparatus, as shown in the figure. For Soil [latex]1, L_{1}=50 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex], and [latex]k_{1}=0.055 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]; for Soil [latex]2, L_{2}=30 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex], and [latex]\mathrm{k}_{2}=0.035 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The cross sectional area of the horizontal pipe is [latex]100 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}[/latex], and the head difference ( [latex]\Delta \mathrm{h}[/latex] ) is 150 cm . The discharge (in [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] ) through the soils is _________
 (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 11 A single pile with 450 mm diameter has been driven into a homogeneous clay layer, which has an undrained cohesion ( [latex]\mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{u}}[/latex] ) of 20 kPa and unit weight of [latex]18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The ground water table is found to be at the surface of the clay layer. The adhesion factor [latex](\alpha)[/latex] of the soil is 0.95 and bearing capacity factor [latex]\left(N_{c}\right)[/latex] is 9 . The pile is supporting a column load of 144 kN with a factor of safety of 3.0 against ultimate axial pile capacity in compression. The required embedment depth of the pile (in m ) is _________
 (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: Pile diameter, [latex]D = 450\ \text{mm} = 0.45\ \text{m}[/latex] Undrained cohesion, [latex]c_u = 20\ \text{kPa}[/latex] Unit weight, [latex]\gamma = 18\ \text{kN/m}^3[/latex] [latex]\alpha = 0.95[/latex], [latex]N_c = 9[/latex] Column load, [latex]Q_{working} = 144\ \text{kN}[/latex] Factor of safety, [latex]FOS = 3.0[/latex] First, compute the ultimate load capacity: [latex]Q_{ult} = Q_{working} \times FOS = 144 \times 3 = 432\ \text{kN}[/latex] Ultimate capacity of a pile in clay: [latex]Q_{ult} = Q_b + Q_s[/latex] [latex]Q_b = A_b \cdot c_u \cdot N_c[/latex] (base resistance) [latex]Q_s = \alpha \cdot c_u \cdot P \cdot L[/latex] (skin friction) Base area: [latex]A_b = \frac{\pi D^2}{4} = \frac{\pi (0.45)^2}{4} = 0.1590\ \text{m}^2[/latex] Perimeter: [latex]P = \pi D = \pi \cdot 0.45 = 1.4137\ \text{m}[/latex] [latex]Q_b = 0.1590 \cdot 20 \cdot 9 = 28.62\ \text{kN}[/latex] Let [latex]L[/latex] be the required embedment depth. Then: [latex]Q_s = 0.95 \cdot 20 \cdot 1.4137 \cdot L = 26.26 \cdot L[/latex] Total ultimate capacity: [latex]Q_{ult} = Q_b + Q_s = 28.62 + 26.26L[/latex] Set equal to required ultimate capacity: [latex]28.62 + 26.26L = 432[/latex] [latex]26.26L = 403.38[/latex] [latex]L = \frac{403.38}{26.26} = 15.36\ \text{m}[/latex] Rounded to the nearest integer: Answer: [latex]\boxed{15\ \text{m}}[/latex]

question: Question 12 A clayey soil has a moisture content of [latex]18 \%[/latex], a specific gravity of soil solids of 2.74 , and a degree of saturation of [latex]65 \%[/latex]. The soil soaks up water during a rain event, and the degree of saturation increases to [latex]85.2 \%[/latex]. The change of the volume during the soaking is negligible. The new moisture content (in \%) of the soil will be _________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Initial moisture content, [latex]w_1 = 18% = 0.18[/latex] Specific gravity, [latex]G = 2.74[/latex] Initial degree of saturation, [latex]S_1 = 65% = 0.65[/latex] Final degree of saturation, [latex]S_2 = 85.2% = 0.852[/latex] Assuming negligible change in volume, the void ratio [latex]e[/latex] remains constant. The relation between moisture content, saturation, and void ratio is: [latex]w = \frac{S \cdot e}{G}[/latex] Rearranging to find [latex]e[/latex]: [latex]e = \frac{w_1 \cdot G}{S_1}[/latex] [latex]e = \frac{0.18 \cdot 2.74}{0.65} = 0.75877[/latex] Now calculate the new moisture content [latex]w_2[/latex]: [latex]w_2 = \frac{S_2 \cdot e}{G}[/latex] [latex]w_2 = \frac{0.852 \cdot 0.75877}{2.74} = 0.2361[/latex] [latex]w_2 = 23.61%[/latex]

question: Question 13 A [latex]6 \mathrm{~m} \times 6 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] square footing constructed in clay is subjected to a vertical load of 2500 kN at its centre. The base of the footing is 2 m below the ground surface, as shown in the figure. The footing is made of 2 m thick concrete. The ground water table is at a great depth. Considering Terzaghi's bearing capacity theory, the factor of safety of footing against the bearing capacity failure is _________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places). Note: Unit of concrete [latex]=24 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Properties of clay: [latex]c=50 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \phi=0^{\circ}[/latex], and [latex]\gamma=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] For [latex]\phi=0^{\circ}: N_{c}=5.7, N_{q}=1, N_{\gamma}=0[/latex]
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
Q_{\text {safe }} & =\frac{Q_{u}-\bar{\sigma}}{F O S}+\bar{\sigma} \\
& =\frac{Q_{u}-\gamma D_{f}}{F O S}+\gamma D_{f}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Here, [latex]\quad[/latex] Applied load [latex]=\frac{2500}{6 \times 6}+\gamma_{c} \times 2[/latex]

[latex]
=66.67+24 \times 2=117.44 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
[/latex] For square footing, [latex]Q_{u}=1.3 \mathrm{CN}_{c}+\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.4 B \gamma N_{r}[/latex]

[latex]
=1.3 \times 50 \times 5.7+19 \times 2 \times 1+0
[/latex]

[latex]
=370.5+38=408.5
[/latex] [latex]
\Rightarrow \quad Q_{\text {safe }}=\frac{408.5-38}{F O S}+38
[/latex] [latex]
117.44=\frac{370.5}{F O S}+38
[/latex] [latex]
F O S=4.66
[/latex]

question: Question 14 A cut slope is made in a silty clay soil for a new road project, as shown in the figure. The locations of ground water table (GWT) and potential failure surface are shown in the figure. After the cut is made, the excess pore water pressure is fully dissipated, and the shear stress at the point [latex]A[/latex] is [latex]60 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. The factor of safety at the point [latex]A[/latex] for longterm stability is _________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places). Note : Shear strength properties of silty clay: [latex]c^{\prime}=15 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}, \phi^{\prime}=15^{\circ}[/latex], and [latex]c_{u}=75 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Unit weight of soil above the [latex]\operatorname{GWT}(\gamma)=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Unit weight of soil below the [latex]\operatorname{GWT}\left(\gamma_{\text {sat }}\right)=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Unit weight of water [latex]\left(\gamma_{w}\right)=9.81 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]
solution:
For long term, effective shear parameters will be used, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{FOS} & =\frac{C^{\prime}+\bar{\sigma}_{n} \tan \phi^{\prime}}{\tau} \\
\bar{\sigma}_{n} & =\left(5 \gamma_{B}+6.5 \gamma_{\text {sat }}\right)-6.5 \gamma_{w} \\
& =5 \times 19+6.5 \times 20-6.5 \times 9.81 \\
& =161.235 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
\mathrm{FOS} & =\frac{15+161.235 \tan 15^{\circ}}{60} \\
& =0.97
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 15 In an oedometer apparatus a specimen of fully saturated clay has been consolidated under a vertical pressure of 100 kPa and is at equilibrium state. Immediately on increasing the vertical pressure to 150 kPa , the effective stress [latex]\sigma^{\prime}[/latex] and excess pore water pressure [latex]\Delta u[/latex] will be
solution: The clay is fully saturated and initially consolidated under a vertical pressure of: [latex]\sigma = 100 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] (initial total stress) At this stage, the clay is in equilibrium, meaning: [latex]\sigma' = 100 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] (initial effective stress) [latex]u = 0 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] (initial excess pore pressure = 0, since drained) Now, the vertical pressure is increased suddenly to: [latex]\sigma = 150 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] (new total stress) Since the loading is sudden and the soil is fully saturated, no drainage occurs immediately. So, the entire increase in total stress is initially taken up by excess pore pressure: [latex]\Delta u = \sigma_{\text{new}} - \sigma' = 150 - 100 = 50 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] Thus, immediately after loading: [latex]\sigma' = 100 \ \text{kPa} \quad (\text{no immediate change in effective stress})[/latex] [latex]\Delta u = 50 \ \text{kPa}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\sigma' = 100 \ \text{kPa}, \quad \Delta u = 50 \ \text{kPa}[/latex]

question: Question 16 The standard plasticity chart for the classification of a fine-grained soil is shown in the figure. As per the Indian standard soil classification system, X represents
solution: From the given plasticity chart, point X lies: Above the [latex]A\text{-line}[/latex] Has a liquid limit greater than [latex]50%[/latex] According to IS 1498:1970 soil classification system: Soils above the A-line are classified as clays (C) Soils below the A-line are classified as silts (M) Soils with Liquid Limit (LL) > 50% are considered high plasticity (H) Since point X is above the A-line and LL > 50%, it is classified as: [latex]CH \Rightarrow \text{Inorganic Clay of High Plasticity}[/latex]

question: Question 17 The results of a consolidated drained triaxial test on a normally consolidated clay are shown in the figure. The angle of internal friction is
solution:
For CD test, [latex]\quad C=0[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{1} & =\sigma_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \\
100 & =50 \times\left[\frac{1+\sin \phi}{1-\sin \phi}\right] \\
\sin \phi & =\frac{1}{3} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \phi & =\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 18 A drained triaxial test was conducted on a saturated sand specimen using a stress-path triaxial testing system. The specimen failed when the axial stress reached a value of [latex] 100 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] from an initial confining pressure of [latex] 300 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. The angle of shearing plane (in degrees) with respect to horizontal is _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: In stress-path triaxial testing, we can control both radial and axial stress. [latex] \begin{aligned} & \sigma_1=\sigma_3 \tan ^2\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+2 \mathrm{C} \tan \left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \\ & 300=100 \tan ^2\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+0\end{aligned}[/latex] [Since for drained test [latex] C=0 [/latex] ] [latex] \Rightarrow \phi=30^{\circ} [/latex] Angle between normal to major plane and failure plane is [latex] 45+\frac{\phi}{2} [/latex] Angle between normal to minor plane and failure plane is [latex] 45^{\circ}-\frac{\phi}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Angle between minor plane and failure plane [latex] =45-\frac{\phi}{2}=45^{\circ}-\frac{30^{\circ}}{2}=30^{\circ} [/latex]

question: Question 19 The in-situ percentage of voids of a sand deposit is [latex] 50 \% [/latex]. The maximum and minimum densities of sand determined from the laboratory tests are [latex] 1.8 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex] and [latex] 1.3 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex], respectively. Assume the specific gravity of sand as 2.7 . The relative density index of the in-situ sand is ______ (rounded off to 2 decimal places)
solution:
maximum density [latex] \left(\gamma_{\mathrm{d}}\right)_{\max }=1.8 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex] minimum density [latex] \left(\gamma_{\mathrm{d}}\right)_{\min }=1.3 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex] specific gravity [latex] (G)=2.7 [/latex] [latex] \left(I_{D}\right) [/latex] relative density [latex] =\frac{\gamma_{d \max }\left(\gamma_{d}-\gamma_{d \min }\right)}{\gamma_{d}\left(\gamma_{d \max }-\gamma_{d \min }\right)} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad(n) [/latex] percentage of voids [latex]
=\frac{\left(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{v}}\right) \text { volume of voids } \times 100}{\left(\mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{T}}\right) \text { Total volume }}=50 \%
 [/latex] Porosity( [latex] n [/latex] ) [latex] =0.5 [/latex] void ratio (e) [latex] =\frac{\mathrm{n}}{1-\mathrm{n}}=\frac{0.5}{1-0.5}=1 [/latex] [latex] \left(\gamma_{\mathrm{d}}\right)_{\text {insitu }}=\frac{\mathrm{G} \cdot \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}}{1+\mathrm{e}}=\frac{2.7 \times 1}{1+1}=1.35 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex] [latex] \left(I_{D}\right)=\frac{1.8(1.35-1.3)}{1.35(1.8-1.3)}=0.13 [/latex] Relative density [latex] \left(I_{D}\right)=0.13 [/latex]

question: Question 20 A homogeneous earth dam has a maximum water head difference of [latex] 15 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] between the upstream and downstream sides. A flownet was drawn with the number of potential drops as 10 and the average length of the element as [latex] 3 \mathrm{~m} [/latex]. Specific gravity of the soil is 2.65 . For a factor of safety of 2.0 against piping failure, void ratio of the soil is ____(rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 21 Consider the statements [latex] \mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q} [/latex] and [latex] \mathrm{R} [/latex]. P: [latex] \quad [/latex] Compacted fine-grained soils with flocculated structure have isotropic permeability. Q: Phreatic surface/line is the line along which the pore water pressure is always maximum. R: [latex] \quad [/latex] The piping phenomenon occuring below the dam foundation is typically known as blowout piping. Which of the following option(s) is/are CORRECT?
solution:
A fine grained soil when compacted on dry side of optimum has a flocculant (random) structure. Compacted fine grained soils with flocculant structure has isotropic permeability The top most flow line below which seepage takes place through a dam body is called phreatic line.
Hydrostatic pressure is observed below phreatic line where as pressure on and above the phreatic line is atmospheric.

options.B: [latex] P [/latex] is false and [latex] Q [/latex] is true
options.C: [latex] P [/latex] is true and [latex] R [/latex] is false

question: Question 22 Consider the statements [latex] \mathrm{P} [/latex] and [latex] \mathrm{Q} [/latex] related to the analysis/design of retaining walls. P: When a rough retaining wall moves toward the backfill, the wall friction force/resistance mobilizes in upward direction along the wall. Q: Most of the earth pressure theories calculate the earth pressure due to surcharge by neglecting the actual distribution of stresses due to surcharge. Which of the following options is CORRECT?
solution:
When rough retaining wall moves toward the back fill passive earth pressure [latex] \left(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{P}}\right) [/latex] condition will develop which can be represented with the help of diagram shown below. Hence wall friction force/resistance [latex] (\mathrm{F}) [/latex] mobilizes in upward direction along the wall.
   Earth pressure due to surcharge is assumed to be constant along the depth of retaining wall and actual variation of stress due to surcharge is neglected.

options.B: [latex] P [/latex] is true and [latex] Q [/latex] is false
options.D: [latex] P [/latex] is false and [latex] Q [/latex] is true

question: Question 23 A reinforced concrete pile of [latex] 10 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] length and [latex] 0.7 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] diameter is embedded in a saturated pure clay with unit cohesion of [latex] 50 \mathrm{kPa} [/latex]. If the adhesion factor is 0.5 , the net ultimate uplift pullout capacity (in kN) of the pile is _____. (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given, Length of pile [latex] (L)=10 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] Diameter of pile [latex] (D)=0.7 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] Cohesion of clay [latex] \left(C_{4}\right)=50 \mathrm{kPa} [/latex] Adhesion factor [latex] (\alpha)=0.5 [/latex] Pullout capacity [latex] (\mathrm{P})= [/latex] ? Uplift pull out capacity [latex] = [/latex] skin friction resistance + wt. of pile For clay, [latex] (P) [/latex] skin friction resistance [latex] =f_{s} A_{s} [/latex] [latex] P=\alpha C_{u} A_{s}+W [/latex] Taking unit wt of concrete [latex] =25 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] P=0.5 \times 50 \times \pi \times 0.7 \times 10+\frac{\pi(0.7)^{2}}{4} \times \gamma_{c} [/latex] [latex] P=0.5 \times 50 \times \pi \times 0.7 \times 10+\frac{\pi(0.7)^{2}}{4} \times 25 [/latex]

[latex] =550 \mathrm{kN} [/latex]

question: Question 24 Which one of the following saturated fine-grained soils can attain a negative Skempton's pore pressure coefficient [latex] ( \mathrm{A}) [/latex]?
solution: Value of skempton's pore pressure coefficient  may be as large as 2 to 3 for very loose saturated fine sand. It can be ( -0.5 to 0 ) for heavily over consolidated clays. For normally consolidated clays [latex] \mathrm{A}=0.5-1 [/latex] For OC clays, [latex] A=f(O C R) [/latex], for heavily over consolidated clays, [latex] A \lt 0 [/latex].

question: Question 25 The contact presure distribution shown in the figure belongs to a
solution: Flexible footing over clayey soil: In flexible footing, the contact pressure at the interface between footing and soil is uniformly distributed producing dish-shape pattern in clayey soil. Flexible footing over Granular soil: In granular soil, modulus of elasticty [latex] \left(E_{S}\right) [/latex] varies across the width being maximum at the centre and minimum at edge. As [latex] \mathrm{E} [/latex] is maximum at centre, defflection is less at centre. As [latex] E [/latex] is less at edge deflection is more at edge. Rigid footing on Clayey soil: In case of flexible footing, deflection is more at centre. Hence pressure developed at centre is less. Deflection is less in flexible footing at edge, hence in rigid footing pressure developed is more at edge. Rigid footing on Granular soil

options.A: rigid footing resting on a cohesionless soil.
options.B: rigid footing resting on a cohesive soil.
options.C: flexible footing resting on a cohesionless soil.
options.D: flexible footing resting on a cohesive soil.

question: Question 26 A soil sample was consolidated at a cell pressure of [latex] 20 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and a back pressure of [latex] 10 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] for 24 hours during a consolidated undrained (CU) triaxial test. The cell pressure was increased to [latex] 30 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] on the next day and it resulted in the development of pore water pressure of [latex] 1 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The soil sample failed when the axial stress was gradually increased to [latex] 50 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The pore water pressure at failure was recorded as [latex] 21 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The value of skempton's pore pressure parameter [latex] B[/latex]  for the soil sample is ______ (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Given: [latex]  \begin{aligned}
\sigma_{3} & =20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
\text { Back pressure } & =10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
\Delta u_{c} & =1 \mathrm{kPa} \\
\sigma_{3}^{\prime} & =30 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
\Delta \sigma_{3} & =(30-20) \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
B & =\frac{\Delta u_{c}}{\Delta \sigma_{3}}=\frac{1}{10}=0.1
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 An infinite slope is made up of cohesionless soil with seepage parallel to and upto the sloping surface. The angle of slope is [latex] 30^{\circ}[/latex] with respect to horizontal ground surface. The unit weight of the saturated soil and water are [latex] 20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and [latex] 10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] respectively. The minimum angle of shearing resistance of soil (in degrees) for the critically stable condition of the slope is _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\text { FOS }&=\frac{\gamma_{\text {sub }}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }}} \times \frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta}\\
\text{Here, } \beta & =30^{\circ} \\
\gamma_{\text {sat }} & =20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
\gamma_{w} & =10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
\gamma_{\text {sub }} & =\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{w} \\
& =20-10=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad \gamma_{\text {sub }}=\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{w}[/latex] For critically stable condition, [latex]\mathrm{FOS}=1[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{ll}\because & 1=\frac{20-10}{20} \times \frac{\tan \phi}{\tan 30^{\circ}} \\ \Rightarrow & \phi=49.10^{\circ}\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 28 The total primary consolidation settlement [latex]\left(S_{C}\right)[/latex] of a building constructed on a [latex] 10 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] thick saturated clay layer is estimated to be [latex] 50 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. After 300 days of the construction of the building. primary consolidation settlement was reported as [latex] 10 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. The additional time (in days) required to achieve [latex] 50 \%[/latex]  of [latex] S_{c}[/latex] will be ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
Question 29 Which of the following statement(s) is/are CORRECT?
solution:
Shrinkage limit is defined as the maximum water
content at which further reduction in water
content of soil does not lead to reduction in the
volume of soil as water is being just replaced
by air. Higher is the shrinkage limit lower is the
compressibility (volume change). Dilatancy correction is applied to the already
corrected N-values for overburden pressure. At large value of shearing strain, both the initially
loose and initially dense sands approach a
constant value of void ratio called critical void
ratio.

options.A: Swell potential of soil decreases with an increase in the shrinkage limit.
options.B: Both loose and dense sands with different initial void ratios can attain similar void ratio at large strain during shearing.
options.C: Among the several corrections to be applied to the SPT-N value, the dilatancy correction is applied before all other corrections.
options.D: In electrical resistivity tomography, the depth of current penetration is half of the spacing between the electrodes.

question: Question 30 A vertical smooth rigid retaining wall is supporting horizontal ground with dry cohesionless backfill having a friction angle of [latex] 30^{\circ}[/latex]. The inclinations of failure planes with respect to the major principal plane for Rankine's active and passive earth pressure condition, respectively are
solution:
For Rankine's active pressure condition where,
[latex]\theta_{f}=45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}=45^{\circ}+\frac{30^{\circ}}{2}=60^{\circ}[/latex] For Rankine's passive pressure condition where,
[latex]\theta_{f}=45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}=45^{\circ}+\frac{30^{\circ}}{2}=60^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 31 An embankment is constructed with soil by maintaining the degree of saturation as [latex] 75 \%[/latex]  during compaction. The specific gravity of soil is 2.68 and the moisture content is [latex] 17 \%[/latex]  during compaction. Consider the unit weight of water as [latex] 10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The dry unit weight (in [latex]\mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] ) of the compacted soil is (rounded off to 2 decimal places)

Question 32 Consider the statements P and Q. P : Soil particles formed by mechanical weathering, and close to their origin are generally subrounded. Q: Activity of the clay physically signifies its swell potential. Which one of the following options is CORRECT?
solution:
Bulky particles are formed mostly by mechanical
weathering of rocks and minerals. Geologists
use such terms as angular, subangular,
subrounded and rounded to describe the shape
of bulky particles. Small sand particles located
close to their origin are generally very angular
sand particles carried by wind and water for a
long distance can be subangular to rounded in
shape. Activity number of clay is used to study the
swelling behaviour. Activity number [latex](A_C)
= \frac{\text{Plasticity index}}{\text{
\% of clay sized particles in soil}}[/latex] [latex] A_C \lt 0.75 \rightarrow [/latex] normal active [latex] 0.75 \lt A_C \lt 1.25 \rightarrow inactive [/latex] [latex] A_C \gt 1.25 \rightarrow active [/latex] Active means more prone to volume change.

options.A: Both P  and Q  are TRUE
options.B: P  is TRUE and Q  is FALSE
options.C: Both P  and Q  are FALSE
options.D: P  is FALSE and Q  is TRUE

question: Question 33 A [latex] 2 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] wide strip footing is founded at a depth of [latex] 1.5 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] below the ground level in a homey, pure clay bed. The clay bed has unit cohesion [latex] 40 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. Due to seasonal fluctuations of water table from peak summer to peak monsoon period, the net ultimate bearing capacity of the footing as per Terzaghi's theory
solution:
Ultimate bearing capacity, [latex] q_{u}=C N_{c}^{5.7}+\gamma D f \mathcal{N}_{q}^{1}+0.5 B \gamma \mathcal{N}_{\gamma}^{0}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
q_{u} & =5.7 C+\gamma D f \\
q_{n u} & =5.7 C
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\left[\because q_{n u}=\left(q_{u}-r_{f}\right)_{f}\right]
[/latex] Net ultimate bearing capacity, So, [latex] q_{n u}[/latex] does not depend on presence of water table.

question: Question 34 A consolidated drained (CD) triaxial test was carried out on a sand sample with the known effective shear strength parameters, [latex]C^{\prime}=0[/latex] and [latex]\phi^{\prime}=30^{\circ}[/latex]. In the test, prior to the failure, when the sample was undergoing axial compression under constant cell pressure, the drainage valve was accidentally closed. At the failure, [latex]360 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] deviatoric stress was recorded along with [latex]70 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] pore water pressure. If the test is repeated without such error, and no back pressure is applied in either of the tests, what is the deviatoric stress (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex], in integer) at the failure? _____
solution:
We know that, [latex]\bar{\sigma}_{1 F}=\bar{\sigma}_{3 \mathrm{~F}} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right)+20 \tan \left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right)[/latex] Assuming [latex]c^{\prime}=0[/latex] under both the conditions when drainage line in suddenly dosed. [latex]
\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}+360-70\right)=\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cy}}-70\right) \tan ^{2} 60+0\;\;\;...(i)
[/latex] When drainage is open and assuming the confining stress [latex]\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}\right)[/latex]. [latex]
\left[\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}+\sigma_{2}\right)-0\right]=\left[\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}-0\right] \tan ^{2} 60^{\circ}+0 \;\;\;...(ii)
[/latex] From (i) and (ii), we get [latex]
\begin{aligned}
290-\sigma_{2} & =-70 \times \tan ^{2} 60^{\circ} \\
290-\sigma_{d} & =-210 \\
\sigma_{d} &=500 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 35 For the flow setup shown in the figure (not to scale), the hydraulic conductivities of the two soil samples, Soil 1 and Soil 2, are [latex]10 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] and [latex]1 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex], respectively. Assume the unit weight of water as [latex]10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and ignore the velocity head. At steady state, what is the total head (in [latex]m[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) at any point located at the junction of the two samples? ____

Question 36 A circular pile of diameter [latex]0.6 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] and length [latex]8 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] was constructed in a cohesive soil stratum having the following properties: bulk unit weight [latex]=[/latex] [latex]19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]; angle of internal friction [latex]=0^{\circ}[/latex] and cohesion [latex]=25 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The allowable load the pile can carry with a factor of safety of 3 is ____ [latex]\mathrm{kN}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place). [Adopt: Adhesion factor, [latex]\alpha=1.0[/latex] and Bearing capacity factor, [latex]\left.\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{C}}=9.0\right][/latex]

Question 37 A square footing is to be designed to carry a column load of [latex]500 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] which is resting on a soil stratum having the following average properties: bulk unit weight [latex]=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]; angle of internal friction [latex]=0^{\circ}[/latex], and cohesion [latex]=25 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. Considering the depth of the footing as [latex]1 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] and adopting Meyerhof's bearing capacity theory with a factor of safety of 3 , the width of the footing (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) is ____ (round off to one decimal place) [Assume the applicable shape and depth factor values as unity; ground water level at greater depth.]
solution:
As per Meyerhoff's approach [latex]
q_{u}=C N_{c}\left[i_{c} S_{c} d_{c}\right]+q N_{q}\left[{ }_{q} S_{q} d_{r}\right]+\frac{1}{2} \beta \gamma N_{r}\left[i_{r} S_{r} d_{r}\right]
[/latex] Given; shape factor [latex]S_{c}, S_{q}, S_{r}=1[/latex] depth factor [latex]d_{c}, d_{v}, d_{r}=1[/latex] Assuming no inclination of loading hence [latex]i_{c} i_{q} i_{r}=1[/latex] For [latex]\phi=0^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{c}}=5.14 \\
& N_{\mathrm{q}}=1 \\
& N_{r}=0 \\
& \therefore \quad \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{u}}=25 \times 5.14 \times 1 \times 1 \times 1+19 \times 1 \times \\
& 1 \times 1 \times 1 \\
& =147.5 \mathrm{kPa} \\
& \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{nu}}=\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{u}}-\mathrm{rD}_{\mathrm{f}} \\
& =147.5-19 \times 1 \\
& =128.5 \mathrm{kPa}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]q_{n s}=\frac{q_{n u}}{F O S}=\frac{128.5}{3}=42.83 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Hence, [latex]\frac{500}{B^{2}} \leq 42.83[/latex] or

[latex]B \geq 3.416 m[/latex] Hence [latex]B=3.4 m[/latex]

question: Question 38 The figure shows a vertical retaining wall with backfill consisting of cohesive-frictional soil and a failure plane developed due to passive earth pressure. The forces acting on the failure wedge are: [latex]P[/latex] as the reaction force between the wall and the soil, [latex]R[/latex] as the reaction force on the failure plane, [latex]C[/latex] as the cohesive force along the failure plane and [latex]W[/latex] as the weight of the failure wedge. Assuming that there is no adhesion between the wall and the wedge, identify the most appropriate force polygon for the wedge.

Question 39 In the given figure, Point [latex]\mathrm{O}[/latex] indicates the stress point of a soil element at initial non-hydrostatic stress condition. For the stress path (OP), which of the following loading conditions is correct ?
solution: For [latex]1: 1[/latex] slope, [latex]\frac{d q}{d P}=1[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{d \sigma_{V}-d \sigma_{H}}{d \sigma_{V}+d \sigma_{H}}=1[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow d \sigma_{V}-d \sigma_{H}=d \sigma_{V}+d \sigma_{H}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad-\mathrm{d} \sigma_{\mathrm{H}}=\mathrm{d} \sigma_{\mathrm{H}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{d} \sigma_{\mathrm{H}}=0[/latex] Hence, if [latex]\sigma_{H}[/latex] is constant then increasing [latex]\sigma_{V}[/latex] or decreasing [latex]\sigma_{\mathrm{V}}[/latex] will lead to [latex]1: 1[/latex] slope. Answer is (A)

question: Question 40 An unconfined compression strength test was conducted on a cohesive soil. The test specimen failed at an axial stress of [latex]76 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The undrained cohesion (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex], in integer) of the soil is ___
solution: UCS Test : [latex]\sigma_{3}=0[/latex] [Cell pressure] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Axial stress [latex]=[/latex] Deviatoric stress [latex]=\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}=\sigma_{1}[/latex] Given, [latex]\sigma_{1}=76 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] We know, [latex]\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+2 C \tan \left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)[/latex] [latex][\mathrm{C}=[/latex] Undrained cohesion, [latex]\phi=0[/latex] (Cohesive soil)] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{1}=2 \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad 76=2 \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow  \quad C=38 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The reason(s) of the nonuniform elastic settlement profile below a flexible footing, resting on a cohesionless soil while subjected to uniform loading, is/are:
solution: The modulus of elasticity varies with width of footing so there is a variation in the stiffness along the width of footing.

options.A: Variation of friction angle along the width of the footing
options.B: Variation of soil stiffness along the width of the footing
options.C: Variation of friction angle along the depth of the footing
options.D: Variation of soil stiffness along the depth of the footing

question: Question 42 A vertical sheet pile wall is installed in an anisotropic soil having coefficient of horizontal permeability, [latex]k_{H}[/latex] and coefficient of vertical permeability, [latex]k_{V}[/latex]. In order to draw the flow net for the isotropic condition, the embedment depth of the wall should be scaled by a factor of _____, without changing the horizontal scale.
solution:
We know that, for 2D flow. [latex]
\mathrm{K}=\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\mathrm{dx}}+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\mathrm{dz}}=0
[/latex] When [latex]\mathrm{K}_{1}=\mathrm{K}_{\text {horizontal }}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{K}_{2}=\mathrm{K}_{\text {vertical }}[/latex] as shown in figure. [latex]
\frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}} \partial \mathrm{x}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\partial \mathrm{z}^{2}}=0
[/latex] From the above equation we can note that, when soil is anisotropic with respect to permeability i.e. [latex]k_{x}=k_{z}[/latex], the flow and equipotential line are not necessarily to be orthogonal as because [latex]\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}}=1[/latex], and we cannot get the actual form of Laplace equation which is [latex]\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial z^{2}}=0[/latex]. But if we replace [latex]
x_{t}=x \sqrt{\frac{K_{z}}{\mathrm{~K}_{x}}}
[/latex] Then, [latex]\quad \partial x_{t}^{2}=\partial x^{2} \frac{K_{z}}{\mathrm{~K}_{x}}[/latex] [latex]
\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial x_{t}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial z^{2}}=0
[/latex] Thus, new flow line and equipotential lines are drawn on transformed section with [latex]\mathrm{x}[/latex]-distance changed to [latex]x \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}}}[/latex] while keeping the vertical dimension constant. If we scale up the depth by keeping the horizontal distance same the depth will be scaled by factor [latex]\sqrt{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}} / \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}[/latex].

question: Question 43 A standard penetration test (SPT) was carried out at a location by using a manually operated hammer dropping system with [latex]50 \%[/latex] efficiency. The recorded SPT value at a particular depth is 28 . If an automatic hammer dropping system with [latex]70 \%[/latex] efficiency is used at the same location, the recorded SPT value will be
solution: We know that, Efficiency of blow [latex]\alpha \frac{1}{\text { SPT value }}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \eta_{1} \mathrm{~N}_{1}=\eta_{2} \mathrm{~N}_{2}[/latex] Hence, [latex]0.50 \times 28=0.70 \times \mathrm{N}_{2}[/latex] or [latex]\quad \mathrm{N}_{2}=\frac{0.50 \times 28}{0.7}=20[/latex] Option (B) is correct

question: Question 44 A vertical trench is excavated in a clayey soil deposit having a surcharge load of [latex]30 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. A fluid of unit weight [latex]12 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] is poured in the trench to prevent collapse as the excavation proceeds. Assume that the fluid is not seeping through the soil deposit. If the undrained cohesion of the clay deposit is [latex]20 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and saturated unit weight is [latex]18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], what is the maximum depth of unsupported excavation (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) ? ____

Question 45 A smooth vertical retaining wall supporting layered soils is shown in figure. According to Rankine's earth pressure theory, the lateral active earth pressure acting at the base of the wall is ____ [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place)

Question 46 A soil having the average properties, bulk unit weight [latex]=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]; angle of internal friction [latex]=25^{\circ}[/latex] and cohesion [latex]=15 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex], is being formed on a rock slope existing at an inclination of [latex]35^{\circ}[/latex] with the horizontal. The critical height (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) of the soil formation up to which it would be stable without any failure is _____ (round off to one decimal place).

Question 47 A square footing of size [latex]2.5 \mathrm{~m} \times 2.5 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] is placed [latex]1.0 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] below the ground surface on a cohesionless homogeneous soil stratum. Considering that the groundwater table is located at the base of the footing, the unit weights of soil above and below the groundwater table are [latex]18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and [latex]20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], respectively, and the bearing capacity factor [latex]N_{q}[/latex] is 58 , the net ultimate baring capacity of the soil is estimated as [latex]1706 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] (unit weight of water [latex]10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] ). Earlier, a plate load test was carried out with a circular place of [latex]30 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] diameter in the same foundation pit during a dry season, when the water table was located beyond the plate influence zone. Using Terzaghi's bearing capacity formulation, what is the ultimate bearing capacity (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}_{-}[/latex]of the plate ?

Question 48 Consider that a force [latex]P[/latex] is acting on the surface of a half-space (Boussingesq's problem). The expression for the vertical stress [latex]\left(\sigma_{z}\right)[/latex] at any point [latex](r, z)[/latex] with the half-space is given as, [latex]\sigma_{z}=\frac{3 P}{2 \pi} \frac{z^{3}}{\left(r^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{5 / 2}}
[/latex] where, [latex]r[/latex] is the radial distance, and [latex]z[/latex] is the depth with downward direction taken as positive. At any given [latex]r[/latex], there is a variation of [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] along [latex]z[/latex], and at a specific [latex]z[/latex], the value of [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] will be maximum. What is the locus of the maximum [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] ?
Question 49 With reference to the compaction test conducted on soils, which of the following is INCORRECT ?
solution: Line of optimum 100% saturation line or zero void line. Compaction curve never crosses the zero-air-voids curve.

options.A:
Peak point of the compaction curve gives
the maximum dry unit weight and optimum
moisture content.
options.B:
With increase in the compaction effort, the
maximum dry unit weight increases.
options.C:
With increase in the compaction effort, the
optimum moisture content decreases.
options.D:
Compaction curve cross the zero-air-voids
curve.

question: Question 50 A drained direct shear test was carried out on a sandy soil. Under a normal stress of [latex]50 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex], the test specimen field at shear stress of [latex]35 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The angle of internal friction of the sample is ______ degree (round off to the nearest integer).

Question 51 A possible slope failure is shown in the figure. Three soil samples are taken from different locations (I, II and III) of the potential failure plane. Which is the most appropriate shear strength test for each of the sample to identify the failure mechanism? Identify the correct combination from the following options: P: Triaxial compression test Q: Triaxial extension test R: Direct shear or shear box test S: Vane shear test

Question 52 A group of 9 friction piles are arranged in a square grid maintaining equal spacing in all directions. Each pile is of diameter [latex]300 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] and length [latex]7 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]. Assume that the soil is cohesionless with effective friction angle [latex]\phi^{\prime}=32^{\circ}[/latex]. What is the center-to-center spacing of the piles (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) for the pile group efficiency of [latex]60 \%[/latex] ?
solution:
[latex]
\mathrm{n}=9
[/latex] Dia. of pile [latex]=300 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Length of pile [latex](\mathrm{L})=7 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] Using the Converse Labarre formula. [latex]m=3, \quad n=3[/latex] [latex]
n_{g}=1-\frac{\theta}{90} \frac{[m(n-1)+n(m-1)]}{m n}
[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
0.6 & =1-\frac{\theta}{90} \times \frac{3 \times 2+3 \times 2}{3 \times 3} \\
\frac{\theta}{90} \times \frac{12}{9} & =0.4 \\
\theta & =\frac{0.9 \times 9 \times 90}{12} \\
\tan \theta & =\tan \left(\frac{0.4 \times 9 \times 90}{12}\right) \\
\frac{d}{s} & =\tan \theta \\
\frac{0.3 \mathrm{~m}}{\mathrm{~s}} & =0.5095 \Rightarrow \mathrm{S}=0.588 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Alternatively, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Group efficiency }=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{ug}}}{\mathrm{n} \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{us}}} \\
& \Rightarrow 0.6=\frac{\frac{1}{2}(\gamma \mathrm{l}) \tan \delta(2 \mathrm{~S}+\mathrm{d}) \times 1 \times 4}{9 \times \frac{1}{2}(\gamma \mathrm{l}) \tan \delta(\mathrm{pdl})} \\
& \Rightarrow 0.6 \frac{(2 \mathrm{~S}+\mathrm{d}) \times 4}{9 \times \pi \mathrm{d}} \\
& \Rightarrow \mathrm{~S}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{0.6 \times 9 \times \pi \times 0.3}{4}-0.3\right]=0.486
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Note:
As the exact answer of spacing is not matching with the given options by E Converse-Labarre formula, therefore we will use alternative method to find spacing.

question: Question 53 The specific gravity of a soil is 2.60 . The soil is at [latex]50 \%[/latex] degree of saturation with a water content of [latex]15 \%[/latex]. The void ratio of the soil is
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{s}} & =2.60 \\
\mathrm{~S} & =50 \% \\
\mathrm{w} & =15 \%
\end{aligned}
[/latex] We know, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{s}} & =\omega \mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{s}} \\
\mathrm{e} \times 0.5 & =0.15 \times 2.60 \\
\mathrm{e} & =\frac{0.15 \times 2.60}{0.5} \\
\mathrm{e} & =0.78
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:
Question 54 A saturated compressible clay layer of thickness h is sandwiched between two
sand layers, as shown in the figure. Initially, the total vertical stress and pore
water pressure at point P, which is located at the mid-depth of the clay layer,
were 150 kPa and 25 kPa, respectively. Construction of a building caused an
additional total vertical stress of 100 kPa at P. When the vertical effective stress
at P is 175 kPa, the percentage of consolidation in the clay layer at P is
_____________. (in integer)
solution:
Initial effective stress at P [latex]\sigma _{P_1}'=150-25=125kPa [/latex] After construction, [latex]\sigma _{P_2}'=125+100=225kPa [/latex] 100% consolidation will occur when effective stress
at P reaches 225 kPa. Percentage of consolidation when vertical effective
stress is at P is 175 kPa. [latex]=\frac{175-125}{225-125} \times 100=\frac{50}{100} \times 100=50 [/latex]

question:
Question 55 A group of total 16 piles are arranged in a square grid format. The center-to-
center spacing (s) between adjacent piles is 3 m. The diameter (d) and length of embedment of each pile are 1 m and 20 m, respectively. The design capacity of
each pile is 1000 kN in the vertical downward direction. The pile group efficiency
( [latex]\eta _g[/latex]) is given by [latex]\eta _g=1-\frac{\theta }{90}\left [ \frac{(n-1)m+(m-1)n}{mn}  \right ][/latex] where m and n are number of rows and columns in the plan grid of pile
arrangement, and  [latex]\theta =\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{d}{s} \right )[/latex]. The design value of the pile group capacity (in kN) in the vertical downward
direction is __________________. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\eta _g&=1-\frac{\theta }{90}\left \{ \frac{m(n-1)+n(m-1)}{mn} \right \} \\
\theta &=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{d}{s} \right )=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )=18.43^{\circ}\\
\eta _g&=\frac{Q_{ug}}{nQ_{up}}\\
Q_{ug}&=\left [ 1-\frac{18.43}{90}\left \{ \frac{4(4-1)+4(4-1)}{4 \times 4} \right \} \right ](16 \times 1000)\\
&=11085kN
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 56 A soil sample is underlying a water column of height [latex]h_1[/latex], as shown in the figure.
The vertical effective stresses at points A, B, and C are [latex]\sigma '_A[/latex], [latex]\sigma '_B[/latex], and [latex]\sigma '_C[/latex] respectively. Let [latex]\gamma _{sat}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma '[/latex] be the saturated and submerged unit weights of the
soil sample, respectively, and [latex]\gamma _{w}[/latex] be the unit weight of water. Which one of the
following expressions correctly represents the sum ([latex]\sigma '_A+ \sigma '_B+\sigma '_C[/latex] )?
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\sigma _A'&=0\\
\sigma _B'&=h_2\gamma '\\
\sigma _C'&=(h_2+h_3)\gamma '\\
\sigma _A'+\sigma _B'+\sigma _C'&=(2h_2+h_3)\gamma '\\
\end{aligned} [/latex]

In a triaxial compression test, with increase
of axial strain in loose sand under drained
shear condition, the volumetric strain
decreases. As the sample is compressing. Hence, volume is decreasing. In a triaxial compression test, with increase
of axial strain in loose sand under undrained
shear condition, the excess pore water
pressure increases. (R) In a triaxial compression test, the pore pressure
parameter ?B? for a saturated soil is 1. (S) For shallow strip footing in pure saturated
clay, Terzaghi's bearing capacity factor (Nq) due to surcharge is 1.

question:
Question 58 In a triaxial unconsolidated undrained (UU) test on a saturated clay sample, the
cell pressure was 100 kPa. If the deviatoric stress at failure was 150 kPa, then
the undrained shear strength of the soil is _________ kPa. (in integer)
solution: [latex] \sigma _3=\sigma _c=100kPa , \sigma _d=\sigma _1-\sigma _3=150kPa[/latex] For UU test Undrained shear strenth [latex] C_{uu}=\tau _f=\frac{\sigma _1-\sigma _3}{2}=\frac{150}{2}=75KPa[/latex]

question:
Question 59 A concentrically loaded isolated square footing of size 2 m x 2 m carries a
concentrated vertical load of 1000 kN. Considering Boussinesq's theory of stress
distribution, the maximum depth (in m) of the pressure bulb corresponding to
10% of the vertical load intensity will be ________. (round off to two
decimal places)
solution:
Considering Boussinesq's theory of stress
distribution [latex]\sigma _x=\frac{3Q}{2\pi z^2}\left [ \frac{1}{1+\left ( \frac{r}{z} \right )^2} \right ]^{5/2} [/latex] For [latex]r=0,  \sigma _z=\frac{3Q}{2\pi z^2}[/latex] [latex] \sigma _z=0.1q=0.1 \times \frac{Q}{B^2}=\frac{0.1}{2^2}Q[/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{40}Q=\frac{3Q}{2 \pi z^2} [/latex] [latex] z^2=\frac{3 \times 40}{2 \pi}\Rightarrow z=4.37m[/latex]

question:
Question 60 The inside diameter of a sampler tube is 50 mm. The inside diameter of the
cutting edge is kept such that the Inside Clearance Ratio (ICR) is 1.0% to
minimize the friction on the sample as the sampler tube enters into the soil. The inside diameter (in mm) of the cutting edge is ________.
(round off to two decimal places)
solution:
Moisture content [latex]\begin{aligned}
C_i&=\frac{D_3-D-1}{D_1} \times 100\\
1&=\frac{50-D_1}{D_1} \times 100\\
D_1&=49.50mm
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 61 Read the following statements: (P) While designing a shallow footing in sandy soil, monsoon season is
considered for critical design in terms of bearing capacity. (Q) For slope stability of an earthen dam, sudden drawdown is never a critical
condition. (R) In a sandy sea beach, quicksand condition can arise only if the critical
hydraulic gradient exceeds the existing hydraulic gradient. (S) The active earth thrust on a rigid retaining wall supporting homogeneous
cohesionless backfill will reduce with the lowering of water table in the
backfill. Which one of the following combinations is correct?
solution:
In monsoon season sand will be fully
saturated hence this will be critical condition
in designing of shallow foundation. In case of sudden drawdown flow direction
reverses hence for slope stability, it will be
critical condition. In sandy sea beach, quicksand condition can
arise only if existing hydraulic gradient
exceeds the critical hydraulic gradient.

question:
Question 62 A raft foundation of 30 m x 25 m is proposed to be constructed at a depth of 8 m
in a sand layer. A 25 m thick saturated clay layer exists 2 m below the base of
the raft foundation. Below the clay layer, a dense sand layer exists at the site.
A 25 mm thick undisturbed sample was collected from the mid-depth of the clay
layer and tested in a laboratory oedometer under double drainage condition. It
was found that the soil sample had undergone 50% consolidation settlement in
10 minutes. The time (in days) required for 25% consolidation settlement of the raft
foundation will be ______. (round off to the nearest integer)

Question 63 A square concrete pile of 10 m length is driven into a deep layer of uniform
homogeneous clay. Average unconfined compressive strength of the clay,
determined through laboratory tests on undisturbed samples extracted from the
clay layer, is 100 kPa. If the ultimate compressive load capacity of the driven
pile is 632 kN, the required width of the pile is _______ mm. (in integer) (Bearing capacity factor [latex]N_c 9[/latex]; adhesion factor [latex]\alpha =0.7 [/latex])
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
Q_{up}&=q_bA_b+q_sA_s\\
C_u&=\frac{q_u}{2}=\frac{100}{2}=50kN/m^2\\
&=9 \times CB^2+\alpha \bar{C}(4BL)\\
632kN&=9 \times 50 \times B^2 +0.7  \times 50(4B \times 10)\\
B&=0.4m\\
B&=400mm
\end{aligned} [/latex]

Question 66 At a site, Static Cone Penetration Test was carried out. The measured point (tip)
resistance [latex]q_c[/latex] was 1000 kPa at a certain depth. The friction ratio ([latex]f_r[/latex]) was estimated as 1% at the same depth. The value of sleeve (side) friction (in kPa) at that depth was _______ . (in integer)
solution:
Friction ratio, [latex]
f_r=\frac{q_s}{q_t}=1 %[/latex] [latex]q_s=[/latex] Sleeve friction [latex]q_t=[/latex] Tip friction [latex]\frac{q_s}{q_t}=\frac{1}{100}[/latex] [latex]q_s=\frac{1000}{100}=10 kPa[/latex]

question:
Question 67 A concentrated vertical load of 3000 kN is applied on a horizontal ground
surface. Points P and Q are at depths 1 m and 2 m below the ground,
respectively, along the line of application of the load. Considering the ground to
be a linearly elastic, isotropic, semi-infinite medium, the ratio of the increase in
vertical stress at P to the increase in vertical stress at Q is ________. (in integer)
solution:
Increase in vertical stress, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\sigma _z&=\frac{KQ}{z^2}\\
\sigma _z&\propto \frac{1}{z^2}\\
\frac{\sigma _P}{\sigma _Q}&=\left ( \frac{z_Q}{z_P} \right )^2\\
&=\left ( \frac{2}{1} \right )^2=4
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 An uncompacted heap of soil has a volume of 10000 [latex]m^3[/latex] and void ratio of 1. If the soil is compacted to a volume of 7500 [latex]m^3[/latex], then the corresponding void ratio of the compacted soil is __________. (round off to one decimal place)
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
(V_S)_{\text{heap}}&=(V_S)_{\text{compacted soil}}\\
\left ( \frac{V_T}{1+e} \right )_{\text{heap}}&=\left ( \frac{V_T}{1+e} \right )_{\text{compacted soil}}\\
\frac{10000}{1+1}&=\frac{7500}{1+e}\\
e&=0.5
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 73 The void ratio of a clay soil sample M decreased from 0.575 to 0.510 when the applied pressure is increased from 120 kPa to 180 kPa. For the same increment in pressure, the void ratio of another clay soil sample N decreases from 0.600 to 0.550. If the ratio of hydraulic conductivity of sample M to sample N  is 0.125, then the ratio of coefficient of consolidation of sample M to sample N (round off to three decimal places) is ______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m_{v}&=\frac{a_{V}}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{\Delta e}{\left(1+e_{0}\right) \times(\Delta \bar{\sigma})} & (\Delta \bar{\sigma} \text { is same for both } M \text { and } N)\\ m_{v 1}&=\frac{0.575-0.510}{(1+0.575) \times \Delta \bar{\sigma}}\\ m_{v 2}&=\frac{0.600-0.550}{(1+0.600) \times \Delta \bar{\sigma}}\\ \frac{C_{v_{1}}}{C_{V_{2}}} &=\frac{\frac{k_{1}}{m_{v_{1}} \gamma_{w}}}{\frac{k_{2}}{m_{v_{2}} \gamma_{w}}}=\frac{k_{1}}{k_{2}} \times \frac{m_{v_{2}}}{m_{v_{1}}} \\ &=0.125\left(\frac{1.575}{1.6}\right) \times\left(\frac{0.60-0.55}{0.575-0.510}\right) \\ &=0.0947 \simeq 0.095 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The soil profile at a road construction site is as shown in figure (not to scale). A large embankment is to be constructed at the site. The ground water table (GWT) is located at the surface of the clay layer, and the capillary rise in the sandy soil is negligible. The effective stress at the middle of the clay layer after the application of the embankment loading is [latex]180 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. Take unit weight of water, [latex]\gamma_{w}=9.81 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The primary consolidation settlement (in m, round off to two decimal places) of the clay layer resulting from this loading will be ______
solution: Primary consolidation settlement [latex]\Delta H=\frac{C_{c} H}{1+e_{0}} \log _{10}\left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right)[/latex] [latex]\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}=[/latex]Effective stress at the center of clay layer after embankment loading [latex]=180 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] [latex]\bar{\sigma}_{0}=[/latex] Effective stress at the centre of clay layer before embankment loading [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma_{\text {sub }} \text { of clay layer } &=\frac{G-1}{1+e} \gamma_{w}=\frac{(2.65-1)}{1+\frac{w G}{1}} \times 9.81 \\ &=\frac{1.65 \times 9.81}{1+0.45 \times 2.65}=7.383 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \bar{\sigma}_{0} &=(18.5 \times 2)+(7.383) \times 3=59.149 \mathrm{kNm} /{ } \\ e_{0} &=\frac{w G}{1}=0.45 \times 2.65=1.1925 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad & \Delta \mathrm{H}=\frac{0.25 \times 6}{1+1.1925} \log _{10}\left(\frac{180}{59.149}\right)=0.33 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 A rectangular footing of size 2.8m x 3.5m is embedded in a clay layer and a vertical load is placed with an eccentricity of 0.8 m as shown in the figure (not to scale). Take Bearing capacity factors: [latex]N_{c}=5.14[/latex],[latex]N_{q}=1.0[/latex], and [latex]N_{\gamma}=0.0[/latex]; Shape factors: [latex]s_{c}=1.16[/latex],[latex]s_{q}=1.0[/latex] and [latex]s_{\gamma}=1.0[/latex]; Depth factors: [latex]d_{c}=1.1[/latex],[latex]d_{q}=1.0[/latex] and [latex]d_{\gamma}=1.0[/latex]; and Inclination factors: [latex]i_{c}=1.0[/latex] and [latex]i_{q}=1.0[/latex] and [latex]i_{\gamma}=1.0[/latex]. Using Meyerhoff's method, the load (in kN, round off to two decimal places) that can be applied on the footing with a factor of safety of 2.5 is _________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}& \text { Given data: } 2.8 \times 3.56, e=0.8, D_{f}=1.5 \mathrm{~m} \\ N_{c}&=5.14, \qquad N_{q}=1, \qquad N_{r}=0 \\ S_{c}&=1.16, \qquad S_{q}=1, \qquad S_{r}=1.0 \\ d_{c}&=1.1, \qquad d_{q}=1, \qquad d_{f}=1.0 \\ i_{c}&=1, \qquad \quad i_{q}=1, \qquad i_{r}=1.0 \\ \gamma&=18.2, \qquad c=40 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ B^{\prime}&=B-2 e_{x}=2.8-2(0.8)=1.2 \mathrm{~m} \\ L^{\prime}&=L=3.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ultimate bearing capacity [latex]\begin{aligned} q_{u} &=C N_{c} S_{c} d_{c} i_{c}+\gamma D_{p} N_{q} S_{q} d_{q} i_{q}+0.5 B^{\prime} \gamma N_{r} S_{r} d_{r} \\ q_{u} &=40 \times 5.14 \times 1.16 \times 1.1+18.2 \times 1.5 \times 1+0 \\ q_{n u} &=q_{u}-\gamma D_{f}=262.346 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ q_{n s} &=\frac{q_{n u}}{F}=104.938 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Net safe load } &=q_{n s} \times A=\frac{q_{n u}}{F} \times\left(B^{\prime} \times L\right) \\ &=104.938 \times 1.2 \times 3.5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Load applied on the footing = 440.740 kN

question: Question 76 An elevated cylindrical water storage tank is shown in the figure. The tank has inner diameter of 1.5 m. It is supported on a solid steel circular column of diameter 75 mm and total height (L) of 4m.Take, water density=[latex]1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and acceleration due to gravity = [latex]10 \mathrm{m/s}^{2}[/latex]. If elastic modulus (E) of steel is 200 GPa, ignoring self-weight of the tank, for the supporting steel column to remain unbuckled, the maximum depth (h) of the water permissible (in m, round off to one decimal place) is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{cr}&=\frac{\pi ^2 EI}{L^2} =\text{Buckling load }=\text{weight of water} \\ \frac{\pi ^2 EI}{(2L)^2}&=(\rho gh) \times \frac{\pi}{4}d^2 =\rho g \times \text{volume of tank}\\ &\frac{\pi ^2 \times 200 \times 10^9 \times \pi (75 \times 10^{-3})^4}{(2 \times 4)^2 \times 64}=1000 \times 10 \times h \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times 1.5^2\\ h&=2.7\; m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 From laboratory investigations, the liquid limit, plastic limit, natural moisture content and flow index of a soil specimen are obtained as 60%, 27%, 32% and 27%, respectively. The corresponding toughness index and liquidity index of the soil specimen, respectively, are
solution: Flow index = 27 [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Plasticity index, } \qquad I_{P}&=W_{L}-W_{P}=33 \\ \text { Toughness index, } \qquad I_{T}&=\frac{I_{P}}{I_{f}}=\frac{33}{27}=1.22 \\ \text { Liquidity index, } \qquad I_{L}&=\frac{W_{n}-W_{P}}{W_{L}-W_{P}}=0.151 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 78 A clay layer of thickness H has a preconsolidation pressure [latex]p_{c}[/latex]
 and an initial void ratio [latex]e_{0}[/latex].The initial effective overburden stress at the mid-height of the layer is [latex]p_{0}[/latex]. At the same location, the increment in effective stress due to applied external load is [latex]\Delta p[/latex]. The compression and swelling indices of the clay are [latex]C_{c}[/latex]
 and [latex]C_{s}[/latex], respectively. If  [latex]p_{0} \lt p_{c}  \lt  \left(p_{0}+\Delta p\right)[/latex], then the correct expression to estimate the consolidation settlement [latex]\left(S_{c}\right)[/latex] of the clay layer is
solution: As the soil is initially in over consolidate state [latex](p_o  \lt  p_c)[/latex], due to the external applied load [latex](\Delta p)[/latex] the soil initially undergoes re-compression upto [latex](p_c)[/latex] and then changes to virgin compression from [latex](p_c)[/latex] to [latex](p_f)[/latex] The re-compression index  [latex](C_r)[/latex]  is also called Swelling index, [latex](C_S)[/latex]. [latex]s_{c}=\frac{H}{I+e_{0}} \left[C_{s} \log \frac{p_{c}}{p_{0}}+C_{c} \log \frac{p_{0}+\Delta p}{p_{c}}\right][/latex]

question: Question 80 The most appropriate triaxial test to assess the long-term stability of an excavated clay slope is

question: Question 81 An unsupported slope of height 15 m is shown in the figure (not to scale), in which the slope face makes an angle [latex]50^{\circ} [/latex] with the horizontal. The slope material comprises purely cohesive soil having undrained cohesion 75 kPa. A trial slip circle KLM, with a radius 25 m, passes through the crest and toe of the slope and it subtends an  angle [latex]60^{\circ} [/latex] at its center O. The weight of the active soil mass (W, bounded by KLMN) is 2500 kN/m, which is acting at a horizontal distance of 10 m from the toe of the slope. Consider the water table to be present at a very large depth from the ground surface. Considering the trail slip circle KLM, the factor of the safety against the failure of slope under undrained condition (round off to two decimal places) is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\begin{aligned} \mathrm{FOS} &=\frac{\text { Resisting moment }}{\text { Actuating moment }} \\ \mathrm{FOS} &=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{u}} l R}{w \bar{x}} \\ l &=\text { Length of ac } \mathrm{KLM} \\ \bar{x} &=\text { Distance of ' } \mathrm{w}^{\prime} \text { from toe } \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \quad \mathrm{FOS} &=\frac{75 \times 2 \pi \times 25 \times \frac{60}{36} \times 25}{2500 \times 10} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \quad \mathrm{FOS} &=1.96 \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 A retaining wall of height 10 m with clay backfill is shown in the figure (not to scale). Weight of the retaining wall is 5000 kN per m acting at 3.3 m from the toe of the retaining wall. The interface friction angle between base of the retaining wall and the base soil is [latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]. The depth of clay in front of the retaining wall is 2.0 m. The properties of the clay backfill and the clay placed in front of the retaining wall are the same. Assume that the tension crack is filled with water. Use Rankine's earth pressure theory. Take unit weight of water, [latex]\gamma_{w}=9.81 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The factor of safety (round off to two decimal places) against sliding failure of the retaining wall after ignoring the passive earth pressure will be ________________
solution: Depth of tension crack, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{C}&=\frac{2 C}{\gamma }  \text {  If } \phi=0 \\ &=\frac{2 \times 30}{17.2 }=3.488 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Tension crack develops only in the back fill (clay) The tension crack will not develop in the clay which is infront of the wall. The total active thrust on the wall, due to the backfill, and the water in the tension crack [latex]F_a=k_a\cdot \frac{\gamma H^2}{2}-2C\sqrt{k_a}\cdot H+\frac{2C^2}{\gamma }+\frac{\gamma _wz_c^2}{2}[/latex] [latex]k_a=1 \text{ since }\phi =0[/latex] [latex]F_a=1 \times \frac{17.2 \times 10^2}{2}-2 \times 30\sqrt{1} \times 10+\frac{2 \times 30^2}{17.2 }+\frac{9.81 \times 3.488^2}{2}=424.326 \; kN[/latex] Factor of safety against sliding neglecting passive earth pressure on front side, [latex]F_s[/latex] [latex]F_s=\frac{\mu \cdot W}{F_a}[/latex] [latex]\mu =[/latex] coefficient of friction at base [latex]= \tan \delta[/latex] [latex]F_s=\frac{\tan \delta \cdot W}{F_a}=\frac{\tan 20^{\circ} \times 5000}{424.326}=4.2888\approx 4.29[/latex]

question: Question 83 The soil profile at a construction site is shown in the figure (not to scale). Ground water table (GWT) is at 5 m below the ground level at present. An old well data shows that the ground water table was as low as 10 m below the ground level in the past. Take unit weight of water, [latex]\gamma_{W}=9.81 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The overconsolidation ratio (OCR)(round off to two decimal places) at the mid-point of the clay layer is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{OCR} &=\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{c}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}} \\ \bar{\sigma}_{c} &=\text { Preconsolidation stress } \\ \bar{\sigma}_{0} &=\text { Present effective stress } \\ \bar{\sigma}_{c} &=17.5 \times 10+(18.5-9.81) \times 5+(17-9.81) \times 4 \\ &=247.21 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \bar{\sigma}_{0} &=17.5 \times 5+(18.5-9.81) \times 10+(17-9.81) \times 4 \\ &=203.16 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \mathrm{OCR} &=\frac{247.21}{203.16}=1.22 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 84 Based on drained triaxial shear tests on sands and clays, the representative variations of volumetric strain [latex](\Delta V / V)[/latex] with the shear strain [latex](\gamma)[/latex] is shown in the figure. Choose the CORRECT option regarding the representative behaviour exhibited by Curve P and Curve Q.

options.A: Curve P represents dense sand and overconsolidated clay, while Curve Q represents loose sand and normally consolidated clay
options.B: Curve P represents dense sand and normally consolidated clay, while Curve Q represents loose sand and overconsolidated clay
options.C: Curve P represents loose sand and overconsolidated clay, while Curve Q represents dense sand and normally consolidated clay
options.D: Curve P represents loose sand and normally consolidated clay, while Curve Q represents dense sand and overconsolidated clay

question:
Question 85 The cohesion (c), angle of internal friction [latex](\phi)[/latex] and unit weight [latex](\gamma)[/latex] of a soil are [latex]15 \mathrm{kPa}, 20^{\circ}[/latex]
 and [latex]17.5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], respectively. The maximum depth of unsupported excavation in the soil (in m, round off to two decimal places) is __________
solution: Maximum depth of unsupported excavation, [latex]\begin{aligned} H&=\frac{4 C}{\gamma_{t} \sqrt{k_{a}}} \\ k_{a}&=\frac{1-\sin \phi}{1+\sin \phi}=\frac{1-\sin 20^{\circ}}{1+\sin 20^{\circ}}=0.49 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad H&=\frac{4 \times 15}{17.5 \sqrt{0.49}}=4.9 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 A partially-saturated soil sample has natural moisture content of 25% and bulk unit weight of [latex]18.5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The specific gravity of soil solids is 2.65 and unit weight of water is [latex]9.81 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]. The unit weight of the soil sample on full saturation is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{w} &=0.25, \gamma_{\mathrm{t}}=18.5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{s}} &=2.65, \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}=9.81 \\ \gamma_{\mathrm{t}} &=\frac{G_{\mathrm{S}} \gamma_{W}(1+w)}{1+e} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \mathrm{e} &=\frac{2.65 \times 9.81 \times 1.25}{18.5}-1\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad e&=0.756\\ \text{At full saturation}, \quad \mathrm{S}&=1\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \quad \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}&=\frac{\left(G_{\mathrm{S}}+e\right) \gamma_{\mathrm{W}}}{1+e}\\ \gamma_{\text {sat }} &=\frac{(2.65+0.756) \times 9.81}{1.756} \\ &=19.03 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 In an Oedometer apparatus, a specimen of fully saturated clay has been consolidated under a vertical pressure of [latex]50 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] and is presently at equilibrium. The effective stress and pore water pressure immediately on increasing the vertical stress to [latex]150 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], respectively are
solution: Stress is increased suddenly, hence entire change will be taken by water [latex]\Delta \bar{\sigma}=\Delta U=100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. There will be no change in effective stress [latex]\therefore \qquad \qquad\bar{\sigma}=50 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]

question:
Question 88 A 5 m high vertical wall has a saturated clay backfill. The saturation unit weight and
cohesion of clay are [latex]18kN/m^3[/latex] and 20 kPa, respectively. The angle of internal friction
of clay is zero. In order to prevent development of tension zone, the height of the wall
is required to be increased. Dry sand is used as backfill above the clay for the increased
portion of the wall. The unit weight and angle of internal friction of sand are [latex]16kN/m^3[/latex]
and [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex], respectively. Assume that the back of the wall is smooth and top of the backfill
is horizontal. To prevent the development of tension zone, the minimum height (in m,
round off to one decimal place) by which the wall has to be raised, is __________.
solution: To prevent tension crack, [latex]\begin{aligned} q&=\frac{2c}{\sqrt{k_a}}=\frac{2 \times 20}{1}=40\\ q&=\gamma _d x=40\\ x&=\frac{40}{16}=2.5m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 89 A constant head permeability test was conducted on a soil specimen under a hydraulic
gradient of 2.5. The soil specimen has specific gravity of 2.65 and saturated water content
of 20%. If the coefficient of permeability of the soil is 0.1 cm/s, the seepage velocity
(in cm/s, round off to two decimal places) through the soil specimen is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Void ratio,}\; e&=\frac{wG}{s}\\ &=\frac{0.2 \times 2.65}{1}=0.53\\ \text{Porosity,}\; n&=\frac{e}{1+e}=0.3464\\ \text{Seepage velocity,}\; V_s&=\frac{v}{n}=\frac{k_i}{n}\\ &=\frac{0.1 \times 2.5}{0.3464}=0.72 cm/sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 A footing of size 2m x 2m transferring a pressure of 200 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex], is placed at a depth
of 1.5 m below the ground as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The clay
stratum is normally consolidated. The clay has specific gravity of 2.65 and compression
index of 0.3. Considering 2:1 (vertical to horizontal) method of load distribution and [latex]\gamma _w = 10 kN/m^3[/latex],
the primary consolidation settlement (in mm, round off to two decimal places) of the clay
stratum is _________.
solution: For clay layer, [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _{sat}&=\left ( \frac{G+e}{1+e} \right )\gamma _w \\ &= \left ( \frac{2.65+1}{1+e} \right )10=17kNm^3\\ e_0&=1.357 \\ H_0&=1.5m \\ (\bar{\sigma _0})_{c-c}&=[2\gamma _d+0.5\gamma _{sat}+0.75\gamma _{sat}]-1.25\gamma _w \\ &= (2 \times 15+0.5 \times 15+0.75 \times 17)-1.25 \times 10\\ &= 39.25kN/m^2\\ \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=\frac{Force}{Area} \\ &= \frac{qB^2}{(B+2nZ)^2}\\ &=\frac{200 \times 2 \times 2}{(2 \times 2 \times \frac{1}{2} \times 1.75)^2}\\ &=56.88kN/m^2\\ \Delta H&=\frac{H_0C_c}{1+e_0} \log \left ( \frac{\bar{\sigma _0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma }}{\bar{\sigma_0 }} \right )\\ &=\frac{1.5 \times 0.3}{1+1.357} \log \left ( \frac{39.25+56.88}{39.25} \right )\\ &=74.27mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 91 A 10 m high slope of dry clay soil (unit weight = 20 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]), with a slope angle of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]
and the circular slip surface, is shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The weight
of the slip wedge is denoted by W. The undrained unit cohesion ([latex]c_u[/latex]) is 60 kPa. The factor of safety of the slope against slip failure, is
