solution: As per GATE Official Answer Key MTA (Marks to All) Consider unit length of slope Area of circular arc [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{\theta }{360} \times \pi r^2-\text{Area of }\Delta \\ &=\frac{90}{360} \times \pi \times 10^2-\frac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 10\\ &=28.54m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Height of wedge}& = \text{Volume} \times \gamma \\ &=(\text{Area} \times 1) \times \gamma \\ &=28.54 \times 1 \times 20\\ &=570.8 kN\\ FOS&=\frac{M_R}{M_0}\\ &=\frac{[c \times (r\theta )]\times r}{W \times x}\\ &=\frac{60 \times 10 \times \frac{\pi}{1} \times 10}{570.8 \times 4.48}\\ &=3.68 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 92 Permeability tests were carried out on the samples collected from two different layers
as shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale). The relevant horizontal ([latex]k_h[/latex]) and vertical
([latex]k_v[/latex]) coefficients of permeability are indicated for each layer. The ratio of the equivalent horizontal to vertical coefficients of permeability, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{k_{eq.H}}{k_{eq.V}}&=\frac{\frac{\Sigma K_iZ_i}{\Sigma Z_i}}{\frac{\Sigma Z_i}{\Sigma \frac{Z_i}{K_i}}}\\ &=\frac{\frac{4.4 \times 10^{-3} \times 3 +6 \times 10^{-1} \times 4}{7}}{\frac{7}{\frac{3}{4 \times 10^{-3}}+\frac{4}{5.5 \times 10^{-1}}}}\\ &=\frac{0.3447}{9.24 \times 10{-3}}=37.29 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 A one-dimensional consolidation test is carried out on a standard 19 mm thick clay
sample. The oedometer's deflection gauge indicates a reading of 2.1 mm, just
before removal of the load, without allowing any swelling. The void ratio is 0.62
at this stage. The initial void ratio (round off to two decimal places) of the standard
specimen is ________.
solution: Oedometer reading = 2.1 mm 16 mm thick, e = 0.62 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\Delta H}{H_0}&=\frac{\Delta e}{1+e_0}=\frac{e_0-e_f}{1+e_0} \\ \frac{2.1 mm}{19mm} &=\frac{e_0-0.62}{1+e_0} \\ e_0&=0.82 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 94 A soil has dry weight of 15.5 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex], specific gravity of 2.65 and degree of saturation
of 72%. Considering the unit weight of water as 10 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex], the water content of the soil
(in %, round off to two decimal places) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _d&=15.5 kN/m^3\\ G&=2.65\\ S&=72\% \\ \gamma _d&=\frac{G\gamma _w}{1+e}\\ &=\frac{2.65 \times 10}{1+e}=15.5\\ e&=0.7096\\ w&=\frac{Se}{G}=\frac{0.72 \times 0.7096}{2.65}=0.1928\\ w&=19.28\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 95 A sample of 500 g dry sand, when poured into a 2 litre capacity cylinder which is partially
filled with water, displaces 188 [latex]cm^3[/latex] of water. The density of water is 1 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]. The specific
gravity of the sand is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_s&=500gm \\ V_s&=188cc \\ \gamma _s&=\frac{W_s}{V_s} \\ G_s&=\frac{\gamma _s}{\gamma _w}\\&=\frac{500/188}{1}=2.66 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 Soil deposit formed due to transportation by wind is termed as
solution: Soil deposited by wind is Aeolian soil.

question:
Question 97 A 10 m thick clay layer is resting over a 3 m thick sand layer and is submerged. A
fill of 2 m thick sand with unit weight of 20 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex] is placed above the clay layer to
accelerate the rate of consolidation of the clay layer. Coefficient of consolidation of clay
is [latex]9 \times 10^{-2} m^2/year[/latex] and coefficient of volume compressibility of clay is [latex]2.2 \times 10^{-4} m^2/kN[/latex].
Assume Taylor?s relation between time factor and average degree of consolidation. The settlement (in mm, round off to two decimal places) of the clay layer, 10 years after
the construction of the fill, is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=2 \times 20=40 kN/m^2\\ \Delta H&=m_v\Delta \bar{\sigma }H \\ &= 2.2 \times 10^{-4} \times 40 \times 10 \times 10^3 mm\\ &= 88 mm\\ T_v&=\frac{C \times t}{H^2} \\ &= \frac{9 \times 10^{-2}\times 10}{5^2}=0.036\\ T_v&=\frac{\pi}{4}U^2 \\ U&=\sqrt{\frac{0.036 \times 4}{\pi}}=0.214 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Delta h[/latex] after 10 year [latex]=0.214 \times 88=18.832 mm[/latex]

question:
Question 98 Water flows in the upward direction in a tank through 2.5 m thick sand layer as shown
in the figure. The void ratio and specific gravity of sand are 0.58 and 2.7, respectively.
The sand is fully saturated. Unit weight of water is 10 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. The effective stress (in kPa, round off to two decimal places) at point A, located 1 m
above the base of tank, is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _{suv}&=\left ( \frac{G-1}{1+e} \right )\gamma _\omega \\ &=\left ( \frac{2.7-1}{1+0.58} \right ) \times 10\\ &=10.759\\ \bar{\sigma }&=z\gamma _{suv}-iz\gamma _\omega \\ &=1.5(\gamma _{suv})-\left ( \frac{1.2}{2.5} \right )\times 1.5 \times \gamma _\omega \\ &=8.939 kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 A vertical retaining wall of 5 m height has to support soil having unit weight of 18[latex]kN/m^3[/latex],
effective cohesion of 12 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex], and effective friction angle of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex]. As per Rankine's earth
pressure theory and assuming that a tension crack has occurred, the lateral active thrust
on the wall per meter length (in kN/m, round off to two decimal places), is ______.
solution: After tension crack [latex]\begin{aligned} P_a&=\frac{1}{2}\times 16.144(5-2.309)\\ &=21.714kN/m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 100 The soil profile at a site up to a depth of 10 m is shown in the figure (not drawn to the
scale). The soil is preloaded with a uniform surcharge (q) of 70 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex] at the ground
level. The water table is at a depth of 3 m below ground level. The soil unit weight of
the respective layers is shown in the figure. Consider unit weight of water as 9.81 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]
and assume that the surcharge (q) is applied instantaneously. Immediately after preloading, the effective stresses (in kPa) at points P and Q respectively,
are
solution:
Surcharge ([latex]q=70kN/m^2[/latex]) is applied instantaneously hence excess pore pressure
([latex]u_i=70kPa[/latex]) is developed at point P and Q [GWT level is at level P] At point P: Total stress [latex]\sigma =q+3\gamma =70+3\times 18[/latex] Pore water pressure = Hydrostatics pore pressure
+ Excess pore pressure [latex]=0+u_i=0+70=70kN/m^2[/latex] Effective stress, [latex]\bar{\sigma }=\sigma -u=54kPa[/latex] At point Q: Total stress, [latex]\sigma= q+3\gamma +4\gamma _{sat}=70+3\times 18 +4 \times 20[/latex] Pore pressure, u = Hydrostatics pore pressure + Excess pore pressure [latex]= 4\gamma _{w}+u_i=4 \times 9.81 +70[/latex] Effective stress, [latex]\bar{\sigma }=\sigma -u=94.76kPa[/latex]

question:
Question 101 A fully submerged infinite sandy slope has an inclination of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] with the horizontal. The
saturated unit weight and effective angle of internal friction of sand are 18 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex] and
[latex]38^{\circ}[/latex], respectively. The unit weight of water is 10 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. Assume that the seepage is
parallel to the slope. Against shear failure of the slope, the factor of safety (round off
to two decimal places) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F.O.S.&=\frac{\gamma '}{\gamma _{sat}} \frac{\tan \phi }{\tan \beta }\\ &=\left ( \frac{18-10}{18} \right )\frac{\tan 38^{\circ}}{\tan 30^{\circ}} \\ &=0.601 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 102 In a drained tri-axial compression test, a sample of sand fails at deviator stress of 150 kPa
under confining pressure of 50 kPa. The angle of internal friction (in degree, round off
to the nearest integer) of the sample, is ________
solution: [latex]\text{Sand }(C=0); \; \sigma _d=150;\; \sigma _3=50;\; \sigma _1=200 [/latex] [latex]\sigma _1=\sigma _3 \tan^2\left ( 45+\frac{\phi }{2} \right )+2c\tan \left ( 45+\frac{\phi }{2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]200=50 \tan^2 \left ( 45+\frac{\phi }{2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\phi =36.87^{\circ} [/latex] So, the angle of internal friction to the nearest integer is [latex]37^{\circ}[/latex].

question:
Question 103 In a soil investigation work at a site, Standard Penetration Test (SPT) was conducted
at every 1.5 m interval up to 30 m depth. At 3 m depth, the observed number of hammer
blows for three successive 150 mm penetrations were 8, 6 and 9, respectively. The SPT N-value at 3 m depth, is
solution: No. of blows for each 150 mm penetration 8, 6 and 9. We will not consider first 150 mm number of blows. Hence, for last 300 mm, number of blows are 15. Hence, observed SPT number = 15.

question: Question 104 Which one of the following statements is NOT correct?
solution: A clay deposit with liquidty index greater then 1, will be in liquid stage of consistency. [latex]\because \;\;I_L=\frac{w_n-w_p}{w_l-w_p} \gt 1[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; w_n \gt w_L[/latex]

options.A: A clay deposit with a liquidity index greater than unity is in a state of plastic consistency.
options.B:
The cohesion of normally consolidated clay is zero when tri-axial test is conducted
under consolidated undrained condition.
options.C:
The ultimate bearing capacity of a strip foundation supported on the surface of sandy
soil increase in direct proportion to the width of footing.
options.D:
In case of a point load, Boussinesq's equation predicts higher value of vertical stress
at a point directly beneath the load as compared to Westergaard's equation.

question: Question 105 A square footing of 2 m sides rests on the surface of a homogeneous soil bed having the properties: cohesion c=24 kPa, angle of internal friction [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex], and unit weight [latex]\gamma =18kN/m^3[/latex]. Terzaghi's bearing capacity factors for [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex] are [latex]N_c=25.1, N_q=12.7[/latex], [latex]N_{\gamma}=9.7, N_c'=14.8,N_q'=5.6[/latex], and [latex]N_{\gamma}'=3.2[/latex]. The ultimate bearing capacity of the foundation (in kPa, round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} c &=24kN/m^2 ,\; \phi =25^{\circ} \\ \gamma &=18 kN/m^3 ,\; N_c =25.1 \\ N_q&=12.7 ,\; N_\gamma =9.7 \\ N_c' &=14.8 ,\; N_q'=5.6 \\ N_\gamma '&=3.2 \\ &\text{Square footing}\\ B&=2m ,\;L=2m\\ D_f&=0\;\; (\text{Surface footing})\\ \text{since,}\;\;\phi &=25^{\circ} \lt 28^{\circ}\rightarrow \text{Assume local shear failure.}\\ \text{Hence,}\;\;&=c_m=\frac{2}{3}c=\frac{2}{3} \times 24=16kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ultimate bearing capacity of square footing, [latex]\begin{aligned} q_u&=1.3c_mN_c' +\gamma D_fN_q'+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma '\\ q_u&=1.3\times 16 \times 14.8+0+0.4 \times 18 \times 2 \times 3.2\\ q_u&=307.84+46.08\\ q_u&=353.92kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 A timber pile of length 8 m and diameter 0.2 m is driven with a 20 kN drop hammer, falling freely from a height of 1.5 m. The total penetration of the pile in the last 5 blows is 40 mm. Use the Engineering News Record expression. Assumea factor of safety of 6 and empirical factor (allowing reduction in the theoretical set, due to energy losses) of 2.5cm. The safe load carrying capacity of the pile (in kN, round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: L = 8 m; d = 0.2 m, 20 kN = W ( drop hammer) H = 1.5 m Penetration in 5 blows = 40 mm [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; \text{in 1 blow}&=\frac{40}{5}=8mm=0.8cm\\ Q_{safe}&=\left ( \frac{WH}{s+c} \right )\times \frac{1}{FOS}\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left [ \frac{20kN \times (1.5 \times 100)}{0.8cm+2.5cm} \right ]\\ Q_{safe}&=151.51kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 Constant head permeability tests were performed on two soil specimens, S1 and S2. The ratio of height of the two specimens ([latex]L_{S1}:L_{S2}[/latex]) is 1.5, the ratio of the diameter of specimens ([latex]D_{S1}:D_{S2}[/latex]) is 0.5, and the ratio of the constant head ([latex]h_{S1}:h_{S2}[/latex]) applied on the specimens is 2.0. If the discharge from both the specimens is equal, the ratio of the permeability of the soil specimens ([latex]k_{S1}:k_{S2}[/latex]) is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{L_{s1}}{L_{s2}}&=1.5\\ \frac{D_{s1}}{D_{s2}}&=0.5\\ \frac{h_{s1}}{h_{s2}}&=2\\ \frac{k_{s1}}{k_{s2}}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Discharge is same. [latex]\begin{aligned} k_1i_1A_1&=k_2i_2A_2\\ k_1\frac{h_{s1}}{L_{s1}} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times D_{s1}^2&=k_2\frac{h_{s2}}{L_{s2}} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times D_{s2}^2\\ \frac{k_{s1}}{k_{s2}}&=\frac{L_{s1}}{L_{s2}} \times \frac{h_{s2}}{h_{s1}} \times \frac{D_{s2}^2}{D_{s1}^2}\\ &=1.5 \times \frac{1}{2} \times \left ( \frac{1}{0.5} \right )^2=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 A 2mx 4m rectangular footing has to carry a uniformly distributed load of 120 kPa. As per the 2:1 dispersion method of stress distribution, the increment in vertical stress (in kPa) at a depth of 2m below the footing is ________
solution: The area of rectangular footing = 2 m x 4 m q = 120 kPa as 2:1 dispersion method of stress distribution [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=\frac{q(B \times L)}{(B+2nZ)(L+2nZ)}\\ &=\frac{120 \times 2 \times 4}{(2+2 \times \frac{1}{2}\times 2)(4+2 \times \frac{1}{2}\times 2)}\\ \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=40kPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 The dimensions of a soil sampler are given in the table. For this sampler, the outside clearance ratio (in percent, round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Outside clearance [latex]=\left ( \frac{D_2 -D_4}{D_4} \right ) \times 100[/latex] Outside clearance [latex]=\left ( \frac{100 -90}{90} \right ) \times 100 =11.11\%[/latex]

question: Question 110 Construction of a new building founded on a clayey soil was completed in January 2010. In January 2014, the average consolidation settlement of the foundation in clay was recorded as 10 mm. The ultimate consolidation settlement was estimated in design as 40 mm. Considering double drainage to occur at the clayey soil site, the expected consolidation settlement in January 2019 (in mm, round off to the nearestinteger) will be ________
solution: Jan. 2010 - Jan. 2014 (4 years) Settlement is 10 mm [latex]\Delta H = 40 mm[/latex] 2 - way drainage Settlement in Jan. 2019 (in 9 years) = ? In 4 years, [latex]\begin{aligned} \%U &=\frac{\Delta h}{\Delta H}\times 100 \\ &= \frac{10}{40}\times 100=25\%\\ T_v&=C_v\frac{t}{d^2}\;\;\;\because \%U \lt 60\% \\ T_v&=\frac{\pi}{4}U^2 \\ \frac{\pi}{4}\left ( \frac{25}{100} \right )^2&=\frac{C_v}{d^2} \times 4 \; years...(1) \end{aligned}[/latex] In 9 years [latex]\begin{aligned} T_v&=C_v\frac{t}{d^2}\\ &=\frac{\pi }{4} \times\frac{(0.25)^2}{4}\times 9 \; \text{years}\\ &=0.11044\\ \because \; (T_v)_{60}&=0.283 \\ \therefore \;\%U &\lt 60\%\\ \therefore \;T_v&=0.11044=\frac{\pi}{4}U^2\\ \%U&=0.3749=37.499\%\\ \%U&=\frac{\Delta h}{\Delta H} \times 100\\ &=\frac{\Delta h}{40mm}\times 100=37.499\\ \Delta h&=14.99mm=15mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 111 An anisotropic soil deposit has coefficient of permeability in vertical and horizontal directions as [latex]k_z \; and \; k_x[/latex], respectively. For constructing a flow net, the horizontal dimension of the problem's geometry is transformed by a multiplying factor of
solution: [latex]X=X_T\sqrt{\frac{k_x}{k_z}}[/latex] Transformed horizontal dimension, [latex]X_T=X\sqrt{\frac{k_z}{k_x}}[/latex]

question: Question 112 The notation "SC" as per Indian Standard Soil Classification System refers to
solution: SC[latex]\rightarrow[/latex]Clayey sand

question: Question 113 An earthen dam of height H is made of cohesive soil whose cohesion and unit weight are c and [latex]\gamma[/latex], respectively. If the factor of safety against cohesionis [latex]F_c[/latex], the Taylor's stability number ([latex]S_n[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]S_n=\frac{c}{\gamma H_c}=\frac{c}{\gamma F_cH} \;\;\;\;\left \{ \because \; F_c=\frac{H_c}{H} \right \}[/latex]

question: Question 114 If the fineness modulus of a sample of fine aggregates is 4.3, the mean size of the particles in the sample is between
solution: F.M of mean size 2.36 = 5 F.M of mean size 1.18 = 4 Hence for F.M of 4.3, the mean size of aggregate will be between 1.18 mm and 2.36 mm.

question: Question 115 A square footing of 4 m side is placed at 1 m depth in a sand deposit. The dry unit weight ([latex]\gamma[/latex]) of sand is 15 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. This footing has an ultimate bearing capacity of 600 kPa. Consider the depth factors: [latex]d_q=d_\gamma =1.0[/latex] and the bearing capacity factor: [latex]N_\gamma =18.75[/latex]. This footing is placed at a depth of 2m in the same soil deposit. For a factor of safety of 3.0 as per Terzaghi's theory, the safe bearing capacity (in kPa) of this footing would be _______
solution: As per Terzaghi's theory, the ultimate bearing capacity for a square footing considering depth factors: [latex]d_q=d_\gamma =1[/latex] is as follows: [latex]\begin{aligned} q_u&=1.3CN_C+\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ &\text{For sand,} \\ C&=0 \\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ \text{Given:} \\ \gamma &=15kN/m^3 \\ B&=4m \\ N_\gamma &= 18.75\\ &\text{Initial condition: } \\ D_f&= 1m\\ q_u&=600kPa\\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ 600&=15 \times 1 \times N_q +0.4 \times 15 \times 4 \times 18.75\\ N_q&=10\\ \text{If}\;\; D_f&=2m, \;\; \text{then,}\\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ &=15 \times 2 \times 10 +0.4 \times 15 \times 4 \times 18.75\\ &=750kN/m^2\\ &\text{Net ultimate BC of soil, }\\ q_{nu}&=q_u-\gamma D_f\\ &=750-15 \times 2=720kN/m^2\\ &\text{The gross safe BC or safe BC, }\\ q_s&=\frac{q_{nu}}{F}+\gamma D_f\\ &=\frac{720}{3}+15 \times 2\\ &=270kPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 A granular soil has a saturated unit weight of 20[latex]kN/m^3[/latex] and an effective angle of shearing resistance of 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The unit weight of water is 9.81 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. A slope is to be made on this soil deposit in which the seepage occurs parallel to the slope up to the free surface. Under this seepage condition for a factor of safety of 1.5, the safe slope angle (in degree, round off to 1 decimal place) would be _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _{sat}&=20kN/m^3\\ \gamma _w&=9.81kN/m^3\\ \therefore \; \gamma '&=\gamma _{sat}-\gamma _w=10.19kN/m^3\\ \therefore \; \phi '&=30^{\circ},\; F=1.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] For infnite slope, the F.O. safety for seepage parallel to the slope in a granular soil (C = 0) is given below [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\frac{\gamma '}{\gamma _{sat}}\frac{\tan \phi '}{\tan i}\\ 1.5&=\frac{10.19}{20}\frac{\tan 30}{\tan i}\\ i&=11.095 \; \text{say}\; 11.1^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 A reinforced concrete circular pile of 12 m length and 0.6 m diameter is embedded in stiff clay which has an undrained unit cohesion of 110 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex]. The adhesion factor is 0.5. The Net Ultimate Pullout (uplift) Load for the pile (in kN, round off to 1 decimal place) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Net Ultimate pullout} \\ &=\alpha CA_s =0.5 \times 110(\pi dL) \\ &=0.5 \times 110(\pi \times 0.6 \times 12)\\&=1244.1kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 118 A box measuring 50 cmx50cmx50cm is filled to the top with dry coarse aggregate of mass 187.5 kg. The water absorption and specific gravity of the aggregate are 0.5% and 2.5, respectively. The maximum quantity of water (in kg, round off to 2 decimal places) required to fill the box completely is_______
solution: Total volume of Box [latex]=0.5 \times 0.5\times 0.5=0.125m^3[/latex] wt of aggregates = 187.5 kg sp. gravity = 2.5 Unit weight [latex]=2.5 \times 9.81=24.525kN/m^3[/latex] wt of water absorbed [latex]=\frac{0.5}{100}\times 187.5=0.9375kg[/latex] vol of aggregate [latex]=\frac{187.5 \times 9.81}{1000 \times 24.525}=0.075m^3[/latex] volume of voids [latex]=0.125-0.075=0.05m^3[/latex] wt of water in voids [latex]=0.05 \times 1000=50kg[/latex] wt of water required to fill the box [latex]= 50 + 0.9375 = 50.94 kg[/latex]

question: Question 119 A survey line was measured to be 285.5 m with a tape having a nominal length of 30 m. On checking, the true length of the tape was found to be 0.05 m too short. If the line lay on a slope of 1 in 10, the reduced length (horizontal length) of the line for plotting of survey work would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L&=30m, \; L'=30-0.05=29.95m\\ \therefore \;\;& \; \text{Correct Length}\\ l&=l' \times \frac{l'}{L}\\ &=285.5 \times \frac{29.95}{30}=285.024m\\ D&=l \cos \theta \\ \cos \theta &=\frac{10}{\sqrt{10^2+1^2}}=0.995\\ \therefore \;D \;&\; =\text{ correct Horizontal length }\\ &=l\cos \theta \\ &=285.024 \times 0.9950\\ &=283.6m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 For the following statements: P: The lateral stress in the soil while being tested in an oedometer is always at-rest. Q: For a perfectly rigid strip footing at deeper depths in a sand deposit, the vertical normal contact stress at the footing edge is greater than that at its centre. R: The corrections for overburden pressure and dilatancy are not applied to measured SPT-N values in case of clay deposits. The correct combination of the statements is
solution:
P: True In the Oedometer test, stress is applied to the soil specimen along the vertical axis, while strain in the horizontal
direction is prevented by the confining ring (a condition of zero lateral strain). Thus it simulates at-rest condition. Q: True For a perfectly rigid footing resting on surface of sand deposit, the contact pressure distribution is zero
at the edges and maximum at centre. However, for a very deep rigid footing on sand, the contact pressure
distribution may tend to become like that of rigid footing on clayey soil, with edge contact stress greater than at
its centre. R: True For cohesive soil, there is no need for overburden pressure correction (Peck et al 1974). For cohesionless soil at
first overburden pressure correction is made, then if it is fine sand or silt under water table with N-value [latex]\gt[/latex] 15,
dilatancy correction is made.

question: Question 121 A concentrated load of 500 kN is applied on an elastic half space. The ratio of the increase in vertical normal stress at depths of 2m and 4m along the point of the loading, as per Boussinesq's theory, would be ___
solution: As per Boussinesq's equation, The vertical stress below the ground level at a depth, Z, vertically below the load, [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _Z&=\frac{3}{2\pi}\frac{Q}{Z^2}\\ \sigma _Z &\propto \frac{1}{Z^2}\\ \therefore \;\; \frac{\sigma _{Z_1}}{\sigma _{Z_2}}&=\left [ \frac{Z_2}{Z_1} \right ]^2\\ &=\left [ \frac{4}{2} \right ]^2=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 A soil has specific gravity of its solids equal to 2.65. The mass density of water is 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]. Considering zero air voids and 10% moisture content of the soil sample, the dry density (in [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], round off to 1 decimal place) would be _______
solution: [latex]G_s=2.65,[/latex] [latex] \gamma _w=1000kg/m^3[/latex] Degree of saturation, S = 100% (Zero air voids) w = 10% The dry density corresponding to zero air voids or 100% saturation, [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _d&= \frac{\gamma _wG_s}{1+wG_s}\\ &= \frac{1000\times 2.65}{1+0.1 \times 2.65}\\ &= 2094.9kg/m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 In a soil specimen, the total stress, effective stress, hydraulic gradient and critical hydraulic gradient are [latex]\sigma ,\sigma ',i, \; and \; i_c[/latex], respectively. For initiation of quicksand condition, which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Quick sand condition occurs if [latex]\sigma '=0[/latex] and [latex]i=i_c[/latex]

question: Question 124 A retaining wall of height H with smooth vertical backface supports a backfill inclined at an angle [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal. The backfill consists of cohesionless soil having angle of internal friction [latex]\phi[/latex]. If the active lateral thrust acting on the wall is [latex]P_a[/latex], which one of the following statements is TRUE?

options.A: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/2 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal
options.B: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/2 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\phi[/latex] with the horizontal
options.C: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/3 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal
options.D: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/3 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\phi[/latex] with the horizontal

question: Question 125 A group of nine piles in a 3 x 3 square pattern is embedded in a soil strata comprising dense sand underlying recently filled clay layer, as shown in the figure. The perimeter of an individual pile is 126 cm. The size of pile group is 240 cm x 240 cm. The recently filled clay has undrained shear strength of 15 kPa and unit weight of [latex]16 kN/m^{3}[/latex] The negative frictional load (in kN, up to two decimal places) acting on the pile group is______
solution: [latex]3 \times 3 [/latex] pile group Negative skin friction for group. [latex] =\alpha \bar{c}(4 B L)+ [/latex] weight of soil in negative zone. [latex] \begin{aligned} =& \alpha \bar{c}(4 B L)+\gamma(\text { Area } \times \text { length }] \\ =& 1 \times 15[4 \times 2.4 \times 2]+16\left[2.4^{2} \times 2\right] \\ &=472.32 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Negative skin friction in individual action. [latex] \begin{array}{l} =n[\alpha \bar{c} \text { (perimeter } \times l] \\ =9[0.5 \times 15 \times 1.26 \times 2] \\ \text { [Assume } \alpha=0.5] \\ =170.1 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] Negative skin friction is maximum of above (two) [latex] Q_{n t}=472.32 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 126 The total horizontal and vertical stresses at a point X in a saturated sandy medium are 170 kPa and 300 kPa, respectively. The static pore-water pressure is 30 kPa. At failure, the excess pore-water pressure is measured to be 94.50 kPa, and the shear stresses on the vertical and horizontal planes passing through the point X are zero. Effective cohesion is 0 kPa and effective angle of internal friction is [latex]36^{\circ}[/latex]. The shear strength (in kPa, up to two decimal places) at point X is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \because\quad \sigma_{n} &=\frac{300+170}{2}+\frac{300-170}{2} \cos 2 \alpha \\ \alpha &=45^{\circ}+\frac{36^{\circ}}{2}=63^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \sigma_{n} &=196.79 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \sigma_{n}^{\prime} &=\sigma_{\mathrm{n}}-u=196.79-(30+94.5) \\ \sigma_{n}^{\prime} &=72.29 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \tau &=c+\sigma_{\mathrm{n}}^{\prime} \tan \phi \\ &=72.29 \text { tan } 36=52.52 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 The compression curve (void ratio, e vs. effective stress, [latex]{\sigma_{v}}'[/latex] ) for a certain clayey soil is a straight line in a semi-logarithmic plot and it passes through the points [latex](e = 1.2; {\sigma_{v}}' = 50 kPa)[/latex] and [latex](e = 0.6; {\sigma_{v}}' = 800 kPa).[/latex] The compression index (up to two decimal places) of the soil is ______
solution: Compression Index [latex] C_{c}=\frac{\Delta e}{\log \left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{1}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right)}=\frac{1.2-0.6}{\log \left(\frac{800}{50}\right)}[/latex] [latex] C_{c}=\frac{0.6}{\log (16)}=\frac{0.6}{1.204}=0.4982[/latex]

question: Question 128 Three soil specimens (Soil 1, Soil 2 and Soil 3), each 150 mm long and 100 mm diameter, are placed in series in a constant head flow set-up as shown in the figure. Suitable screens are provided at the boundaries of the specimens to keep them intact. The values of coefficient of permeability of Soil 1, Soil 2 and Soil 3 are 0.01, 0.003 and 0.03 cm/s, respectively. The value of h in the set-up is
solution: In normal to bedding plane flow (series arrangement), Discharge will be same and Head loss and Hydraulic gradient will be different [latex] \begin{aligned} q &=K_{1} i_{1} A=K_{2} i_{2} A \\ &=K_{3} i_{3} A=K_{\mathrm{avg}} \cdot\left(\frac{H_{L}}{L}\right) A \\ K_{\mathrm{avg}_{1}} &=\frac{\Sigma Z_{i}}{\Sigma \frac{Z_{i}}{K_{i}}}=\frac{150+150+150}{\frac{150}{0.01}+\frac{150}{0.003}+\frac{150}{0.03}} \\ &=0.0064\\ \text{Total head loss}\\ &=H_{L}=560 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore K_{3} \cdot \frac{h}{150} \times A &=K_{a v g} \cdot \frac{560}{(150+150+150)} A \\ 0.03 \cdot\left(\frac{h}{150}\right) &=0.0064\left(\frac{560}{450}\right) \\ h &=40 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 A 3 m high vertical earth retaining wall retains a dry granular backfill with angle of internal friction of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] and unit weight of 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex]. If the wall is prevented from yielding (no movement), the total horizontal thrust (in kN per unit length) on the wall is
solution: Soil is dry sand [latex] \therefore K_{0}=1-\sin \phi=1-\sin 30^{\circ}=0.5 [/latex] Total horizontal thrust [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{0} &=\frac{1}{2} K_{0} \gamma H \cdot H=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times 20 \times 3^{2} \\ &=45 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 The clay mineral, whose structural units are held together by potassium bond is
solution: Kaolinite [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Hydrogen bond Illite [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] lonic Bond/Potassium Bond Montmorillonite [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Water Bond

question: Question 131 Which one of the following statements is NOT correct?
solution: Boussinesq's assumed soil as isotropic hence not applicable for stratified soil.

options.A: When the water content of soil lies between its liquid limit and plastic limit, the soil is said to be in plastic state.
options.B: Boussinesq's theory is used for the analysis of stratified soil.
options.C: The inclination of stable slope in cohesive soil can be greater than its angle of internal friction.
options.D: For saturated dense fine sand, after applying overburden correction, if the Standard Penetration Test value exceeds 15, dilatancy correction is to be applied.

question: Question 132 The contact pressure and settlement distribution for a footing are shown in the figure. The figure corresponds to a
solution: Rigid footing on granlar soil.

question: Question 133 A flownet below a dam consists of 24 equipotential drops and 7 flow channels. The difference between the upstream and downstream water levels is 6 m. The length of the flow line adjacent to the toe of the dam at exit is 1 m. The specific gravity and void ratio of the soil below the dam are 2.70 and 0.70, respectively. The factor of safety against piping is
solution: [latex]N_{f}=7 \quad N_{d}=24 \quad H=6 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Critical Hydraulic Gradient, [latex] i_{c}=\frac{G-1}{1+e}=\frac{2.7-1}{1+0.7}=1[/latex] Exit Gradient [latex](i_{\text{exit}})[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\Delta h}{l}=\frac{\left(\frac{H}{N_{d}}\right)}{l}=\frac{\left(\frac{6}{24}\right)}{1 m}=\frac{1}{4} \\ \text { F.O.S. } &=\frac{i_{c}}{i_{\text {exit }}}=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 A rigid smooth retaining wall of height 7 m with vertical backface retains saturated clay as backfill. The saturated unit weight and undrained cohesion of the backfill are 17.2 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and 20 kPa, respectively. The difference in the active lateral forces on the wall (in kN per meter length of wall, up to two decimal places), before and after the occurrence of tension cracks is ______

Question 135 The void ratio of a soil is 0.55 at an effective normal stress of 140 kPa. The compression index of the soil is 0.25. In order to reduce the void ratio to 0.4, an increase in the magnitude of effective normal stress (in kPa, up to one decimal place) should be ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta H &=\frac{H_{0} \Delta e}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{H_{0} C_{c}}{1+e_{0}} \log \left(\frac{\sigma_{0}+\Delta \sigma}{\sigma_{0}}\right) \\ \Delta H &=H_{0}\left(\frac{0.55-0.40}{1+0.50}\right)=\frac{H_{0} \times 0.25}{1+0.50} \log \left(\frac{140+\Delta \sigma}{140}\right) \\ \frac{0.15}{0.25} &=\frac{3}{5}=\log \left(\frac{140+\Delta \sigma}{140}\right) \\ \Delta \sigma &=417.35 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 A conventional drained triaxial compression test was conducted on a normally consolidated clay sample under an effective confining pressure of 200 kPa. The deviator stress at failure was found to be 400 kPa. An identical specimen of the same clay sample is isotropically consolidated to a confining pressure of 200 kPa and subjected to standard undrained triaxial compression test. If the deviator stress at failure is 150 kPa, the pore pressure developed (in kPa, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: [latex]I^{st}[/latex] Specimen : Drained condition [latex] \bar{\sigma}_{3}=200 \mathrm{kPa}: \sigma_{\mathrm{d}}=400 \mathrm{kPa}: \bar{\sigma}_{1}=600 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] [latex] II^{nd} [/latex]Specimen : Undrained condition [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{3} &=200 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \sigma_{\mathrm{d}} &=150 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \sigma_{1} &=\sigma_{3}+\sigma_{\mathrm{d}}=350 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let pore pressure developed is u [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \bar{\sigma}_{3}&=(200-u)\\ \bar{\sigma}_{1}&=(350-u)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] From stress relationship [latex] \bar{\sigma}_{1}=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+2 c\tan\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)[/latex] For clay under drained condition c=0 [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \bar{\sigma}_{1} &=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \\ 600 &=200 \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \\ \phi &=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] For second specimen, [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{1}&=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\\ (350-u) &=(200-u) \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{30^{\circ}}{2}\right) \\ u &=125 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 At a construction site, a contractor plans to make an excavation as shown in the figure. The water level in the adjacent river is at an elevation of +20.0 m. Unit weight of water is 10 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The factor of safety (up to two decimal places) against sand boiling for the proposed excavation is ______
solution: [latex]\mathrm{FOS}=\frac{10 \times \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}}{20 \times \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}}=\frac{10 \times 20}{20 \times 10}=1[/latex]

question: Question 138 A 0.5 m x 0.5 m square concrete pile is to be driven in a homogeneous clayey soil having undrained shear strength, [latex]c_{u}[/latex]= 50 kPa and unit weight, [latex]\gamma = 18.0 kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The design capacity of the pile is 500 kN. The adhesion factor [latex]\alpha[/latex] is given as 0.75. The length of the pile required for the above design load with a factor of safety of 2.0 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{u}=& 50 \mathrm{kPa}, \gamma=18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \mathrm{FOS}=2 \\ Q_{\text {up}}=& 9 \mathrm{C} \times B^{2}+\alpha \bar{C}(4 \mathrm{BL})=1000 \mathrm{kN} \\ 1000=& 9 \times 50 \times 0.5 \times 0.5+0.75 \\ & \times 50(4 \times 0.5 \mathrm{L}) \\ L=& 11.83 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 A core cutter of 130 mm height has inner and outer diameters of 100 mm and 106 mm, respectively. The area ratio of the core cutter (in %, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Area ratio } &=\frac{A_{\text {outer }}-A_{\text {inne }} r}{A_{\text {inner }}} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} D_{0}^{2}-\frac{\pi}{4} D_{i}^{2}}{\frac{\pi}{4} D_{i}^{2}} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}(106)^{2}-\frac{\pi}{4}(100)^{2}}{\frac{\pi}{4}(100)^{2}} \times 100 \\ &=12.36 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 140 In a shrinkage limit test, the volume and mass of a dry soil pat are found to be 50 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] and 88 g, respectively. The specific gravity of the soil solids is 2.71 and the density of water is 1 g/cc. The shrinkage limit (in %, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: Dry soil mass =88 gm Volume of dry soil = 50 cc Dry density of soil mass, [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho_{d}&=\frac{M_{d}}{V_{d}}=\frac{88}{50} \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{cc}\\ \therefore \text{ Shrinkage limit, } w_{s}&=\frac{1}{R}-\frac{1}{G}=\frac{1}{\left(\rho_{d} / \rho_{w}\right)}-\frac{1}{G} \\ w_{s} &=\frac{\rho_{w}}{\rho_{d}}-\frac{1}{G} \\ &=\frac{1}{1.76}-\frac{1}{2.71}=0.1990 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 141 The width of a square footing and the diameter of a circular footing are equal. If both the footings are placed on the surface of sandy soil, the ratio of the ultimate bearing capacity of circular footing to that of square footing will be
solution: Footing placed on surface [latex] \therefore \quad D_{f}=0 [/latex] For square footing, [latex] q_{u}=C N_{c}+\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.4 B \gamma N_{\gamma}[/latex] For circular footing, [latex] q_{u}=C N_{c}+\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.3 B \gamma N_{\gamma}[/latex] For sandy soil, [latex] \begin{aligned} C&=0\\ \text{Ratio }\frac{\left(q_{u}\right)_{\text {circular}}}{\left(q_{u}\right)_{\text {square}}}&=\frac{3}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 142 The percent reduction in the bearing capacity of a strip footing resting on sand under flooding condition (water level at the base of the footing) when compared to the situation where the water level is at a depth much greater than the width of footing, is approximately
solution:
For strip footing on sand (c=0) [latex]
q_{u}=\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.5 \mathrm{B} \gamma N_{\gamma}[/latex] In flooding condition water level rises to base 
of footing hence IIIrd term unit weight of soil 
will change and IInd term unit weight will be unaffected. [latex]
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & q_{u}=\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.5 B \gamma N_{\gamma} \\
\because & \gamma \simeq \frac{1}{2} \gamma_{s a t}
\end{array}[/latex] Hence third term reduced and second term will 
be same thereby percentage reduction will not be 50%. According to option approach answer should be 25% Note: If water table rises to ground level then 
both [latex]\gamma[/latex] will reduce to [latex]\gamma[/latex].  Hence, percentage 
reduction would be approximately 50%.

question: Question 143 Consider a square-shaped area ABCD on the ground with its Centre at M as shown in the figure. Four concentrated vertical load of P=5000 kN are applied on this area, at each corner. The vertical stress increment (in kPa, up to one decimal place) due to these loads according to the Boussinesq's equation, at a point 5 m right below M, is_____
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} P=5000 \mathrm{kN} \\ r=\sqrt{2^{2}+2^{2}}=2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] According to Boussinesq's [latex] \sigma_{z}=k \frac{Q}{z^{2}}=\frac{3}{2 \pi}\left(\frac{1}{1+\frac{r^{2}}{z^{2}}}\right)^{5 / 2} \frac{Q}{z^{2}}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Vertical stress at 5m below point M [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{z} &=4 \times \frac{3}{2 \pi} \times\left\{\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{5}\right)^{2}}\right\}^{5/2} \quad \times \frac{5000}{5^{2}} \\ &=190.8 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 144 For the construction of a highway. A cut is to be made as shown in the figure. The soil exhibits [latex]c'=20kPa,\; \; \phi '=18^{\circ}[/latex] and the undrained shear strength = 80 kPa. The unit weight of water is 9.81[latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The unit weights of the soil above and below the ground water table are 18 and 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex], respectively. If the shear stress at Point A is 50 kPa, the factors of safety against the shear failure at this point, considering the undrained and drained conditions, respectively, would be
solution: Drained parameters: [latex] c^{\prime}=20 \mathrm{kPa}, \phi^{\prime}=18^{\circ}[/latex] Undrained shear strength. [latex] S=80 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Normal stress at point A. [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{n} &=\sigma_{n}-u=2 \times \gamma_{b}+4 \gamma \\ \bar{\sigma}_{n} &=2 \times 18+4(20-981) \\ &=76.76 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Shear stress at point A=50kPa FOS under undrained condition [latex] =\frac{\text { Shear strength }}{\text { Sthear stress }}=\frac{80}{50}=1.6[/latex] FOS in drained condition [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{c+\bar{\sigma}_{n} \tan \phi^{\prime}}{\tau} \\ &=\frac{20+76.76 \tan 18^{\circ}}{50}=0.9788 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 145 Following are the statements related to the stress paths in a triaxial testing of soils: P. If [latex]\sigma _{1}=\sigma _{3}[/latex] , the stress point lies at the origin of the p-q plot. Q. If, [latex]\sigma _{1}=\sigma _{3}[/latex] the stress point lies on the p-axis of the p-q plot. R. If [latex]\sigma _{1} \gt \sigma _{3}[/latex] , both the stress points p and q are positive. For the above statements, the correct combination is

options.A: P - False; Q - True; R - True
options.B: P - False; Q - True; R - True
options.C: P - False; Q - True; R - False
options.D: P - True; Q - False; R - False

question: Question 146 Two identical concrete piles having the plan dimensions 50 cm x 50 cm are driven into a homogeneous sandy layer as shown in the figures. Consider the bearing capacity factor [latex]N_{q}[/latex], for [latex]\phi =30^{\circ}[/latex] as 24 If [latex]Q_{P1}[/latex] and [latex]Q_{P2}[/latex] represent the ultimate point bearing resistance of the piles under dry and submerged conditions, respectively, which one of the following statements is correct?
solution:
The point bearing resistance of piles in sandy soils [latex]Q_P=A_b\ \cdot \sigma '_v \cdot N_q[/latex] As the area at base [latex](A_b)[/latex] and [latex]N_q[/latex] are same for both the piles given, [latex]Q_P \propto \sigma '_v[/latex] For dry sand condition, [latex]\sigma '_v=\sigma _v=20 \times \gamma[/latex] For submerged condition, [latex]\sigma '_v=20 \times \gamma '[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Since, } \gamma '&= \frac{1}{2} \gamma \\ \therefore \;\; QP_2&\approx \frac{1}{2} QP_1\\ QP_1& \approx QP_2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]QP_1 \gt QP_2[/latex]
 by about 100%.

question: Question 147 A sheet pile has an embedment depth of 12 m in a homogeneous soil stratum. The coefficient of permeability of soil is [latex]10^{-6}\, m/s[/latex]. Difference in the water levels between the two sides of the sheet pile is 4 m. The flow net is constructed with five number of flow lines and eleven number of equipotential lines. The quantity of seepage (in [latex]\frac{cm^{3}}{s}[/latex] per m, up to one decimal place) under the sheet pile is________
solution: [latex]N_{f}=[/latex] No. of flow lines [latex]-1=5-1=4 [/latex] [latex] N_{d}=[/latex] No. of equipotential lines [latex]-1=11-1=10 [/latex] [latex] H=4 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Discharge, [latex] q=\frac{K H N_{f}}{N_{d}}=10^{-6} \times 4 \times \frac{4}{10}=16 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] q=16 \times 10^{-7} \times 10^{6} \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] q=1.6 \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] per meter length of dam

question: Question 148 The plate load test was conducted on clayey strata by using a plate of 0.3mx0.3 m dimensions, and the ultimate load per unit area for the plate was found to be 180 kPa. The ultimate bearing capacity (in kPa) of a 2 m wide square footing would be
solution:
Plate load test was conducted on a clay strata. Bearing capacity for the plate is 180 kPa. Ultimate bearing capacity in case of clay is 
independent of width of footing, hence 
ultimate bearing capacity for footing will be 180kPa.

question: Question 149 Consider a rigid retaining wall with partially submerged cohesionless backfill with a surcharge. Which one of the following diagrams closely represents the Rankine's active earth pressure distribution against this wall?

Question 150 Consider the following statements related to the pore pressure parameters, A and B: P. A always lies between 0 and 1.0 Q. A can be less than 0 or greater than 1.0 R. B always lies between 0 and 1.0 S. B can be less than 0 or greater than 1.0 For these statements, which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Pore pressure parameter B lies in between 0 to 1 and pore pressure parameter A may be as low as -0.5 and may be as high as 3.

question: Question 151 Let G be the specific gravity of soil solids, w the water content in the soil sample,[latex]\gamma _{w}[/latex] the unit weight of water, and [latex]\gamma _{d}[/latex] the dry unit weight of the soil. The equation for the zero air voids line in a compaction test plot is
solution: Percentage air void line is relation between dry unit weight and water content at constant air void. Hence equation of zero air void line is [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma_{\mathrm{d}}&=\left(1-n_{\mathrm{a}}\right) \frac{G \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}}{1+w G} &\left(n_{\mathrm{a}}=0\right) \\ \gamma_{\mathrm{d}}&=\frac{G \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}}{1+w G} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 152 A consolidated undrained [latex]\bar{CU}[/latex] triaxial compression test is conducted on a normally consolidated clay at a confining pressure of 100 kPa. The deviator stress at failure is 80 kPa, and the pore-water pressure measured at failure is 50 kPa. The effective angle of internalfriction (in degrees, up to one decimal place) of the soil is _________
solution: CU test is conducted. [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{3}= 100 &\mathrm{kPa}, \sigma_{a}=80 \mathrm{kPa}, u=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \sigma_{1}&=\sigma_{3}+\sigma_{d} =100+80=180 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \bar{\sigma}_{1}&=\sigma_{1}-u= 180-50=130 \mathrm{kPa}\\ \bar{\sigma}_{3}&=\sigma_{3}-u=100-50=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \bar{\sigma}_{1}&=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right)+2 C^{\prime} \tan \left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right) \\ \text{Assume }\quad C^{\prime}&=0 \\ \bar{\sigma}_{1}&=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right) \\ 130&=50 \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right) \\ \phi^{\prime}&=26.4^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 153 The infinite sand slope shown in the figure is on theverge of sliding failure. The ground water tablecoincides with the ground surface. Unit weight of water [latex]\gamma _{w}=9.81\; kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The value of the effective angle of internal friction (indegrees, up to one decimal place) of the sand is________
solution: Infinite sand slope: GWT coincides with the ground surface, therefore [latex] F.O.S. =\frac{\gamma^{\prime}}{\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}} \times \frac{\tan \phi^{\prime}}{\tan \beta}[/latex] As slope is on the verge of sliding failure hence, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{F} \mathrm{O} . \mathrm{S}=\frac{\gamma^{\prime} \tan \phi^{\prime}}{\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}} \tan \beta}=1\\ (21-9.81) \tan \phi^{\prime}=21 \tan 20^{\circ} \\ \phi=34.3^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 154 It is proposed to drive H-piles up to a depth of 7 m at a construction site. The average surfacearea of the H-pile is 3 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] per meter length. The soil at the site is homogeneous sand, havingan effective friction angle of 32[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The ground water table (GWT) is at a depth of 2 m below the ground surface. The unit weights of the soil above and below the GWT are 16 [latex] kN/m^{3}[/latex] and 19 [latex] kN/m^{3}[/latex] respectively. Assume the earth pressure coefficient, K= 1.0, and the angle of wall friction [latex]\delta =23^{\circ}[/latex], The total axial frictional resistance (in kN, up to one decimal place) mobilized on the pile against the driving is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{s t} &=\frac{1}{2} k \gamma L_{1} \tan \delta A_{s_{1}}+\frac{1}{2} K\left[\gamma L_{1}+\gamma^{\prime} L_{2}\right] \tan \delta A_{s_{2}} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 16 \times 2 \tan 23^{\circ}(3 \times 2) \\ &+\frac{1}{2} \times 1[16 \times 2+77.95] \times \tan 23^{\circ}(5 \times 3) \\ &=390.8 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 155 The laboratory test on a soil sample yields the following results: natural moisture content = 18%, liquid limit = 60%, plastic limit = 25%, percentage of clay sized fraction = 25%. The liquidity index and activity (as per the expression proposed by skempton) of the soil, respectively, are
solution: Given data: [latex]w_{n}=18 \%, w_{L}=60 \%, w_{p}=25 \% [/latex] % of clay size particle =25 % Liquidity index [latex] I_{L}=\frac{w_{n}-w_{p}}{w_{L}-w_{p}}=\frac{0.18-0.25}{0.60-0.25}=-0.2 [/latex] Activity [latex]=\frac{I_{p}}{\% C}=\frac{w_{L}-w_{p}}{\% C}=\frac{60-25}{25}=1.4[/latex]

question: Question 156 A 3 m thick clay layer is subjected to an initial uniform pore pressure of 145 kPa as shown in the figure. For the given ground conditions, the time (in days, rounded to the nearest integer) required for 90% consolidation would be ____________
solution: As per Terzaghi's 1-D consolidation theory [latex] T_{v}=C_{v} \frac{t}{d^{2}}[/latex] One way drainage condition d=3m For 90% consolidation [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(T_{v}\right)_{90} &=C_{v} \cdot \frac{t_{90}}{d^{2}} \\ 0.85 &=3 \times 10^{-6} \times \frac{t_{90}}{(3)^{2}} \\ t_{90} &=\frac{0.85 \times 9}{3 \times 10^{-6}} \mathrm{min} \\ t_{90} &=1770.83 \simeq 1771 \text { days } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 A uniformly distributed line load of 500 kN/m is acting on the ground surface. Based on Boussinesq's theory, the ratio of vertical stress at a depth 2 m to that at 4 m, right below the line of loading, is
solution: [latex]q^{\prime}=500 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex]x=0[/latex] (Just below the line load) [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{z} &=\frac{2 q^{\prime}}{\pi z}\left(\frac{1}{1+\frac{x^{2}}{z^{2}}}\right)^{2}=\frac{2 q^{\prime}}{\pi z} \\ \text { Ratio } &=\frac{\left(\sigma_{z}\right)_{a t, 2 m}}{\left(\sigma_{z}\right)_{a t, 4 m}}=\frac{\frac{2 q^{\prime}}{\pi \times 2}}{\frac{2 q^{\prime}}{\pi \times 4}}=\frac{4}{2}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 A strip footing is resting on the ground surface of a pure clay bed having an undrainedcohesion [latex]C_{u}[/latex]. The ultimate bearing capacity of the footing is equal to
solution: Footing is at surface Hence, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Hence},\quad D_{t}&=0 \\ q_{u}&=C N_{c}+\gamma D_{f} N_{q}+0.5 \mathrm{B} \gamma N_{\gamma} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad [/latex]For clay [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{Y} &=0, N_{q}=1 \\ \therefore \quad q_{U}&=C N_{c} \end{aligned}[/latex] As per Terzaghi [latex] N_{c}=5.7[/latex] and as per Meyerhoff and Prandtl. [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{c} &=5.14 \\ \therefore \quad q_{u} &=(\pi+2) C_{u} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 159 A soil sample is subjected to a hydrostatic pressure, [latex]\sigma[/latex]. The Mohr circle for any point in the soil sample would be
solution: Hydrostatic pressure acts equally in all directions.

options.A: a circle of radius  [latex]\sigma[/latex]   and center at the origin
options.B: a circle of radius [latex]\sigma[/latex]  and center at a distance [latex]\sigma[/latex] from the origin
options.C: a point at a distance [latex]\sigma[/latex]   from the origin
options.D: a circle of diameter [latex]\sigma[/latex]   and center at the origin

question: Question 160 Group I lists the type of gain or loss of strength in soils. Group II lists the property or process responsible for the loss or gain of strength in soils. The correct match between Group I and Group II is
solution:
Loss in strength of soil due to remoulding 
at same water content is termed as 
sensitivity. Over a period of time soil regain a part of 
its lost strength is termed as thixotropy. 
When seepage takes place in upward 
direction, seepage pressure acts in upward 
direction and effective stress is reduced 
consequently shear strength is reduced. In liquefaction, due to dynamic/cyclic loading 
in loose saturated sand, effective stress 
decreases and decrease in shear strength 
is recorded.

question: Question 161 A 4 m wide strip footing is founded at a depth of 1.5 m below the ground surface in a [latex]c-\phi[/latex] soil as shown in the figure. The water table is at a depth of 5.5 m below ground surface. The soil properties are: [latex]{c}'=35\: kN/m^{2},{\phi }'=28.63^{\circ}, [/latex] [latex]\gamma _{sat}=19\: kN/m^{3}, \; \gamma _{bulk}=17\:kN/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex] \gamma _{w}=9.81kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The values of bearing capacity factors for different [latex]{\phi }'[/latex] are given below. Using Terzaghi's bearing capacity equation and a factor of safety [latex]F_{s}=2.5[/latex], the net safe bearing capacity (expressed in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex] ) for local shear failure of the soil is ________.
solution: Local shear failure is occuring hence modified c and [latex]\phi[/latex] should be used [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{m} &=\frac{2}{3} c=\frac{2}{3} \times 35=23.33 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \tan \phi_{m} &=\frac{2}{3} \tan \phi=\frac{2}{3} \tan 28.63 \\ \phi_{m} &=20^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] for [latex]\quad \phi_{m}=20^{\circ}, N_{c}=17.7, N_{\mathrm{q}}=7.4, N_{\gamma}=5.0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Water table is at [latex] D_{t}+B=1.5+4=5.5 \mathrm{m} [/latex] hence no effect on bearing capacity [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] As per Terzaghi for strip footing [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{u} &=c N_{c}+8 D_{f} N_{q}+0.5 B \gamma N_{\gamma} \\ q_{u} &=\frac{2}{3} \times 35 \times 17.7+17+1.5 \times 7.4+0.5 \\ & \times 4 \times 17 \times 5 \\ q_{u} &=771.7 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ q_{\mathrm{nu}} &=q_{u}-\bar{\sigma}=q_{u}-\gamma D_{f}=771.7-17 \times 1.5 \\ q_{n} &=746.2 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net safe bearing capacity [latex] q_{n s}=\frac{q_{n u}}{F}=\frac{746.2}{2.5}=298.48 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 162 Water flows from P to Q through two soil samples, Soil 1 and Soil 2, having cross sectional area of 80[latex]cm^2[/latex] as shown in the figure. Over a period of 15 minutes, 200 ml of water was observed to pass through any cross section. The flow conditions can be assumed to be steady state. If the coefficient of permeability of Soil 1 is 0.02 mm/s, the coefficient of permeability of Soil 2 (expressed in mm/s) would be ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Discharge } &=\frac{200 \mathrm{ml}}{15 \mathrm{min}} \\ &=\frac{200 \mathrm{cm}^{3}}{15 \times 60 \mathrm{sec}}=\frac{200 \times 10^{3}}{900} \frac{\mathrm{mm}^{3}}{\mathrm{sec}} \end{aligned}[/latex] As per Darcy's Law, [latex] \begin{aligned} q &=k_{a v g} i A \\ k_{a v g} &=\frac{\Sigma z_{i}}{\Sigma \frac{z_{i}}{k_{i}}}\\ &(\because\text{ flow is normal to bedding plane})\\ k_{\text {avg }}&=\frac{150+150}{\frac{150}{0.02}+\frac{150}{k}}\\ i&=\frac{\text { Head difference }}{\text { length }}=\frac{600-300}{300}=1 \\ A&=80 \mathrm{cm}^{2}=80 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ q&=\left[\frac{150+150}{\frac{150}{0.02}+\frac{150}{k}}+\right] \times 1 \times 80 \times 10^{2} \\ &=\frac{200 \times 10^{3}}{900} \\ k&=0.045 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 163 OMC-SP and MDD-SP denote the optimum moisture content and maximum dry density obtained from standard Proctor compaction test, respectively. OMC-MP and MDD-MP denote the optimum moisture content and maximum dry density obtained from the modified Proctor compaction test, respectively. Which one of the following is correct?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{r} \mathrm{OMC}-\mathrm{SP} \gt \mathrm{OMC}-\mathrm{MP} \\ \mathrm{MDD}-\mathrm{SP} \lt \mathrm{MDD}-\mathrm{MP} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 164 The soil profile at a site consists of a 5 m thick sand layer underlain by a [latex]c-\phi[/latex] soil as shown in figure. The water table is found 1 m below the ground level. The entire soil mass is retained by a concrete retaining wall and is in the active state. The back of the wall is smooth and vertical. The total active earth pressure (expressed in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex] ) at point A as per Rankine's theory is _________.
solution: In [latex]\mathrm{c}-\phi[/latex] soil Earth pressure [latex] \begin{array}{l} p_{\mathrm{a}}=k_{\mathrm{a}} \sigma_{\mathrm{v}}-2 \mathrm{c} \sqrt{\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{a}}} \\ k_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{1-\sin \phi}{1+\sin \phi}=\frac{1-\sin 24}{1+\sin 24}=0.4217 \end{array}[/latex] Note: Below water table, water pressure will not be multiplied by [latex] k_{\mathrm{a}} [/latex] at point A [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sigma_{v}=1 \times \gamma_{b}+4 \gamma_{\text {sat }}+3 \gamma_{\text {sat }} \\ \sigma_{v}=1 \times \gamma_{b}+\left(4 \times \gamma^{\prime}+4 \times \gamma_{w}\right)+\left(3 \gamma^{\prime}+3 \gamma_{w}\right) \\ \sigma_{v}=\left(1 \times \gamma_{b}+4 \gamma^{\prime}+3 \gamma^{\prime}\right)+\left(4 \gamma_{w}+3 \gamma_{w}\right) \end{array}[/latex] Earth Pressure at 'A' [latex] \begin{array}{l} p_{\mathrm{a}}=k_{\mathrm{a}} \sigma_{v}-2 c \sqrt{k_{\mathrm{a}}} \\ =k_{a}\left[\gamma_{b}+4 \gamma^{\prime}+3 \gamma^{\prime}\right]+4 \gamma_{w}+3 \gamma_{w}-2 \times c^{\prime} \sqrt{k_{a}} \\ =0.4217[16.5+4(19-9.81)+3(18.5-9.81)] \\ +7 \times 9.81-2 \times 25 \times \sqrt{0.4217} \\ p_{\mathrm{a}}=69.65 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 165 The seepage occurring through an earthen dam is represented by a flow net comprising of 10 equipotential drops and 20 flow channels. The coefficient of permeability of the soil is 3 mm/min and the head loss is 5 m. The rate of seepage (expressed in [latex]cm^{3}/s[/latex] per m length of the dam) through the earthen dam is ___.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q&=\frac{KH.N_{f}}{N_{d}}\\ K&=\frac{3 \mathrm{mm}}{\mathrm{min}}=\frac{3 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}}{60} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ H&=5 \mathrm{m}, N_{\mathrm{f}}=20, \quad N_{\mathrm{d}}=10\\ q&=\frac{3 \times 10^{-3}}{60} \times 5 \times \frac{20}{10} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \text { per } \mathrm{m} \text { length of dam }\\ q&=\frac{3 \times 10^{-3} \times 5 \times 20}{60 \times 10} \times 10^{6} \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \text { per } \mathrm{m} \text { length of dam }\\ q&=500 \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \text { per } \mathrm{m} \text { length of } \mathrm{dam} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 166 The results of a consolidation test on an undisturbed soil, sampled at a depth of 10 m below the ground level are as follows: Saturated unit weight :[latex]16kN/m^{3}[/latex] Pre-consolidation pressure : 90kPa The water table was encountered at the ground level. Assuming the unit weight of water as [latex]10kN/m^{3}[/latex], the over-consolidation ratio of the soil is
solution: [latex]\mathrm{OCR}=\frac{\text { Maximum effective stress in past }}{\text { Maximum effective stress in present }} [/latex] Maximum effective stress in present [latex] \begin{aligned} =& 10 \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}-10 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \\ =& 10 \times 16-10 \times 10=60 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{OCR} &=\frac{90}{60}=1.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 167 The relationship between the specific gravity of sand (G) and the hydraulic gradient (i) to initiate quick condition in the sand layer having porosity of 30% is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} i_{c}=\frac{G-1}{1+e}=(G-1)(1-n) \quad \because \frac{1}{1+e}=1-n \\ i_{c}=(G-1)(1-0.3)=(G-1) \times 0.7 \\ G=\frac{i_{c}}{0.7}+1=1.43 i_{c}+1 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 168 A strip footing is resting on the surface of a purely clayey soil deposit. If the width of the footing is doubled, the ultimate bearing capacity of the soil
solution: In case of clay ultimate bearing capacity is independent of width of footing.

question: Question 169 Seepage is occurring through a porous media shown in the figure. The hydraulic conductivity values [latex]\left ( k_{1},\,k _{2},\,k_{3}\right )[/latex] are in m/day. The seepage discharge [latex]\left ( m^{3}/day\: per\: m \right )[/latex] through the porous media at section PQ is
solution: Flow is normal to bedding plane [latex] \therefore k_{\mathrm{avg}}=\frac{\Sigma z_{i}}{\Sigma \frac{z_{t}}{k_{i}}}=\frac{20+30+10}{\frac{20}{2}+\frac{30}{3}+\frac{10}{1}}=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} [/latex] Hydraulic gradient, [latex] i=\frac{\text { Head difference }}{\text { Length }}=\frac{15-10}{60}=\frac{5}{60} [/latex] Seepage discharge, [latex] =k_{\mathrm{avg}} i A=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} \times \frac{5}{60} \times 3 \mathrm{m} =\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 170 A drained triaxial compression test on a saturated clay yielded the effective shear strength parameters as [latex]{c}'=15\, kPa \: \, and \: {\phi }'=22^{\circ}.[/latex] Consolidated Undrained triaxial test on an identical sample of this clay at a cell pressure of 200 kPa developed a pore water pressure of 150kPa at failure. The deviator stress (expressed in kPa) at failure is _________ .
solution: Cell pressure, [latex] \sigma_{3}=200 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Pore water pressure. [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=150 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \therefore \bar{\sigma}_{3} &=\sigma_{3}-U=200-150=50 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Effective shear parameters [latex] \left(c^{\prime}=150 \mathrm{kPa}\text{ and } \phi^{\circ}=22^{\circ}\right) [/latex] is given [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \bar{\sigma}_{1} &=\bar{\sigma}_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\varphi^{\prime}}{2}\right)+2 c^{\prime} \tan \left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right) \\ \bar{\sigma}_{1} &=50+\tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{22}{2}\right)+2 \times 15 \tan \left(45+\frac{22}{2}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\bar{\sigma}_{1}=154.376 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Now [latex] \begin{array}{l} \vec{\sigma}_{1}=\bar{\sigma}_{3}+\sigma_{\sigma} \\ \sigma_{d}=\bar{\sigma}_{1}-\bar{\sigma}_{3}=154.376-50 \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\text{Deviator stress, }\sigma_{\sigma}=104.376 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]

question: Question 171 A seepage flow condition is shown in the figure.The saturated unit weight of the soil [latex]\gamma _{sat}=18kN/m^{3}[/latex]. Using unit weight of water, [latex]\gamma _{w}=9.81kN/m^{3}[/latex], the effective vertical stress (expressed in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex] ) on plane X-X is ________.
solution: Hydraulic gradient, [latex] \begin{aligned} i&=\frac{\text { Hydraulichead difference }}{\text { Length }}=\frac{H_{A}-H_{B}}{6} \\ i&=\frac{10-7}{6}=\frac{3}{6}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \text { Force }&=m_{w} \end{aligned}[/latex] Head loss at x-x [latex] =i \times 5=2.5 \gamma_{w}[/latex] Effective stress at x-x [latex] \begin{array}{l} =5 \gamma_{\text {sub }}+2.5 \gamma_{w} \\ =5 \times(18-9.81)+2.5 \times 9.81 \\ =65.475 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 172 An undisturbed soil sample was taken from the middle of a clay layer (i.e., 1.5 m below GL), as shown in figure. The water table was at the top of clay layer. Laboratory test results are as follows: Natural water content of clay : 25% Preconsolidation pressure of clay : 60 kPa Compression index of clay : 0.50 Recompression index of clay : 0.05 Specific gravity of clay : 2.70 Bulk unit weight of sand : 17 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] A compacted fill of 2.5 m height with unit weight of 20 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] is placed at the ground level Assuming unit weight of water as10 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], the ultimate consolidation settlement (expressed in
mm) of the clay layer is ____________
solution: Change in effective stress due to compacted [latex] \Delta \bar{\sigma}_{0}=2.5 \times 20=50 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] since pre-consolidation pressure is 60kPa, hence from 22.075 to 60 kPa Over consolidation stage [latex] \text { from60 } \mathrm{kPa}+\mathrm{O}(20.075+6 \mathrm{O}=72.075)[/latex] Normal consolidated stage Hence consolidation settlement [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta H &=\frac{H_{0} c_{t}}{1+e_{0}} \log \left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{1}}{\sigma_{0}}\right)+\frac{H_{0} c_{c}}{1+e_{0}} \log \left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{2}}{\sigma_{1}}\right) \\ \Delta H &=\frac{1 \times 0.05}{1+0.675} \log \left(\frac{60}{22.075}\right)+\frac{1 \times 0.50}{1+0.675} \log \left(\frac{72.075}{60}\right) \\ &=0.0367 \mathrm{m}=36.7 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 173 A homogeneous gravity retaining wall supporting a cohesionless backfill is shown in the figure. The lateral active earth pressure at the bottom of the wall is 40 kPa. The minimum weight of the wall (expressed in kN per m length) required to prevent it from overturning about its toe (Point P) is
solution:
W = weight of wall [latex]
 R_{v}=[/latex] Reaction from cohesion less backfill [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&=\frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times H \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times 6 \\
&=120 \mathrm{kN}
\end{aligned}[/latex] To prevent overturning about point P. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
M_{0} &\leq M_{R} \\
R_{v} \times \frac{H}{3} &\leq W \times 2 \\
120 \times \frac{6}{3} &\leq W \times 2\\
 \Rightarrow \quad W &\geq 120 \mathrm{kN} \\
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]
 \therefore [/latex] Minimum weight of wall [latex]=120kN [/latex]

question: Question 174 The porosity (n) and the degree of saturation (S) of a soil sample are 0.7 and 40%, respectively. In a 100 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] volume of the soil, the volume (expressed in [latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) of air is ________ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} n=0.7 .5 &=40 \%, V=100 \mathrm{m}^{3}, V_{a}=? \\ n &=\frac{V_{v}}{V} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.7 &=\frac{V_{v}}{100} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{v} &=70 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text { Now, } \quad S &=\frac{V_{W}}{V_{v}}=\frac{V_{v}-V_{a}}{V_{v}}=1-\frac{V_{a}}{V_{v}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.40&=1-\frac{V_{a}}{V_{v}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{a}}{V_{v}}&=0.60 \Rightarrow V_{a}=0.6 \times 70=42 \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 175 A vertical cut is to be made in a soil mass having cohesion c, angle of internal friction [latex]\phi[/latex], and unit weight [latex]\gamma[/latex]. Considering [latex]K_{a}[/latex] and [latex]K_{p}[/latex] as the coefficients of active and passive earth pressures, respectively, the maximum depth of unsupported excavation is
Question 176 A fine grained soil is found to be plastic in the water content range of 26-48%. As per Indian Standard Classification System, the soil is classified as
solution:
Soil is plastic in the range of 26-48% Hence plastic limit =26% and liquid limit =48% Because liquid limit is in the range of 35% to 
50%. Hence, intermediate compressible soil.

question: Question 177 In the consolidated undrained triaxial test on a saturated soil sample, the pore water pressure is zero

options.B: at the end of consolidation stage only
options.C: both at the end of consolidation and during shearing stages
options.D: under none of the above conditions

question: Question 178 A 6 m high retaining wall having a smooth vertical back face retains a layered horizontal backfill. Top 3 m thick layer of the backfill is sand having an angle of internal friction, [latex]\phi=30^{\circ}[/latex] while the bottom layer is 3 m thick clay with cohesion, c = 20 kPa. Assume unit weight for both sand and clay as 18 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The totalactive earth pressure per unit length of the wall (in kN/m) is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi_{\text {clay }}&=0 \\ K_{a_{1}}&=\frac{1-\sin \phi}{1+\sin \phi}=\frac{1}{3} \\ K_{a_{2}}&=1 \\ p_{B}&=K_{a_{1}} \gamma z=\frac{1}{3} \times 18 \times 3=18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ p_{B^{\prime}}&=K_{a_{2}} \gamma z-2 c \sqrt{K_{a_{2}}} \\ &=1 \times 18 \times 3-2 \times 20 \sqrt{1}=14 \\ p_{C}&=K_{a_{2}} \gamma Z-2 c \sqrt{K_{a_{2}}} \\ &=18 \times 6-2 \times 20 \sqrt{1}=68 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total active earth pressure per unit length of wall [latex] P_{a}=\frac{1}{2} \times 18 \times 3+\frac{1}{2}(68+54) \times 3=150 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 179 Stress path equation for tri-axial test upon application of deviatoric stress is, [latex]q=10\sqrt{3}+0.5p[/latex]. The respective values of cohesion, c (in kPa) and angle of internal friction, [latex]\phi[/latex] are:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{2t}}{2}&= c \cos \phi+\frac{\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{2t}}{2}\sin\phi\\ \text{as}\quad q&=10\sqrt{3}+0.5p\\ \Rightarrow \quad c \cos\phi&=10\sqrt{3}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \beta&=\sin^{-1}(0.5)=30^{\circ}\\ \Rightarrow \quad c&=\frac{10\sqrt{3}}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}=20\\ \Rightarrow \quad c&=20\\ \phi&=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 A pile of diameter 0.4 m is fully embedded in a clay stratum having 5 layers, each 5 m thick as shown in the figure below. Assume a constant unit weight of soil as 18 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] for all the layers. Using [latex]\lambda[/latex]-method ([latex]\lambda[/latex]=0.15 for 25 m embedment length) and neglecting the end bearing component, the ultimate pile capacity (in kN) is ________.
solution: Ultimate bearing capacity [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\lambda\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{v} a v}+2 C_{u}\right) A_{s} \\ &=0.15\left[18 \times 12.5+2 C_{u}\right] \times(\pi \times 0.4 \times 25) \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] C_{u}[/latex] is the average value of all layers i.e., 60 kPa. [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.15[18 \times 12.5+2 \times 60] \times(\pi \times 0.4 \times 25) \\ &=1625.77 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 A 4 m thick layer of normally consolidated clay has an average void ratio of 1.30. Its compression index is 0.6 and coefficient of consolidation is 1 [latex]m^{2}/yr[/latex]. If the increase in vertical pressure due to foundation load on the clay layer is equal to the existing effective overburden pressure, the change in the thickness of the clay layer is ______ mm.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e &=1.3 \\ C_{C} &=0.6 \\ C_{V} &=1 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{year} \\ \Delta H &=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{H}_{0}}{1+\mathrm{e}_{0}} \log _{10}\left[\frac{\overline{\mathrm{\sigma}}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] As increase in vertical pressure [latex](\Delta \sigma)[/latex] is equal to existing effective over burden pressure [latex]\left(\bar{\sigma}_{0}\right), [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{0.6 \times 4}{1+1.3} \log _{10}\left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\bar{\sigma}_{0}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right) \\ &=\frac{0.6 \times 4}{2.3} \log _{10} 2 \\ &=0.314 \mathrm{m}=314 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 182 A 588 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] volume of moist sand weighs 1010 gm. Its dry weight is 918 gm and specific gravity of solids, G is 2.67. Assuming density of water as 1 gm/[latex]cm^{3}[/latex], the void ratio is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma_{\mathrm{d}} &=\frac{918}{588}=1.561 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cc} \\ \gamma_{\mathrm{d}} &=\frac{G \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}}{1+e} \\ 1.561 &=\frac{2.67 \times 1}{1+\mathrm{e}} \\ e &=0.71 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 183 Surcharge loading required to placed on the horizontal backfill of a smooth retaining vertical wall so as to completely eliminate tensile crack is:
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} K_{a} q=2 c \sqrt{K_{a}} \\ q=\frac{2 c}{\sqrt{K_{a}}} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 187 A square footing (2m x 2m) is subjected to an inclined point load P as shown in the figure below. The water table is located well below the base of the footing. Considering one-way eccentricity, the net safe load carrying capacity of the footing for a factor of safety of 3.0 is _________ kN. The following factor may be used: Bearing capacity factors: [latex]N_{q}[/latex] =33.3, [latex]N_{\gamma }[/latex]=37.16; Shape factor:[latex]F_{qs }=F_{\gamma s }[/latex]=1.314; Depth factors : [latex]F_{q d }=F_{\gamma d }[/latex]=1.133; Inclination factors: [latex]F_{q i }[/latex]=0.444, [latex]F_{\gamma i }[/latex]=0.02
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} B'&= B-2e_x\\ &= 2-2 \times 0.15\\ &= 1.7m \end{aligned}[/latex] As per Meyerhof theory [latex]\begin{aligned} q_u&=CN_cS_cd_ci_c+\gamma D_fN_qd_qi_q\\ &+0.5B'\gamma N_\gamma S_\gamma d_ri_r\\ q_u&=18 \times 1(1.314 \times 1.113 \times 0.444) \times 33.3\\ &+10.5 \times 1.7 \times 18 \times 37.16 \\ & \times (1.314 \times 1.113 \times 0.02)\\ &=405.84 \; kN/m^2\\ q_{ns}&=\frac{q_u-\sigma }{F}=\frac{q_u-\gamma D_f}{F}\\ &=\frac{405.84-18 \times 1}{3}\\ &=129.28 \; kN/m^2\\ &\text{Net safe load}\\ &=q_{ns} \times \text{Area}\\ &=q_{ns} \times (B' \times L)\\ &=129.28 \times 1.7 \times 2\\ &=439.55\; kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 188 A non-homogenous soil deposit consists of a silt layer sandwiched between a fine-sand layer at top and a clay layer below. Permeability of the silt layer is 10 times the permeability of the clay layer and one-tenth of the permeability of the sand layer. Thickness of the silt layer is 2 times the thickness of the sand layer and two-third of the thickness of the clay layer. The ratio of equivalent horizontal and equivalent vertical permeability of the deposit is __________.

Question 189 A 20 m thick clay layer is sandwiched between a silty sand layer and a gravelly sand layer. The layer experiences 30 mm settlement in 2 years. Given: [latex]T_{v}=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{\pi }{4}\left ( \frac{U}{100} \right )^{2}& forU\leq 60\%\\ 1.781-0.933\log_{10}(100-U)& for U>60\%\end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Where [latex]T_v[/latex] is the time factor and U is the degree consolidation in [latex]\%[/latex]. If the coefficient of consolidation of the layer is 0.003 [latex]cm^{2}/s[/latex], the deposit will experience a total of 50 mm settlement in the next _______ years.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{v}&=\frac{C_{v} t}{d^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{v}&=\frac{0.003 \times 2 \times 86400 \times 365}{\left(\frac{20}{2} \times 100\right)^{2}}\\ T_{v}&=0.1892 \lt 0.02827 \\ T_{v}&=\frac{\pi}{4} U^{2}=0.1892 &(\therefore U \lt 60 \%)\\ \Rightarrow \quad U&=0.4908 \\ \Rightarrow \quad&\text{Total consolidation}\\ &=\frac{30}{0.4908}=61.12 \mathrm{mm}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Degree of consolidation for 50 mm settlement [latex] \begin{aligned} U &=\frac{50}{61.12}=0.818=81.8 \% \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{v} &=0.60835=\frac{C_{v} t}{H^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t &=\frac{0.60835 \times(10)^{2}}{0.003 \times 10^{-4}} \\ &=6.43 \text { years } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex]Additional number of years =4.43

question: Question 190 A water tank is to be constructed on the soil deposit shown in the figure below. A circular footing of diameter 3 m and depth of embedment 1 m has been designed to support the tank. The total vertical load to be taken by the footing is 1500 kN. Assume the unit weight of water as 10 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] and the load dispersion pattern as 2V:1H. The expected settlement of the tank due to primary consolidation of the clay layer is ________ mm.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta H &=\frac{C_{C} H_{0}}{1+e_{0}} \log _{10}\left[\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right] \\ H_{0} &=\text { Thickness of clay layer } \\ &=10 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \bar{\sigma}_{0}=[/latex] Effective stress before application of load at the centre of clay layer [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{0}&=(15 \times 2)+(18-10) \times 6+(18-10) \times 5 \\ &= 118 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Delta \bar{\sigma}=[/latex] Increase in effective stress due to the structural weight at the centre of clay layer [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta \bar{\sigma} &=\frac{1500}{\frac{\pi}{4} \times(3+12)^{2}}=8.488 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \Delta H &=\frac{0.3 \times 10}{1+0.7} \log _{10}\left(\frac{118+8.488}{118}\right) \\ &=0.053236 \mathrm{m}=53.236 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 191 An earth embankment is to be constructed with compacted cohesionless soil. The volume of the embankment is 5000 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] and the target dry unit weight is 16.2 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex]. Three nearby sites (see figure blwo) have been identified from where the required soil can be transported to the construction site. The void ratios (e) of different sites are shown in the figure. Assume the specific gravity of soil to be 2.7 for all three sites. If the cost of transportation per km is twice the cost of excavation per [latex]m^{3}[/latex] of borrow pits, which site would you choose as the most economic solution? (Use unit weight of water = 10[latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex])
solution:
Volume of solids at embankment, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
V_{s} &=\frac{W_{s}}{G_{s} \gamma_{w}} \\
V_{s} &=\frac{16.2 \times 5000}{27 \times 10} \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
&=3000 \mathrm{m}^{3}
\end{aligned}[/latex] Volume of solids will remain constant. also, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
V &=V_{V}+V_{s} \\
&=e V_{s}+V_{s}=V_{s}(1+e) \\
V &=3000(1+e) \\
V_{X} &=3000 \times 1.6=4800 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
V_{Y} &=3000 \times 1.7=5100 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\
v_{z} &=3000 \times 1.64=4920 \mathrm{m}^{3}
\end{aligned}[/latex] Let cost of excavation be [latex]\alpha / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{X} &=4800 \alpha+140 \times \alpha \times 2 \\
&=5080 \alpha \\
P_{Y} &=5100 \alpha+80 \times \alpha \times 2 \\
&=5260 \alpha \\
P_{Z} &=4920 \alpha+100 \times \alpha \times 2 \\
&=5120 \alpha
\end{aligned}[/latex] Hence [latex] P_{X}[/latex] is least. Hence total cost for site X is least.

question: Question 192 Which of the following statement is NOT correct?
solution: The phenomenon where cohesionless soil near the downstream side of dams or sheet piles loses its shear strength due to high upward hydraulic gradient is called piping

options.A: Loose sand exhibits contractive behavior upon shearing
options.B: Dense sand when sheared under undrained condition, may lead to generation of negative pore pressure
options.C: Black cotton soil exhibits expansive behavior
options.D: Liquefaction is the phenomenon where cohesionless soil near the downstream side of dams or sheet-piles loses its shear strength due to high upward hydraulic gradient

question: Question 193 In an unconsolidated undrained triaxial test, it is observed that an increase in cell pressure from 150 kPas to 250 kPa leads to a pore pressure increase of 80 kPa. It is further observed that, an increase of 50 kPa in deviatoric stress result in an increase of 25 kPa in the pore pressure. The value of Skempton's pore pressure parameter B is:
solution: [latex]B=\frac{\Delta u}{\Delta \sigma_{3}}=\frac{80}{250-150}=0.80[/latex]

question: Question 194 Which of the following statement is TRUE for degree of disturbance of collected soil sample?
solution: As thickness of sampler increase, disturbance increase
