options.C: Thickness of the sampler wall and the degree of disturbance of collected soil sample are unrelated
options.D: The degree of disturbance of collected soil sample is proportional to the inner diameter of the sampling tube

question: Question 195 Which of the following statement is TRUE for the relation between discharge velocity and seepage velocity?
solution: Seepage velocity is given by [latex] V_{s}=\frac{V}{n}[/latex] where, V= discharge velocity [latex] \begin{aligned} n&=\frac{V_{V}}{V}<1 \\ \text{Hence,}\quad V_{s}&>V \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: Seepage velocity is always smaller than discharge velocity
options.B: Seepage velocity can never be smaller than discharge velocity
options.C: Seepage velocity is equal to the discharge velocity
options.D: No relation between seepage velocity and discharge velocity can be established.

question: Question 196 A fine-grained soil has 60% (by weight) silt content. The soil behaves as semi-solid when water content is between 15% and 28%. The soil behaves fluid-like when the water content is more than 40%. The 'Activity' of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{p} &=W_{L}-W_{p}=40-28=12 \% \\ \text { Activity } &=\frac{I p}{C(\% \text { clay fraction finer than } 2 \mu)} \\ &=\frac{12}{40}=0.3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 197 A circular raft foundation of 20 m diameter and 1.6m thick is provided for a tank that applies a bearing pressure of 110 kPa on sandy soil with Young's modulus, [latex]E_s'= 30 [/latex]MPa and Poisson's ration, [latex]v_s=0.3[/latex]. The raft is made of concrete ([latex]E_c=30[/latex] GPa and [latex]v_c=0.15[/latex]). Considering the raft as rigid, the elastic settlement (in mm) is
solution: Elastic settlement of rigid footing [latex] =\frac{q B\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}{E_{s}} \times I_{f}[/latex] Shape factor for circular raft footing. [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{t} &=0.8 \\ \Rightarrow \quad S_{1} &=0.8\left[\frac{110 \times 20\left(1-0.3^{2}\right)}{30}\right] \\ &=53.386 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 198 A single vertical friction pile of diameter 500 mm and length 20 m is subjected to a vertical compressive load. The pile is embedded in a homogeneous sandy stratum where: angle of internal friction is [latex]\phi=30^{\circ}[/latex], dry unit weight [latex](\gamma _{d})=20 kN/m^{3}[/latex] and angle of wall friction is [latex]\delta =2\varphi /3[/latex]. Considering the coefficient of lateral earth pressure (K)=2.7 and the bearing capacity factor ([latex]N_q[/latex])=25, the ultimate bearing capacity of the pile (in kN) is________
solution: Homogeneous sandy stratum [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi &=30^{\circ} \\ \gamma_{d} &=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Wall friction angle. [latex] \delta=\frac{2}{3} \phi=\frac{2}{3} \times 30=20^{\circ}[/latex] Lateral earth pressure coefficient, [latex] K=2.7[/latex] Bearing capacity factor, [latex] N_{q}=25[/latex] Ultimate load capacity, [latex] Q_{u}=?[/latex] Vertical effective stress at 20m. [latex] \overline{\sigma_{v}}=20 \times 20=400 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] From 0 to 20m, unit point bearing resistance and skin friction resistance remain constant at [latex] \overline{\sigma_{\mathrm{v}}}=400 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] The ultimate load capacity is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{u}&=q_{\mathrm{up}} \cdot A_{p}+q_{\mathrm{s}} \cdot A_{s}\\ &=f_{s}\left(Q_{u p}=0\right. for friction pile) \\ \text{where}\quad q_{s}&=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \overline{\sigma_{v}} \cdot K \cdot \tan \delta\\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 400 \times 2.7 \tan 20^{\circ} \\ &=196.54 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Skin friction resistance, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{u}=f_{s} &=196.54 \times \pi \times 0.5 \times 20 \\ &=6174.49 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 199 Group I enlists in-situ field tests carried out for soil exploration, while Group II provides a list of parameters for sub-soil strength characterization. Math the type of tests with the characterization parameters

Question 200 An infinitely long slope is made up of a [latex]c-\phi[/latex] soil having the properties: cohesion (c)=20 kPa, and dry unit weight [latex](\gamma _{d} )= 16kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The angle of inclination and critical height of the slope are [latex]40^{\circ}[/latex] and 5 m, respectively. To maintain the limiting equilibrium, the angle of internal friction of the soil (in degree) is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} F_{0}=\frac{c}{\gamma H \sin \beta \cdot \cos \beta}+\frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta} \geq 1 \\ c=20 \mathrm{kPa}, \gamma=16 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \beta=40^{\circ} \text { and } \\ H=5 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow \quad, \quad \phi \geq 22.44^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 201 Water is flowing at a steady rate through a homogeneous and saturated horizontal soil strip of 10 m length. The strip is being subjected to a constant water head(H) of 5 m at the beginning and 1 m at the end. If the governing equation of flow in the soil strip is [latex]\frac{d^{2}H}{dx^2}=0[/latex] (where x is the distance along the soil strip), the value of H (in m) at the middle of the strip is ________.
solution: Given, equation of the flow of soil strip is [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} H}{d x^{2}}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{H}}{\mathrm{d} x}&=\mathrm{C}_{1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad H&=C_{1} x+C_{2} \\ \text{at }x=0, H=&5 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow \quad C_{2}&=5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad H&=C_{1} x+5 \\ \text{at }x&=10, H=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1&=C_{1} \times 10+5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 10 C_{1}&=-4 \\ \Rightarrow \quad C_{1}&=-\frac{2}{5} \\ \Rightarrow \quad H&=-\frac{2}{5} x+5 \\ \text{at }x&=5 \mathrm{m} \\ H&=-\frac{2}{5} \times 5+5 \\ H&=3 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 202 A certain soil has the following properties: [latex]G_{s}[/latex]=2.71, n=40% and w=20%. The degree of saturation of soil (rounded off to the nearest percent) is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Se&=wG \\ \text{and }e&=\frac{n}{1-n}=0.67 \\ \Rightarrow \quad S&=\frac{2.71 \times 20}{0.67}=81.3 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Stress distribution for cohesiv soil Minimum at center and maximum at adge

question: Question 204 The clay mineral primarily governing the swelling behavior of Black Cotton soil is
Question 205 As per Indian Standard Soil Classification System (IS: 1498-1970), an expression for A-line is

Question 206 The flow net constructed for the dam is shown in the figure below. Taking the coefficient ofpermeability as [latex]3.8\times 10^{-6}m/s[/latex], the quantity of flow (in [latex]cm^{3}/s[/latex]) under the dam per meter of dam is______________
solution: Quantity of flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\mathrm{kH} \frac{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{f}}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{d}}}\\ \text{Here, } \quad N_{f}&=\text{ No. of flow channels =3 }\\ N_{d}&=\text{ No. of equipotential}\\ \text { drops }=10 \\ \text{Given,}\quad k&=3.8 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{and }\quad H&=6.3 \mathrm{m} \\ Q &=3.8 \times 10^{-6} \times 6.3 \times \frac{3}{10} \times 1 \\ &=7.182 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=7.182 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{6} \mathrm{cm}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} \\ \mathrm{Q} &=7.182 \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 207 The following data are given for the laboratory sample. [latex]{\sigma _{o}}'=175\, \, kPa[/latex]; [latex]e_{o}=1.1[/latex]; [latex]{\sigma _{0}}'+\Delta {\sigma _{o}}'=300\, \, kPa[/latex]; e=0.9 If thickness of the clay specimen is 25 mm, the value of coefficient of volume compressibility is___________[latex]\times 10^{-4}\, m^{2}/kN[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m_{v} &=\frac{a_{v}}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{\frac{\Delta e}{\Delta \bar{\sigma}}}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{(1.1-0.9)}{125 \times 2.1} \\ &=7.619 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 208 A given cohesionless soil has [latex]e_{max}=0.85[/latex] and [latex]e_{min}=0.50[/latex]. In the field, the soil is compacted to a mass density of 1800 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]
 at a water content of 8%. Take the mass density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]G_{s}[/latex] as 2.7. The relative density (in %) of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e_{max} &=0.85 \\ e_{min} &=0.5 \\ \rho_{\text {field }} &=1800 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ &\text{at water content }=8\% \\ \rho_{w}&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ G_{S}&=2.7 \end{aligned}[/latex] Relative density, [latex]\mathrm{I}_{D}=? [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho=\frac{G_{p_{W}}(1+w)}{1+e}&=\frac{2.7 \times 1000(1.08)}{1+e}\\ \Rightarrow\quad 1+e &=\frac{2.7 \times 1000 \times 1.08}{1800} \\ \Rightarrow\quad e &=0.62\\ \Rightarrow\quad I_{D} &=\frac{e_{\max }-e}{e_{\max }-e_{\min }} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{0.85-0.62}{0.85-0.5} \times 100 \\ &=65.714 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 209 Group I contains representative load-settlement curves for different modes of bearing capacity failures of sandy soil. Group II enlists the various failure characteristics. Match the load-settlement curves with the corresponding failure characteristics.

Question 210 A long slope is formed in a soil with shear strength parameters: [latex]{c}'=0[/latex]  and [latex]{\phi }'=34^{\circ}[/latex]. A firm stratum lies below the slope and it is assumed that the water table may occasionally rise to the surface, with seepage taking place parallel to the slope. Use [latex]\gamma_{sat}=18 kN/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma_{w}=10 kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The maximum slope angle (in degrees) to ensure a factor of safety of 1.5, assuming a potential failure surface parallel to the slope, would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F O S&=\frac{Y_{s u}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta}\\ \Rightarrow \tan \beta&=\left(\frac{\gamma_{\text {sub }}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{F O S}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \beta&=\frac{\gamma_{\text {sub }}}{\gamma_{\text {aat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{1.5}\\ \tan \beta &=\frac{(18-10)}{18 \times 1.5} \times \tan 34^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \beta &=11.30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 214 A multistory building with a basement is to be constructed. The top 4m consists of loose silt, below which
dense sand layer is present up to a great depth. Ground water table is at the surface. The foundation consists
of the basement slab of 6 m width which will rest on the top of dense sand as shown in the figure. For
dense sand, saturated unit weight = 20kN/[latex]m^3[/latex], and bearing capacity factors [latex]N_q[/latex]=40 and [latex]N_{\gamma }[/latex]=45. For loose
silt, saturated unit weight = 18kN/[latex]m^3[/latex], [latex]N_q[/latex]=15 and [latex]N_{\gamma }[/latex]=20. Effective cohesion c' is zero for both soils. Unit
weight of water is 10 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]. Neglect shape factor and depth factor. Average elastic modulus E and Poisson's ratio [latex]\mu[/latex] of dense sand is [latex]60 \times 10^3kN/m^2[/latex] and 0.3 respectively. The foundation slab is subjected to vertical downward stresses equal to net safe bearing capacity
derived in the above question. Using influence factor [latex]I_{f}[/latex] = 2.0, and neglecting embedment depth and rigidity corrections, the immediate settlement of the dense sand layer will be:
solution:
As per GATE Official Answer Key MTA (Marks to ALL) Immediate settlement [latex]
\begin{aligned}
S_{i} &=\frac{q B\left(1-\mu^{2}\right) 4}{E_{S}} \\
q &=Q_{n s}+\gamma D_{t} \\
&=519.72+8.19 \times 4 \\
&=552.48 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
S_{1} &=\frac{552.48 \times 6 \times\left(1-0.3^{2}\right) \times 2}{60 \times 10^{3}} \\
&=0.10055 \mathrm{m}=100 \mathrm{mm}
\end{aligned}[/latex] (Marks to All)

question:
Question 215 A multistory building with a basement is to be constructed. The top 4m consists of loose silt, below which
dense sand layer is present up to a great depth. Ground water table is at the surface. The foundation consists
of the basement slab of 6 m width which will rest on the top of dense sand as shown in the figure. For
dense sand, saturated unit weight = 20kN/[latex]m^3[/latex], and bearing capacity factors [latex]N_q[/latex]=40 and [latex]N_{\gamma }[/latex]=45. For loose
silt, saturated unit weight = 18kN/[latex]m^3[/latex], [latex]N_q[/latex]=15 and [latex]N_{\gamma }[/latex]=20. Effective cohesion c' is zero for both soils. Unit
weight of water is 10 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]. Neglect shape factor and depth factor. Average elastic modulus E and Poisson's ratio [latex]\mu[/latex] of dense sand is [latex]60 \times 10^3kN/m^2[/latex] and 0.3 respectively. Using factor of safety = 3, the net safe bearing capacity (in kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) of the foundation is:
solution: As per GATE Official Answer Key MTA (Marks to ALL) [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{u}&=1.3 \mathrm{cN}_{\mathrm{c}}+\left(\gamma^{\prime}\right)_{\mathrm{silt}}\left(\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{q}}\right)_{\mathrm{silt}} \mathrm{D}_{\mathrm{t}}+0.4 \mathrm{B}(\gamma)_{\mathrm{sand}} (N_{\gamma})_{\text{sand}} \\ &=8.19 \times 4 \times 15+0.4 \times 10.19 \times 6 \times 45 \\ &=1591.92 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ & \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{nu}}=\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{u}}-\gamma \mathrm{D}_{\mathrm{f}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Safe bearing capacity [latex]=Q_{n s}=\frac{Q_{n u}}{F} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1591.92-8.19 \times 4}{3}=519.72 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex]

question:
Question 216 Two different soil types (Soil 1 and Soil 2) are used as backfill behind a retaining wall as shown in
the figure, where [latex]\gamma _{t}[/latex] is total unit weight, and c' and [latex]\phi[/latex]' are effective cohesion and effective angle of shearing resistance. The resultant active earth force per unit length (in kN/m) acting on the wall is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{a 1} &=\frac{1-\sin 30^{\circ}}{1+\sin 30^{\circ}}=\frac{1}{3}=0.33 \\ k_{a_{2}} &=\frac{1-\sin 40^{\circ}}{1+\sin 40^{\circ}}=0.217 \\ P_{a_{1}} &=\frac{1}{2} k_{a_{1}} \gamma_{1} H_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{3} \times 15 \times 2^{2} \\ &=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{a_{2}} &=k_{a_{2}} \gamma_{1} H_{1} \cdot H_{2}=0.217 \times 15 \times 2 \times 2 \\ &=13.02 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \\ P_{a_{3}} &=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}_{02} \gamma_{2} \mathrm{H}_{2}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 0.217 \times 20 \times 2^{2} \\ &=8.68 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \\ P_{a} &=P_{a_{1}}+P_{\mathrm{a}_{2}}+P_{a_{3}}=10+13.02+8.68 \\ P_{\mathrm{a}} &=31.7 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 217 The soil profile above the rock surface for a 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] infinite slope is shown in the figure, where [latex]s_{u}[/latex] is the undrained shear strength and [latex]\gamma _{t}[/latex] is total unit weight. The slip will occur at a depth of
solution: The slip will occur when shear stress is greater then or equal to shear strength. [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &\geq S_{u} \\ \left(\gamma_{1} z_{1}+\gamma_{2} z_{2}\right) \sin \beta \cos \beta &\geq S_{u}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{\left(16 \times 5+20 \times z_{2}\right) \sin 2 \beta}{2} &\geq S_{u} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\left(80+20 z_{2}\right) \sin 50^{\circ}}{2} &\geq 60 \\ z_{2}&=3.83 \mathrm{m} \\ \text{ Depth of slip }=5+3.83&=8.83 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 218 The soil profile below a lake with water level at elevation = 0 m and lake bottom at elevation = -10 m is shown in the figure, where k is the permeability coefficient. A piezometer (stand pipe)
installed in the sand layer shows a reading of +10 m elevation. Assume that thepiezometric headis
uniform in the sand layer. The quantity of water (in [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s) flowing into the lake from the sand layer through the silt layer per unit area of the lake bed is:
solution: From the diagram, 10m of head is lost in 20m of silt layer before reaching lake [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 &=\frac{h}{z}=\frac{10}{20}=0.5 \\ Q &=k i A=10^{-6} \times 0.5 \times 1 \\ &=0.5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 219 Laplace equation for water flow in soils is given below. [latex]\frac{\partial^2 H}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 H}{\partial y^2}+\frac{\partial^2 H}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex] Head H does not vary in y and z directions. Boundary conditions are: at x = 0, H = 5; and [latex]\frac{dH}{dx}=-1[/latex]. What is the value of [latex]H[/latex] at [latex]x = 1.2[/latex]? __________
solution: [latex]\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial x^{2}}=0[/latex] Integrating both sides, we get [latex] \frac{\partial H}{\partial x}=C_{1} \quad \ldots(i)[/latex] Integrating again [latex] \begin{aligned} H&=C_{1} x+C_{2}\\ \text{At }\quad x&=0, H=5 \\ \therefore \quad 5&=C_{2} \\ \text{At }\quad x&=0, \frac{d H}{d x}=-1 \end{aligned} [/latex] From eq. (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore C_{1}&=-1 \\ \therefore \quad H&=-x+5 \\ \text { At } x &=1.2 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{H}&=5-1.2=3.8 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 220 Four columns of a building are to be located within a plot size of 10 m x 10 m. The expected load
on each column is 4000 kN. Allowable bearing capacity of the soil deposit is 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The type of foundation best suited is
solution:
Load on each column =400 kN Bearing capacity of soil [latex]=100 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] [latex]
 \therefore \quad [/latex] Area of each footing required [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&=\frac{400}{100} m^{2}=4 m^{2}\\
 \therefore \quad \text{Total area required } &=4 \times 4=16 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\
 \therefore \quad \frac{\text { Foundation area }}{\text { Plot area }}&=\frac{16}{100}=16 \% 
\end{aligned}[/latex] If the foundation area is less than 40% of plot 
area, then isolated foundation is suitable otherwise 
provide raft foundation or combined footing.

question:
Question 222 The ratio [latex]N_f/N_d[/latex] is known as shape factor, where [latex]N_f[/latex] is the number of flow lines and [latex]N_d[/latex] is the
number of equipotential drops. Flow net is always drawn with a constant b/a ratio, where b and a
are distances between two consecutive flow lines and equipotential lines, respectively. Assuming
that b/a ratio remains the same, the shape factor of a flow net will change if the
solution:
Flow net depends on given boundary conditions 
and if the boundary conditions does not change 
then [latex]\frac{N_{f}}{N_{d}}[/latex] will not change.

options.A: upstream and downstream heads are interchanged
options.B: soil in the flow space is changed
options.C: dimensions of the flow space are changed
options.D: head difference causing the flow is changed

question:
Question 223 In its natural condition, a soil sample has a mass of 1.980 kg and a volume of 0.001 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]. After being completely dried in an oven, the mass of the sample is 1.800 kg. Specific gravity G is 2.7. 
Unit weight of water is 10 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The degree of saturation of the soil is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho &=\frac{M}{V} \\ &=\frac{1.980}{0.001}=1980 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \rho_{d} &=\frac{M_{d}}{V}\\ &=\frac{1.800}{0.001}=1800 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \rho_{d} &=\frac{\rho}{1+\mathrm{w}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1800 &=\frac{1980}{1+\mathrm{w}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & \mathrm{w}=0.1 \\ \because \quad & \rho_{\mathrm{d}}=\frac{\mathrm{G} \cdot \rho_{\mathrm{w}}}{1+\mathrm{e}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 1800&=\frac{2.7 \times 1000}{1+e} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e&=0.5 \\ \because wG&=e.s\\ \Rightarrow 0.1 \times 2.7&=0.5 S \\ \Rightarrow \quad S&=0.54 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 224 The flow net around a sheet pile wall is shown in the
sketch. The properties of the soil are: permeability
coefficient = 0.09 m/day (isotropic), specific gravity
= 2.70 and void ratio = 0.85. The sheet pile wall and
the bottom of the soil are impermeable. The factor of safety against the occurrence of piping failure is
solution: [latex]H_{2}=H_{1}-H_{2}=10-1.5=8.5 \mathrm{m}[/latex] loss of head per drop [latex] =\frac{8.5}{8}=1.0625[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Hydraulic gradient, [latex] \begin{aligned} i &=\frac{1.0625}{3}=0.354 \\ \therefore \quad & \mathrm{FOS}=\frac{\mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{C}}}{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{0.9189}{0.354}=2.60 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 225 The flow net around a sheet pile wall is shown in the
sketch. The properties of the soil are: permeability
coefficient = 0.09 m/day (isotropic), specific gravity
= 2.70 and void ratio = 0.85. The sheet pile wall and
the bottom of the soil are impermeable. The seepage loss (in [latex]m^3[/latex] per day per unit length of the wall) of water is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k&=0.09 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} \\ G&=2.70 \\ e&=0.85 \\ q&=k H_{L} \frac{N_{t}}{N_{0}}\\ H_{L} &=H_{1}-H_{2}=10-1.5=8.5 \mathrm{m} \\ N_{t} &=\text { No. of flow lines } \\ &=3+1=4 \\ N_{\mathrm{d}}&=\text{ No of equipotential drops }\\ &=7+1=8 \\ q &=0.09 \times 8.5 \times 4 / 8 \\ &=0.38 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 226 Steady state seepage is taking place through a soil element at Q, 2 m below the ground surface immediately downstream of the toe of an earthen dam as shown in the sketch. The water level in
a piezometer installed at P, 500 mm above Q, is at the ground surface. The water level in a piezometer installed at R, 500 mm below Q, is 100 mm above the ground surface. The bulk
saturated unit weight of the soil is 18 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex] and the unit weight of water is 9.81 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]. The vertical effective stress (in kPa) at Q is
solution: Ther given situation can be represented as [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=(1.5+0.5) \gamma_{\operatorname{sat}} \\ u &=2.05 \gamma_{w} \\ \sigma^{\prime} &=\sigma-u \\ &=2 \gamma_{\text{sat}}-2.05 \gamma_{w} \\ &=15.89 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 227 A layer of normally consolidated, saturated silty clay of 1 m thickness is subjected to one
dimensional consolidation under a pressure increment of 20 kPa. The properties of the soil are:
specific gravity = 2.7, natural moisture content = 45%, compression index = 0.45, and
recompression index = 0.05. The initial average effective stress within the layer is 100 kPa.
Assuming Terzaghi's theory to be applicable, the primary consolidation settlement (rounded off to
the nearest mm) is
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta \bar{\sigma} &=20 \mathrm{kPa}, \bar{\sigma}_{0}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ G &=2.7 \\ \mathrm{w} &=45 \% \\ \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{c}} &=0.45 \\ \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{r}} &=0.05 \\ \mathrm{H}_{0} &=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \quad \Delta \mathrm{H} &=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{H}_{0}}{1+\mathrm{e}_{0}} \log _{10}\left[\frac{\overline{\mathrm{\sigma}}_{0}+\Delta \overline{\mathrm{o}}}{\overline{\mathrm{\sigma}}_{0}}\right] \\ \text{Also},\quad wG&=eS \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.45 \times 2.7 &=e .1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad &=1.215 \\ \therefore \quad \Delta H &=\frac{0.45 \times 1}{1+1.215} \log _{10}\left(\frac{(100+20)}{100}\right) \\ &=\frac{0.45}{2.215} \log _{10}\left(\frac{120}{100}\right) \\ &=0.016 \mathrm{m}=16 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 228 Two soil specimens with identical geometric dimensions were subjected to falling head
permeability tests in the laboratory under identical conditions. The fall of water head was measured
after an identical time interval. The ratio of initial to final water heads for the test involving the first
specimen was 1.25. If the coefficient of permeability of the second specimen is 5-times that of the
first, the ratio of initial to final water heads in the test involving the second specimen is
solution: Given, For first specimen. [latex] \frac{h_{1}}{h_{2}}=1.25 \; \& \; k_{2}=5 k_{1}[/latex] then for second specimen, [latex]\frac{h'_1}{h'_2}=? [/latex] We know that; for falling head permeability test. [latex] \begin{aligned} k&=\frac{2.303 a L}{A \cdot t} \log _{10}\left(\frac{h_{1}}{h_{2}}\right)\\ \therefore \quad \frac{k_{2}}{k_{1}}&=\frac{\log _{10}\left(h'_{1} / h'_{2}\right)}{\log _{10}\left(h_{1} / h_{2}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow 5 \log _{10} 1.25&=\log _{10}\left(\frac{h'_{1}}{h'_{2}}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{h'_{1}}{h'_{2}}&=3.05 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 229 An embankment is to be constructed with a granular soil (bulk unit weight = 20 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]) on a
saturated clayey silt deposit (undrained shear strength = 25 kPa). Assuming undrained general shear
failure and bearing capacity factor of 5.7, the maximum height (in m) of the embankment at the
point of failure is
solution: Given, [latex]\gamma=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] Shear strength [latex]\mathrm{s}=25 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] Bearing capacity factor, [latex]N_{c}=5.7 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \because\quad &=c \quad \Rightarrow c=25 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ q_{u}&=c N_{c}=25 \times 5.7 \\ \Rightarrow \gamma \mathrm{D}_{t}&=25 \times 5.7\\ \Rightarrow \quad D_{1}&=7.1 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 231 As per the Indian Standard soil classification system, a sample of silty clay with liquid limit of 40%
and plasticity index of 28% is classified as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 1_{p}\text{ of soil } &=28 \% \\ \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{P}} \text{ of A-line }&=0.73\left(\mathrm{w}_{\mathrm{L}}-20\right) \\ &=0.73(40-20)=14.6\\ \because \quad 1_{p} &\text{ of soil } \gt 1_{p}\text{ of A-line}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] It will be above A-line and also [latex]35 \lt w_{2} \lt 50 [/latex] So it is CI.

question:
Question 232 Two series of compaction tests were performed in the laboratory on an inorganic clayey soil
employing two different levels of compaction energy per unit volume of soil. With regard to the
above tests, the following two statements are made. I The optimum moisture content is expected to be more for the tests with higher energy. II The maximum dry density is expected to be more for the tests with higher energy. The CORRECT option evaluating the above statements is
solution: Optimum moisture content of the soil decreases with increase compactive efforts.

options.C: Both I and II are TRUE
options.D: Neither I nor II is TRUE

question:
Question 233 The effective stress friction angle of a saturated, cohesionless soil is 38[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The ratio of shear stress to
normal effective stress on the failure plane is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \tau&=c+\bar{\sigma}_{a} \tan \phi \\ \text{For sands,} \quad c&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau&=\bar{\sigma}_{n} \tan \phi \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\tau}{\sigma_{n}}&=\tan \phi=\tan 38^{\circ}=0.781 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 234 A sand layer found at sea floor under 20 m water depth is characterized with relative
density=40%, maximum void ratio=1.0 , minimum void ratio=0.5, and specific
gravity of soil solids=2.67. Assume the specific gravity of sea water to be 1.03 and the
unit weight of fresh water to be 9.81 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]. What would be the change in the effective stress (rounded off to the nearest
integer value of kPa) at 30 m depth into the sand layer if the sea water level
permanently rises by 2m?
solution: The effective stress will not alter due to change in sea water level. The total stress will increase due to increase in sea water level. The pore water pressure will also increase in the same proportion, thus nullifying the effect of each other [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=22 \times 10.1043+30 \times 19.48 \\ &=806.695 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ u &=(22+30) \times 10.1043 \\ &=525.424 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \therefore\quad \bar{\sigma} &=\sigma-u=806.695-525.424 \\ &=281.271 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 235 A sand layer found at sea floor under 20 m water depth is characterized with relative
density=40%, maximum void ratio=1.0 , minimum void ratio=0.5, and specific
gravity of soil solids=2.67. Assume the specific gravity of sea water to be 1.03 and the
unit weight of fresh water to be 9.81 kN/[latex]m^3[/latex]. What would be the effective stress (rounded off to the nearest integer value of
kPa) at 30 m depth into the sand layer?
solution: Relative density is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D}(\%)&=\left(\frac{e_{\max }-e_{\text {nat }}}{e_{\max }-e_{\min }}\right) \times 100\\ \Rightarrow \quad 40&=\left(\frac{1-e_{n a t}}{1-0.5}\right) \times 100 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.4 \times 0.5&=1-e_{\text {nat }} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e_{\text {nat }}&=0.8 \\ \text{Also,} \quad G_{\text {sea }}&=\frac{\gamma_{\text {sea }}}{\gamma_{w}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \gamma_{\text {sea }}&=1.03 \times 9.81 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \gamma_{\mathrm{sea}}&=10.1043 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}&=\left(\frac{G \gamma_{sea}+\mathrm{Se}_{\text {nat }} \times \gamma_{\text {sea }}}{1+e_{\text {nat }}}\right)\\ &=\left(\frac{2.67 \times 10.1043 +1 \times 0.8 \times 10.1043}{1+0.8}\right) \\ &=19.48 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total stress at the bottom of sand layer, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=20 \times \gamma_{\operatorname{sen}}+30 \times \gamma_{\text {sat}} \\ &=20 \times 10.1043+30 \times 19.48 \\ &=786.486 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Pore water pressure at the bottom of sand layer, [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=(20+30) \times 10.1043 \\ &=505.215 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Effective stress at the bottom of sand layer. [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma} &=\sigma-u=786.486 -505.215 \\ &=281.271 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 236 A field vane shear testing instrument (shown in figure) was inserted completely
into a deposit of soft, saturated silty clay with the vane rod vertical such that the
top of the blades were 500 mm below the ground surface. Upon application of a
rapidly increasing torque about the vane rod, the soil was found to fail when the
torque reached 4.6 Nm. Assuming mobilization of undrained shear strength on
all failure surfaces to be uniform and the resistance mobilized on the surface of
the vane rod to be neglibible, what would be the peak undrained shear strength
(rounded off to the nearest integer value of kPa) of the soil?
solution: When the top end of the vane completely shear the soil, Then the torque at failure is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} T&=c_{u} \pi\left(\frac{d^{\prime} h}{2}+\frac{d^{3}}{6}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \frac{4.6}{1000}&=c_{u} \times \pi \times\left(\frac{(0.05)^{2} \times 0.1}{2}+\frac{(0.05)^{3}}{6}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad c_{u}&=10 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 237 Identical surcharges are placed at ground surface at sites X and Y , with soil
conditions shown in figure and water table at ground surface. The silty clay
layers at X and Y are identical. The thin sand layer at Y is continuous and freedraining
with a very large discharge capacity. If primary consolidation at X is
estimated to complete in 36 months, what would be the corresponding time for
completion of primary consolidation at Y ?
solution: The time required for any degree of consolidation can be obtained from the Taylor's formula, [latex] T_{v}=\frac{C_{v} t}{d^{2}}[/latex] since C_{v} is constant for same type of soil and [latex]T_{v} [/latex] is constant for same degree of consolidation, [latex] t \propto d^{2} [/latex] where d is the length of drainage path. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}&=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{36}{t_{2}}&=\left(\frac{10}{10 / 2}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t_{2}&=\frac{36}{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t_{2}&=9 \;\text{months} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 238 A singly under-reamed, 8 m long, RCC pile (shown in the figure) weighing
20 kN with 350 mm shaft diameter and 750 mm under-ream diameter is installed
within stiff, saturated silty clay (undrained shear strength is 50 kPa, adhesion
factor is 0.3, and the applicable bearing capacity factor is 9) to counteract the
impact of soil swelling on a structure constructed above. Neglecting suction and
the contribution of the under-ream to the adhesive shaft capacity, what would be
the estimated ultimate tensile capacity (rounded off to the nearest integer value
of kN) of the pile?
solution: The tensile resistance of a pile is given as [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{t} &=Q_{s}+W+Q_{b} \\ \text{Where}\quad Q_{s} &=\text { shaft resistance }=\alpha c A_{s} \\ W &=\text { weight of pile } \\ Q_{1} &=c N_{c} A_{b} \\ \therefore \quad Q_{1} &=\alpha c A_{s}+W+c N_{c} A_{b} \\ &=0.3 \times 50 \times \pi \times 0.35 \times 8+20 \\ &+\frac{50 \times 9 \times \pi\left(0.75^{2}-0.35^{2}\right)}{4} \\ &=300.796 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 239 A soil is composed of solid spherical grains of identical specific gravity and diameter
between 0.075mm and 0.0075mm. If the terminal velocity of the largest particle
falling through water without flocculation is 0.5mm/s, that for the smallest
particle would be
solution: According to Stoke s law [latex] \begin{aligned} v&= D \\ \Rightarrow \frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}&=\left(\frac{D_{1}}{D_{2}}\right)^{2} \Rightarrow \frac{0.5}{v_{2}}=\left(\frac{0.075}{0.0075}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad v_{2}&=\frac{0.5}{100} \quad \Rightarrow \quad v_{2}=0.005 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 241 For a sample of dry, cohesionless soil with friction angle, [latex]\phi[/latex], the failure plane will be inclined to the major principal plane by an angle equal to
solution: Angle between major principal plane and failure plane is [latex]\theta_{1}[/latex] , from Mohr's circle [latex] \begin{array}{r} 2\theta_{1}=90^{\circ}+\phi \\ \theta_{1}=45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 242 Likelihood of general shear failure for an isolated footing in sand decreases with
solution:
General shear tailure is generally associated with dense sand. So if intergranular packing of sand decreases then sand will behave as loose sand.
Hence likelihood of general shear failure with decrease.

options.B: decreasing inter-granular packing of the sand

question:
Question 243 For a saturated sand deposit, the void ratio and the specific gravity of solids
are 0.70 and 2.67, respectively. The critical (upward) hydraulic gradient for the
deposit would be
solution:
Critical hydraulic gradient is given by [latex]
i_{c r}=\frac{G-1}{1+e}=\frac{2.67-1}{1+0.70}=0.98[/latex]

question:

given as FMP, FMQ and FMR, it can be stated that
solution:
The term fineness modulus is used to indicate an 
index number which roughly proportional to 
average size of particle in entire quantity of 
aggregate [latex]
 F_{M Q}=\sqrt{F_{M P} \times F_{M R}}[/latex] (Geometric mean)

question:
Question 245 The unconfined compressive strength of a saturated clay sample is 54kPa. If a squre footing of size 4m x 4m is resting on the surface of a deposit of the above
clay, the ultimate bearing capacity of the footing (as per Terzaghi's equation) is
solution: The ultimate bearing capacity of a square footing in clay as per Terzaghi's bearing capacity equation is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{\mathrm{ult}} &=1.3 \mathrm{cN}_{c}\left[\because N_{c} \text { for clay }=5.7\right] \\ &=1.3 \times 27 \times 5.7=200 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 246 The unconfined compressive strength of a saturated clay sample is 54kPa. The value of sobesion for the clay is
solution: [latex]\text { Cohesion of clay. } c=\frac{q_{l}}{2}=\frac{54}{2}=27 \mathrm{kP}[/latex]

question:
Question 247 The ultimate load capacity of a 10 m long concrete pile of square cross section
500mm x 500 mm driven into a homogeneous clay layer having undrained cohesion
value of 40 kPa is 700 kN. If the cross section of the pile is reduced to 250mm x 2500 mm
and the length of the pile is increased to 20 m, the ultimate load capacity will be
solution: The ultimate load of a pile in clay is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{u}=& c N A_{b}+\alpha c A_{s} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 700=& 40 \times 9 \times 0.5 \times 0.5+\alpha \times 40 \\ & \times 0.5 \times 4 \times 10 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \alpha&=0.7625 \\ \text { Again, } \quad Q_{u}=& 40 \times 9 \times 0.25 \times 0.25+0.7625 \times 40 \\ & \times 0.25 \times 4 \times 20 \\ Q_{u} &=632.5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 248 An open ended steel barrel of 1m height and 1m diameter is filled with saturated
fine sand having coefficient of permability of [latex]10^{-2}[/latex] m/s. The barrel stands on a saturated bed of gravel. The time required for the water level in the barrel to drop by 0.75m is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Time required } &=\frac{\text { Drop in water level }}{\text { Coefficient of permeability }} \\ &=\frac{0.75}{10^{-2}}=75 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 249 The vertical stress at point P1 due to the point load Q on the ground surface as
shown in figure is [latex]\sigma _{2}[/latex]. According to Boussinesq's equation, the vertical stress at point P2 shown in figure will be
solution: As per Boussinesq equation, the vertical stress [latex] \sigma_{2}[/latex] at a point located at a depth 'z' and a horizontal distance 'r' from the point of application of point load Q is [latex] \sigma_{z}=\frac{3 Q}{2 \pi z^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{r}{z}\right)^{2}}\right]^{5 / 2}[/latex] For a horizontal distance [latex]\frac{r}{2}[/latex] and a depth [latex]\frac{2}{2}[/latex], the stress will be [latex] =\frac{3 Q}{2 \pi\left(\frac{z}{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{r / 2}{2 / 2}\right)^{2}}\right]^{5 / 2}=4 \times \frac{3 Q}{2 \pi z^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{r}{z}\right)^{2}}\right)^{5 / 2} [/latex] [latex] =4 \sigma_{z}[/latex]

question: Question 250 If [latex]\sigma _{h}, \sigma_{v}, \sigma' _{h} \; and \; \sigma' _{v}[/latex] represent the total horizontal stress, total vertical stress, effective horizontal stress and effective vertical stress on a soil element, respectively, the coefficient of earth pressure at rest is given by
solution: Coefficient of earth pressure at rest is the ratio of intensity of earth pressure at rest to the vertical stress at a specified depth. [latex] K_{0}=\frac{\sigma_{h}}{\sigma_{v}}[/latex] But for a saturated soil, [latex]K_{0}=\frac{\alpha_{h}^{\prime}}{\sigma_{v}^{\prime}}[/latex]

question:
Question 253 A fine grained soil has liquid limit of 60 and plastic limit of 20. As per the
plasticity chart, according to IS classification, the soil is represented by the letter
symbols
solution:
Plasticity index. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
I_{p} &=w_{L}-w_{p} \\
&=60-20=40
\end{aligned}[/latex] Equation of A line is given by [latex]
\begin{aligned}
I_{p} &=0.73\left(w_{L}-20\right) \\
&=0.73(60-20) \\
&=292
\end{aligned}[/latex] Thus the given soil lies above the A-Line. The liquid 
limit of the soil is more than 50 , hence the soil will 
be CH.

question:
Question 254 In a compaction test, G, w, S and e represent the specific gravity, water content,
degree of saturation and void ratio of the soil sample, respectively. If [latex]\gamma _{w}[/latex] represents the unit weight of water and [latex]\gamma _{d}[/latex] represents the dry unit weight of the soil, the equation of zero air voids line is
solution: The bulk unit weight of soil is given by [latex] \gamma=\frac{(G+S e) \gamma_{w}}{1+e}[/latex] For dry unit weight, degree of saturation, [latex] S=0 \quad \therefore \gamma_{d}=\frac{G \gamma_{w}}{1+e}[/latex] But we know that [latex] G w=\text { Se } \quad \therefore \gamma_{d}=\frac{G \gamma_{w}}{1+\frac{G w}{S}}[/latex] For zero air voids, degree of saturation, [latex] S=100 \% \quad \therefore \gamma_{d}=\frac{G \gamma_{w}}{1+G w}[/latex]

question:
Question 255 Using the properties of the clay layer derived from the above question, the
consolidation settlement of the same clay layer under a square footing (neglecting
its self weight) with additional data shown in the figure below (assume the stress
distribution as 1H:2V from the edge of the footing and [latex]\gamma _{w}=10kN/m^{3}[/latex]) is
solution:
The consolidation settlement at the centre of clay layer is given by [latex] \Delta H=\frac{C_{c} H_{0}}{1+e_{0}} \log _{10}\left[\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right][/latex] Load distribution dimensions at the centre of clay layer [latex] =2+0.75+0.75=3.5 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Increase in stress due to load [latex] =\frac{200}{3.5 \times 3.5}=16.33 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Effective stress at the centre of clay layer [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(18-10) \times 2+(20.625-10) \times 0.5 \\ &=16+5.31=21.31 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\\therefore \Delta H &=\frac{0.4 \times 1}{1+0.6} \times \log _{10}\left[\frac{21.31+16.33}{21.31}\right] \\
&=0.06176 \mathrm{m}=61.67 \mathrm{mm}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 256 A saturated undisturbed sample from a clay strata has moisture content of 
22.22% and specific weight of 2.7. Assuming [latex]\gamma _{w}=10kN/m^{3}[/latex], the void ratio and the saturated unit weight of the clay, respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} S \times e&=G \times W \\ \Rightarrow 1 \times e&=\frac{2.7 \times 22.22}{100}[\because \text { soil is saturated }] \\ \Rightarrow e&=0.5999 \\ \Rightarrow e &\approx 0.6 \\ &\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \gamma_{\text {sat }}&=\left(\frac{G+e}{1+e}\right) \gamma_{w} \\ &=\left(\frac{2.7+0.6}{1+0.6}\right) \times 10 \\ &=20.625 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 257 Examine the test arrangement and the soil properties given below : The maximum resistance offered by the soil through skin friction while pulling
out the pile from the ground is
solution: Ultimate (maximum) skin friction resistance, [latex]Q_{1}[/latex] is given by [latex] Q_{1}=K \bar{\sigma}_{a v} A_{s} \tan \delta[/latex] where, K= lateral earth pressure coefficient [latex] =1.5[/latex] [latex] \bar{\sigma}_{\mathrm{av}}=[/latex] average effective overburden pressure over the embedded length of pile [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{\left(\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}}\right) \times L}{2}=\frac{(18-10) \times 5}{2} \\ =20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] A_{s}=[/latex] Surface area of pile in contact with soil [latex] \therefore \quad Q_{1}=1.5 \times 20 \times \pi \times 0.5 \times 5 \times \tan 24^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] =104.9 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question:
Question 258 Examine the test arrangement and the soil properties given below : The maximum pressure that can be applied with a factor of safety of 3 through
the concrete block, ensuring no bearing capacity failure in soil using Terzaghi's
bearing capacity equation without considering the shape factor, depth factor and
inclination factor is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma &=\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \\ &=8 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] without considering shape and depth factor, safe bearing capacity, [latex]\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{s}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{s} &=\frac{1}{F}\left[0.5 \gamma^{\prime} B N \gamma\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{3}[0.5 \times 8 \times 40] \\ &=53.34 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Nearest option is [latex]60 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question:
Question 259 A plate load test is carried out on a [latex]300mm\times 300mm[/latex] plate placed at 2 m below
the ground level to determine the bearing capacity of a [latex]2m\times 2m[/latex] footing placed
at same depth of 2 m on a homogeneous sand deposit extending 10 m below
ground. The ground water table is 3 m below the ground level. Which of the following factors does not require a correction to the bearing capacity determined based on the load test ?

options.A: Absence of the overburden pressure during the test
options.B: Size of the plate is much smaller than the footing size
options.C: Influence of the ground water table
options.D: Settlement is recorded only over a limited period of one or two days

question: Question 260 The laboratory test results of a soil sample are given below : Percentage finer than 4.75 mm= 60 Percentage finer than 0.075 mm= 30 Liquid Limit= 35% Plastic Limit27% The soil classification is
solution:
Percentage finer than 4.75mm = 60 Percentage finer then 0.075mm = 30 Liquid limit, [latex]w_L=35 %[/latex] Plastic limit, [latex]w_P=27 %[/latex] Plasticity Index, [latex]I_P=w_L-w_P=37-27=8 %[/latex] Fine grained soils are those having 50% or more pass through 75[latex]\mu[/latex] sieve (0.075
mm). It is designated as sand (S) if 50% or more pass through 4.75 mm sieve
otherwise designated as gravel (G). Since the percentage finer than 4.75 mm is 60%, it is designated as sand (S). Further,
percentage finer than 7575[latex]\mu[/latex] is 30 which is more than 12%, observe the liquid limit and
plastic limit on the plasticity chart. Plasticity index corresponding to A-line, [latex]I_P=0.73(w_L-20)=10.95[/latex] The point corresponding to [latex]w_L=35 %[/latex] and [latex]I_P=8 %[/latex] lies below A- line on the
 Plasticity chart. It is designated as M or O. Therefore, the soil is classified as SM.

question:
Question 261 A precast concrete pile is driven with a 50 kN hammer railing through a height of
1.0 m with an efficiency of 0.6. The set value observed is 4 mm per below and the
combined temporary compression of the pile, cushion and the ground is 6 mm. As
per Modified Hiley Formula, the ultimate resistance of the pile is
solution: Ultimate driving resistance as per modified Hiley's formula is given by [latex] R =\frac{w h \eta}{S+0.5 C}=\frac{50 \times 1 \times 0.6}{4 \times 10^{-3}+0.5 \times 6 \times 10^{-3}} =4285.7 \mathrm{kN} [/latex]

question: Question 264 A column is supported on a footing as shown in the figure below. The water table is at a depth of 10 m below the base of the footing. The safe load (kN) that the footing can carry with a factor of safety 3 is
solution: Using net ultimate bearing capacity as [latex] 630 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] [latex]\text{ Safe load} =\frac{630 \times 1.5 \times 3.0}{3}=945 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question: Question 265 A column is supported on a footing as shown in the figure below. The water table is at a depth of 10 m below the base of the footing. The net ultimate bearing capacity (kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) of the footing based on Terzaghi's bearing capacity equation is
Question 266 The ground conditions at a site are shown in the figure below. The total stress, pore water pressure and effective stress (kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) at the point P are, respectively
solution: Total stress, [latex] \sigma=\gamma_{\text {sat }} \times 5=21 \times 5=105 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Pore water pressure, [latex] \mathrm{u}=\gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \times 5=10 \times 5=50 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Effective stress, [latex] \bar{\sigma}=\sigma-u=105-50=55 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 267 The ground conditions at a site are shown in the figure below. The saturated unit weight of the sand (kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad e&=\frac{G w}{S} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e&=\frac{2.7 \times 0.2}{1} \Rightarrow e=0.54 \\ \therefore \quad \gamma_{\text {sat }}&=\left(\frac{G+e}{1+e}\right) \times \gamma_{w}=\left(\frac{2.7+0.54}{1+0.54}\right) \times 10 \\ &=21.04 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 268 A test plate [latex]30cm\times 30cm[/latex] resting on a sand deposit settles by 10 mm under a certain intensity. A footing [latex]150cm\times 200cm[/latex]
 resting on the same sand deposit
and loaded to the same load intensity settles by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} S_{p}&=S_{f}\left[\frac{B_{p}\left(B_{f}+0.3\right)}{B_{i}\left(B_{p}+0.3\right)}\right]^{2} \text { for sandy soils }\\ \Rightarrow \quad 10&=S_{i}\left[\frac{0.3(1.5+0.3)}{1.5(0.3+0.3)}\right]^{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad S_{1}&=\frac{10}{0.36} \Rightarrow S_{1}=27.8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 269 A saturated clay stratum draining both at the top and bottom undergoes 50 percent consolidation in 16 year under an applied load. If an additional drainage
layer were present at the middle of the clay stratum, 50 percent consolidation would occur in
solution: From Taylor's formula, we have [latex] T_{v}=\frac{C_{v} t}{d^{2}}[/latex] Here [latex]T_{v}[/latex] and [latex]C_{v}[/latex] are constant [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad t &\propto d^{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}&=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{16}{t_{2}}&=\left(\frac{H}{H / 2}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t_{2}&=\frac{16}{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t_{2}&=4 \text { years } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 270 A pile of 0.50 m diameter and of length 10 m is embedded in a deposit of clay.
The undrained strength parameters of the clay are cohesion = 60 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] and the angle of internal friction= 0. The skin friction capacity (kN) of the pile for an
adhesion factor of 0.6, is
solution: The skin friction capacity of a pile is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{f} &=\alpha c_{u} A_{s} \\ &=0.6 \times 60 \times \pi \times 0.50 \times 10 \\ &=565.48 \mathrm{kN}=565 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 271 A direct shear test was conducted on a cohesion less soil (c=0) specimen under a normal stress of 200 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The specimen failed at a shear stress of 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The angle of internal friction of the soil (degree) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} t&=c+\bar{\alpha} \tan \theta &\left[\because c=0 \right ]\\ \therefore \quad 100&=0+200 \tan \theta \\ \Rightarrow \quad \phi&=\tan ^{-1}(0.5) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \phi&=26.6^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 272 A footing [latex]2m\times 1m[/latex]
 exerts a uniform pressure of 150 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] on the soil. Assuming a load dispersion of 2 vertical to 1 horizontal, the average vertical stress (kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) at 1.0 m below the footing is
solution: Total dispersion area [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(2+0.5+0.5) \times(1+0.5+0.5) \\ &=3 \mathrm{m} \times 2 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 277 The ground conditions at a site are as shown in the figure. The water table at the
site which was initially at a depth of 5 m below the ground level got permanently
lowered to a depth of 15 m below the ground level due to pumping of water over
a few years. Assume the following data : I unit weight of water= 10 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] II unit weight of sand above water table= 18 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] III unit weight of sand and clay below the water table= 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] IV coefficient of volume compressibility= 0.25 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]/MN What is the compression of the clay layer in mm due to the lowering of the water table ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta H &=H_{0} m_{v} \Delta \sigma^{\prime} \\ &=\frac{5 \times 0.25}{10^{3}} \times 80=100 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 278 The ground conditions at a site are as shown in the figure. The water table at the
site which was initially at a depth of 5 m below the ground level got permanently
lowered to a depth of 15 m below the ground level due to pumping of water over
a few years. Assume the following data : I unit weight of water= 10 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] II unit weight of sand above water table= 18 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] III unit weight of sand and clay below the water table= 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] IV coefficient of volume compressibility= 0.25 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]/MN What is the change in the effective stress in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex] at mid-depth of the clay layer due to the lowering of the water table ?
solution: Initial total, pore and effective stresses at central layer are [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{c-c} &=5 \times 18+15 \times 20+2.5 \times 20 \\ &=440 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ u_{c-c} &=(15+2-5) \times 10=175 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)_{1}=& 265 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] After the drawdown of GWT, changes in total and pore pressure at central layer are as follows [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{c-c}&=15 \times 18+5 \times 20+2.5 \times 20 \\ &=420 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} & \\ &\begin{aligned} u_{c-c}&=7.5 \times 10=75 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ (\sigma)_{2}&=345 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \Delta \sigma^{\prime}&=345-265 \\ \Delta \sigma^{\prime}&=80 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 279 Water is flowing through the permeability apparatus shown in the figure. The coefficient of permeability of the soil is k m/s and the porosity of the soil sample
is 0.50. What are the discharge velocity and seepage velocity through the soil sample ?
solution:
Seepage velocity [latex]\left(v_{s}\right)=\frac{v}{n}=\frac{v}{0.5}=2 v [/latex] [porosity n=0.5] as per Darcy's law, v=ki as [latex]\quad i=1[/latex] [latex]
v=k \; m / s[/latex] Discharge velocity =k Seepage velocity =2k

question:
Question 280 Water is flowing through the permeability apparatus shown in the figure. The coefficient of permeability of the soil is k m/s and the porosity of the soil sample
is 0.50. The total head, elevation head and pressure head in metres of water at the point R shown in the figure are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{where,}\\ \mathrm{DH}&=\text { Datum head }\\ \mathrm{PH}&=\text{ Pressure head}\\ \mathrm{TH}&=\text{ Total head}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Loss of head in soil in soil length between B and C [latex] (h)=1.6-0.4=1.2 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Hydraulic gradient (i) [latex]=\frac{h}{z}=\frac{1.2}{1.2}=1 [/latex] Total head at R=h-i z [latex] =1.6-1 \times 0.8=0.8 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Datum head =0.4m (from above figure) [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Pressure head = total head - Datum head =0.8-0.4=0.4m

question:
Question 281 What is the ultimate capacity in kN of the pile group shown in the figure assuming
the group to fail as a single block ?
solution: The ultimate load capacity of the pile group by block failure, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{u g}=& c_{u} N_{c} A_{b}+P_{b} L c_{u} \\ =& 40 \times 9 \times(1.2+0.4)^{2}+4 \\ & \times(1.2+0.4) \times 10 \times 40 \\ =& 3481.6 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 282 The bearing capacity of a rectangular footing of plan dimensions 1.5m x 3m resting on the surface of a sand deposit was estimated as 600 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] when the water table is far below the base of the footing. The bearing capacities in kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] when the water level rises to depths of 3 m, 1.5 m and 0.5 m below the base of the footing are
solution:
The bearing capacity of the sand deposit will 
remain same until the water table rises to a depth 
less than the width of the footing. 
Thus, when water table is 3.0 below footing, the 
bearing capacity is [latex]600 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]; similarly when 
water table is 1.5m below footing, the bearing 
capacity remaining same i.e. [latex]600 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. But when 
the water table rises to a depth of 0.5m below the 
footing, the sand deposit will be saturated for a 
depth of 1.5-0.5=1m. Thus, the bearing capacity 
below the base of footing will decrease due to 
submergence of soil (1m).

question: Question 283 Match the following groups

Question 284 The factor of safety of an infinite soil slope shown in the figure having the properties c=0, [latex]\phi =35^{\circ},\; \gamma _{dry}=16kN/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma _{sat}=20kN/m^{3}[/latex] is approximately equal to
solution: Factor of safety. [latex] F=\left[1-\frac{\gamma_{w} h}{\gamma_{air} z}\right] \frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta}[/latex] Assuming. [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma_{w} &=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \therefore\quad F &=\left[1-\frac{10 \times 8}{20 \times 10}\right] \frac{\tan 35^{\circ}}{\tan 30^{\circ}} \\ &=0.73 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 285 The water content of a saturated soil and the specific gravity of soil solids were
found to be 30% and 2.70, respectively. Assuming the unit weight of water to be
10 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], the saturated unit weight kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and the void ratio of the soil are
solution: We know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} S \times e&=G \times w \\ \Rightarrow\quad 1 \times e&=2.70 \times 0.30 \\ \Rightarrow\quad e&=0.81 \\ \text{and }\quad \gamma_{\text {sat }}&=\left(\frac{G+e}{1+e}\right) \gamma_{w} \\ &=\left(\frac{2.7+0.81}{1+0.81}\right) \times 10 \\ &=19.4 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 286 Sieve analysis on a dry soil sample of mass 1000 g showed that 980 g and 270 g of
soil pass through 4.75 mm and 0.075 mm sieve, respectively. The liquid limit and
plastic limits of the soil fraction passing through 425[latex]\mu[/latex] sieves are 40% and 18%,
respectively. The soil may be classified as
solution:
% retained on [latex]4.75 \mathrm{mm}=\frac{20}{1000} \times 100=2 \% [/latex] % passing [latex]75 \mu[/latex] sieve [latex]=\frac{270}{1000} \times 100=27 \%  [/latex] [latex]
\therefore \quad \gt 50 \%[/latex] of coarse fraction is between 4.75 mm and [latex]75 \mu [/latex] Hence, sandy soil and % fines [latex]\gt[/latex] 12% Soil is clayey sand (SC).

question:
Question 287 The vertical stress at some depth below the corner of a 2m x 3m rectangular footing due to a certain load intensity is 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. What will be the vertical
stress in kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] below the centre of a 4m x 6m rectangular footing at the same depth and same load intensity ?
solution: For same load intensity and same depth [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{2}}&=\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{100}{\sigma_{2}}=\frac{2 \times 3}{4 \times 6} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{2}&=400 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 288 The number of blows observed in a Standard Penetration Test (SPT) for different
penetration depths are given as follows : The observed N value is
solution:
The number of blows for the first 150mm 
penetration of the sampler are disregarded. The 
number of blows for the next 300 mm penetration 
are recorded as the observed N value. Observed N value =8+10=18

question:
Question 289 A clay soil sample is tested in a triaxial apparatus in consolidated-drained conditions at a cell pressure of 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. What will be the pore water pressure
at a deviator stress of 40 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] ?
solution: In the consolidated drained test, the soil sample is first consolidated under an appropriate cell pressure. With the cell pressure kept at the same value, the soil sample is then sheared by applying the deviator stress so slowly that excess pore Water pressure does not develop during the test. Thus, at any stage of the test, the total stresses are the effective stresses.

question:
Question 290 The average effective overburden pressure on 10 m thick homogeneous saturated clay layer is 150 kPa. Consolidation test on an undisturbed soil sample taken from
the clay layer showed that the void ratio decreased from 0.6 to 0.5 by increased
the stress intensity from 100 kPa to 300 kPa. (G=2.65) The total consolidation settlement of the clay layer due to the construction of a
structure imposing an additional stress intensity of 200 kPa is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta H &=\frac{C_{c} H_{0}}{1+e_{0}} \log _{10}\left[\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \bar{\sigma}}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right] \\ &=\left(\frac{0.2096 \times 10}{1+0.563}\right) \log _{10}\left[\frac{150+200}{150}\right] \\ &=0.493 \mathrm{m} \approx 0.5 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 291 The average effective overburden pressure on 10 m thick homogeneous saturated clay layer is 150 kPa. Consolidation test on an undisturbed soil sample taken from
the clay layer showed that the void ratio decreased from 0.6 to 0.5 by increased
the stress intensity from 100 kPa to 300 kPa. (G=2.65) The initial void ratio of the clay layer is
solution: Coefficient of compression, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{c} &=\frac{e_{1}-e_{2}}{\log _{10}\left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{2}}{\bar{\sigma}_{1}}\right)} \\ &=\frac{0.6-0.5}{\log _{10}\left(\frac{300}{100}\right)}=0.2096\\ \text{also }\quad C_{c}&=\frac{e_{1}-e_{0}}{\log _{10}\left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}{\bar{\sigma}_{1}}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.2096&=\frac{0.6-e_{0}}{\log _{10}\left(\frac{150}{100}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e_{0}&=0.563 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 292 Laboratory sieve analysis was carried out on a soil sample using a complete set
of standard IS sieves. Out of 500g of soil used in the test, 200g was retained on 
[latex]IS \; 600\mu[/latex] sieve, 250g was retained on [latex] IS \; 500\mu[/latex] sieve and the remaining 50g was
retained on [latex]IS \; 425\mu[/latex] sieve. The classification of the soil is
solution:
More than 50% of the soil pass through [latex]600 \mu [/latex] sieve 
which means that even a greater percentage of 
the soil passes through 4.75 mm sieve. Hence, the soil is definitely sandy soil. Also, we 
know that for a sand to be considered well graded [latex]
\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{u}}[/latex] should be greater than 6 Here, in this case [latex]
C_{u}=1.2.[/latex] Thus, the soil is poorly graded sand.

question:
Question 293 Laboratory sieve analysis was carried out on a soil sample using a complete set
of standard IS sieves. Out of 500g of soil used in the test, 200g was retained on 
[latex]IS \; 600\mu[/latex] sieve, 250g was retained on [latex] IS \; 500\mu[/latex] sieve and the remaining 50g was
retained on [latex]IS \; 425\mu[/latex] sieve. The coefficient of uniformity of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D_{60}&=600 \mu \\ D_{10}&=500 \mu \end{aligned}[/latex] Now uniformity coefficient [latex] C_{u}=\frac{D_{60}}{D_{10}}=\frac{600 \mu}{500 \mu}=1.2[/latex]

question:
Question 294 A sample of saturated cohensionless soil tested in a drained triaxial compression
test showed an angle of internal friction of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex]. The deviatoric stress at failure for the sample at a confining pressure of 200 kPa is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{1} &=\sigma_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{9}{2}\right)+2 \mathrm{c} \tan \left(45+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \sigma_{1} &=200 \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{30}{2}\right)+2 \times 0 \times \tan \left(45+\frac{30}{2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \sigma_{1} &=600 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Deviatoric stress at failure [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}=600-200 \\ &=400 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 295 In a standard proctor test, 1.8 kg of moist soil was filling the mould (volume
= 94.4cc) after compaction. A soil sample weighing 23 g was taken from the
mould and ovendried for 24 hours at a temperature of 110[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Weight of the
dry sample was found to be 20 g. Specific gravity of soil solids is G = 2.7. The
theoretical maximum value of the dry unit weight of the soil at that water content
is equal to
solution: Bulk density of the soil [latex] =\frac{1.8 \times 1000}{944}=1.907 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{cc}[/latex] Water content of soil [latex] =\left(\frac{23-20}{20}\right) \times 100=15 \%[/latex] For, theoretical maximum dry unit weight, degree of saturation should be 100 %. [latex] \begin{aligned} S e &=G w \\ \Rightarrow \quad e &=\frac{2.7 \times 0.15}{1} \Rightarrow e=0.405 \end{aligned}[/latex] The theoretical maximum dry unit weight may be given as [latex] \gamma_{d, \max }=\frac{G \gamma_{w}}{1+e}=\frac{2.7 \times 9.81}{1+0.405}=18.85 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]

question:
Question 296 For the soil profile shown in Figure below, the minimum number of precast
concrete piles of 300 mm diameter required of safely carry the load for a given
factor of safety of 2.5 (assuming 100% efficiency for the pile group) is equal to
solution: The ultimate load capacity of piles [latex] =2.5 \times 5000=12,500 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] The load capacity of single pile [latex] \begin{aligned} =& c_{u} N_{c} A_{b}+\alpha \bar{c}_{u} A_{s} \\ =& 150 \times 9 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.3)^{2}+0.57 \times 100 \\ & \times 10 \times 0.3 \pi \\ =& 632.64 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] Number of piles [latex] =\frac{12500}{632.64}=19.75 \approx 20[/latex]

question:
Question 297 List-I below gives the possible types of failure for a finite soil slope and List-II
gives the reasons for these different types of failure. Match the items in List-I
with the items in List-II
solution: Face failure or slope failure can occur when the Slope angle [latex] \beta [/latex] is very high and the soil close to the toe is quite strong or the soil in the upper part of slope is relatively weak. Base failure can occur when the soil below the toe is relatively weak and soft and the slope is flat. Toe failure occurs in steep slopes when the soil mass above the base and below the base is homogeneous.

question:
Question 298 To provide safety against piping failure, with a factor of safety of 5, what should
be the maximum permissible exit gradient for soil with specific gravity of 2.5 and
porosity of 0.35 ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{c r} &=\frac{G-1}{1+e}=(G-1)(1-n) \\ &=(2.5-1)(1-0.35)=0.975 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Maximum permissible exit gradient. [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{i_{cr}}{\text { Factor of safety }}\\ &=\frac{0.975}{5}=0.195 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 299 Which of the following statement is NOT TRUE in the context of capillary pressure in solids ?
solution:
Capillary rise is more in fine grained soils and as
a result of this, the capillary pressure is also more
than the coarse grained soils.

options.A: Water is under tension in capillary zone
options.B: Pore water pressure is negative in capillary zone
options.C: Effective stress increases due to the capillary zone
options.D: Capillary pressure is more in coarse grained soils

question:
Question 300 Figure given below shows a smooth vertical gravity retaining wall with cohesionless soil backfill having an angle of internal friction [latex]\phi[/latex]. In the graphical representation
of Rankine's active earth pressure for the retaining wall shown in figure, length OP represents
solution:
[latex]\begin{array}{l} O P=\text {Major stress}=\sigma_{1} \\ O Q=\text {Mirror stress}=\sigma_{3} \end{array}[/latex] Active condition: OP = Vertical stress at base [latex]
=\sigma_{v} \cos \beta=\gamma+\cos \beta[/latex] OQ = Lateral earth pressure at base [latex]
=\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \cdot \sigma_{\mathrm{v}} \cos \beta[/latex] Note: QR and QR' are failure plane for active case.

options.B: vertical stress at a height H/3 from the base
options.C: lateral earth pressure at the base
options.D: lateral earth pressure at a height H/3 from the base

question:
Question 301 The range of void ratio between which quick sand condition occurs in cohesionless
granular soil deposits is
solution:
The specific gravity of cohesionless granular soils 
(sands) does not vary much and for all practical 
purposes it is taken to be 2.65. Critical hydraulic 
gradient should be nearly 1 for quick sand condition. [latex]
i.e.\quad i_{cr}=\frac{G-1}{1+e} [/latex] From the above equation, the void ratio range is 
found to be between 0.6 and 0.7.

question:
Question 302 A 3 m high retaining wall is supporting a saturated sand (saturated due to
capillary action) of bulk density 18 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] and angle of shearing resistance 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The change in magnitude of active earth pressure at the base due to rise in ground water table from the base of the footing to the ground surface shall ([latex]\gamma _{w}=10 kN/m^{3}[/latex])
solution:
When the water tabel is at the base of footing the active earth pressure will be [latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{1} &=K_{a} \gamma R=\left(\frac{1-\sin \phi}{1+\sin \phi}\right) \times \gamma \times z \\
&=\frac{1-\sin 30^{\circ}}{1+\sin 30^{\circ}} \times 18 \times 3 \\
&=1 / 3 \times 18 \times 3=18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
\end{aligned}[/latex] When the water table rises upto the surface, the 
thrust due to water will also be added to the active 
earth pressure. [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{2} &=K_{2} \gamma z+\gamma_{w} z \\ &=\frac{1}{3} \times(18-10) \times 3+10 \times 3 \\ &=8+30=38 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] change in active earth pressure [latex] \begin{array}{l} =P_{2}-P_{1}=38-18 \\ =20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}(\text { increase }) \end{array}[/latex] Note: In strict terms [latex]\gamma_{\text {sat }}[/latex] should be taker

question:
Question 303 A strip footing (8 m wide) is designed for a total settlement of 40 mm. The safe
bearing capacity (shear) was 150 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] and safe allowable soil pressure was 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. Due to important of the structure, now the footing is to be redesigned for total settlement of 25 mm. The new width of the footing will be
solution:
Load per metre length of footing [latex] P=B \times [/latex]{ Minimum of bearing capacity and allowable soil pressure} [latex] \begin{array}{l} =8 \times \text { Minimum of }[150,100] \\ =8 \times 100=800 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] Allowable pressure for 25mm settlement [latex] =\frac{100 \times 25}{40}=62.5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Load resisted = Width x Allowable pressure [latex]
 \begin{array}{rr} & 800=B \times 62.5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & B=12.8 \mathrm{m}\end{array} [/latex]

question:
Question 304 For two infinite slopes (one in dry condition and other in submerged condition)
in a sand deposit having the angle of shearing resistance 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], factor of safety was determined as 1.5 (for both slopes). The slope angles would have been
solution: For dry or submerged slopes, Factor of safety [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \beta &=\frac{\tan 30^{\circ}}{1.5} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & \beta=21.05^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: 21.05[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for dry slope and 21.05[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for submerged slope
options.B: 19.47[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for dry slope and 18.40[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for submerged slope
options.C: 18.4[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for dry slope and 21.05[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for submerged slope
options.D: 22.6[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for dry slope and 19.47[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] for submerged slope

question:
Question 305 During the subsurface investigations for design of foundations, a standard
penetration test was conducted at 4.5 m below the ground surface. The record of
number of blow is given below. Assuming the water table at ground level, soil as fine sand and correction factor for overburden as 1.0, the corrected 'N' value for the soil would be
solution: The number of blows required for the first 150mm of penetration is disregarded, and only the number of blows required for the last 300 mm of penetration is added together. [latex] \therefore [/latex] Number of blows, [latex] N^{\prime}=6+6+8+7=27[/latex] (i) Correction for overburden pressure Corrected value of observed [latex] N^{\prime}=C_{N} N^{\prime}=1.0 \times 27=27[/latex] (ii) Correction for dilatancy It is to be applied when number of blows obtained after overburden correction exceeds 15 in saturated fine sands and silts. [latex] \therefore N=15+0.5(27-15)[/latex] [latex] =15+6=21[/latex]

question:
Question 306 For a tri-axial shear test conducted on a sand specimen at a confining pressure
of 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] under drained conditions, resulted in a deviator stress ([latex]\sigma_{1} - \sigma _{3}[/latex]) at failure of 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The angle of shearing resistance of the soil would be
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{1}}&=\frac{1+\sin \theta}{1-\sin \theta} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta&=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{3}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \phi&=\frac{100}{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{3}+\sigma_{3}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \phi&=\frac{100}{\left(\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}\right)+2 \sigma_{3}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta &=\frac{100}{100+2 \times 100} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \theta &=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad &=19.47^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 307 Assuming that a river bed level does not change and the depth of water in river
was 10 m, 15 m and 8 m during the months of February, July and December
respectively of a particular year. The average bulk density of the soil is 20 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The density of water is 10 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The effective stress at a depth of 10 m below the river bed during these months would be
solution:
Since the river bed level does not change and the 
depth of water is changing only above the river 
bed, the effective stress below the river bed will 
not change. Total stress at a depth of 10 m below river bed, [latex]
\sigma=20 \times 10=200 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Pore water pressure, [latex]
u=10 \times 10=100 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] [latex]
 \therefore[/latex] Effective stress, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma} &=\sigma-u=200-100 \\
&=100 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
\end{aligned}[/latex] Thus effective stress will be [latex]100 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] each in the month of February, July and December

options.A: 300 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in February, 350 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] July and 320 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in December
options.B: 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in February, 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] July and 100 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in December
options.C: 200 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in February, 250 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] July and 180 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in December
options.D: 300 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in February, 350 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] July and 280 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] in December

question: Question 308 In a constant head permeameter with cross section area of 10 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex], when the flow was taking place under a hydraulic gradient of 0.5, the amount of water collected in 60 seconds is 600 cc. The permeability of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=k \mathrm{i} A \quad \Rightarrow \quad k=\frac{Q}{i A}=\frac{600 / 60}{0.5 \times 10} \\ &=2.0 \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 309 A saturated soil mass has a total density 22 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and a water content of 10%. The bulk density and dry density of this soil are
solution: Total density is bulk density, [latex] \gamma_{t}=22 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Dry density, } \gamma_{d} &=\frac{\gamma_{1}}{1+w}=\frac{22}{1+\frac{10}{100}}=\frac{22}{1.1} \\ &=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 310 A soil mass contains 40% gravel, 50% sand and 10% silt. This soil can be classified as

options.A: silty sandy gravel having coefficient of uniformly less than 60.
options.B: silty gravelly sand having coefficient of uniformly equal to 10.
options.C: gravelly silty sand having coefficient of uniformly greater than 60.
options.D: gravelly silty sand and its coefficient of uniformity cannot be determined.

question:
Question 311 There are two footings resting on the grounds surface. One footing is square of
dimension 'B'. The other is strip footing of width 'B'. Both of them are subjected
to a loading intensity of q . The pressure intensity at any depth below the base of
the footing along the centre line would be
solution:
L/b for square footing =1.0 L/b for strip footing [latex]\rightarrow \infty [/latex] The stress along the centre line, [latex] \sigma_{z}=q I [/latex] where I is called influence value [latex]
\therefore \mathrm{I}_{\text {strip }}>\mathrm{I}_{\text {square }} [/latex] Therefore, the pressure intensity at any depth 
below the base of the footing along the centre line 
would be large for strip footing and small for square 
footing.

options.B: large for square footing and small for strip footing
options.C: large for strip footing and small for square footing
options.D: more for strip footing at shallow depth ([latex]\leq[/latex]B) and more for square footing at large depth ([latex]\gt[/latex]B)

question: Question 312 Negative skin friction in a soil is considered when the pile is constructed through
solution: Negative skin friction is experienced when the soil around the pile settles at a faster rate than pile. Thus, piles installed in freshly prepared fills of soft compressive deposits are subject to a downward drag. This downward drag on the pile surface, where the soil moves down relative to the pile, adds to the structural loads and is called negative skin friction.

obtained the dry density 15.2 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and water content 11%. This construction is acceptable because

The density is less than the maximum dry density and water content is on
dry side of optimum
