options.C: The compaction is done on the dry side of the optimum
options.D:
Both the dry density and water content of the compacted soil are within the
desirable limits

question:
Question 315 A group of 16 piles of 10 m length and 0.5 m diameter is installed in a 10 m thick
stiff clay layer underlain by rock. The pile-soil adhesion factor is 0.4; average
shear strength of soil on the sides is 100 kPa; undrained shear strength of the soil
at the base is also 100 kPa. Assuming 100% efficiency, the group side resistance is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{Q_{u g}}{n Q_{u}} \;\;\;\;\;[\because \eta=100 \%] \\ Q_{u g} &=n Q_{u}=n \times \alpha c_{u} P L_{c} \\ &=16 \times 0.4 \times 100 \times \pi \times 0.5 \times 10 \\ &=10053.1 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 316 A group of 16 piles of 10 m length and 0.5 m diameter is installed in a 10 m thick
stiff clay layer underlain by rock. The pile-soil adhesion factor is 0.4; average
shear strength of soil on the sides is 100 kPa; undrained shear strength of the soil
at the base is also 100 kPa. The base resistance of a single pile is
solution: Base resistance of a single pile [latex] \begin{aligned} &=9 c_{u} A_{b}\\ \text{where}\quad c_{u}&=100 k N / m^{2} \\ A_{b}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.5)^{2}\\ \therefore \quad \text{Base resistance}\\ &=9 \times 100 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.5)^{2} \\ &=176.71 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 317 A retaining wall of height 8 m retains dry sand. In the initial state, the soil is
loose and has a void ratio of 0.5, [latex]\gamma _{d}=17.8 kN/m^{3} \; and \; \phi =30^{\circ}[/latex]. Subsequently, the backfill is compacted to a state where void ratio is 0.4, [latex]\gamma _{d}=18.8 kN/m^{3} \; and \; \phi =35^{\circ}[/latex]. The ratio of initial passive thrust to the final passive thrust, according
to Rankine's earth pressure theory, is
solution: Passive earth pressure for loose sand is [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{p} &=\frac{1+\sin \phi}{1-\sin \phi}=\frac{1+\sin 30^{\circ}}{1-\sin 30^{\circ}}=3 \\ \text { Now } P_{P_{1}} &=\frac{1}{2} K_{P} \gamma H^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 3 \times 17.8 \times 8^{2} \\ &=1708.8 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Passive earth pressure for compacted sand is [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{P}&=\frac{1+\sin \phi}{1-\sin \phi}=\frac{1+\sin 35^{\circ}}{1-\sin 35^{\circ}}=3.69\\ \text { Now } P_{B} &=\frac{1}{2} K_{p} \gamma H^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 3.69 \times 18.8 \times 8^{2} \\ &=2219.90 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ratio of [latex]P_{P_{1}}[/latex] and [latex]P_{P_{2}}=\frac{1708.8}{2219.90}=0.77[/latex]

question:
Question 318 An unsupported excavation is made to the maximum possible depth in a clay
soil having [latex]\gamma _{t}=18 kN/m^{3}[/latex], [latex]c=100 kN/m^{2}[/latex], [latex]\phi =30^{\circ}[/latex]. The active earth pressure, according to Rankine's theory, at the base level of the excavation is
solution: The excavation is unsupported which means the maximum possible depth upto which the clay soil can be excavated is [latex]2Z_{\mathrm{c}}[/latex]. The active earth pressure at this depth is [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{A} &=2 c \sqrt{K_{A}} \quad\left[\because K_{A}=\frac{1-\sin \phi}{1+\sin \phi}\right] \\ &=2 \times 100 \times \sqrt{\frac{1-\sin 30^{\circ}}{1+\sin 30^{\circ}}} \\ &=115.47 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively: [latex] Z_{c}=\frac{2 c}{\gamma \sqrt{K_{A}}} \Rightarrow 2 Z_{c}=\frac{4 c}{\gamma \sqrt{K_{A}}}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Active pressure at a depth, [latex]2Z_{c}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\gamma_{1} \times 2 Z_{c} \times K_{A}-2 c \sqrt{K_{A}} \\ =18 \times \frac{4 \times 100 \times \sqrt{3}}{18} \times \frac{1}{3} \\ \quad-2 \times 100 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ =230.94-115.47=115.47 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 319 The figure below shows two flow lines for seepage across an interface between two
soil media of different coefficients of permeability. If entrance angle [latex]\alpha _{1}=30^{\circ}[/latex], the exit angle [latex]\alpha _{2}[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{k_{1}}{k_{2}}&=\frac{\tan \alpha_{1}}{\tan \alpha_{2}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1.0 \times 10^{-7}}{4.0 \times 10^{-7}}&=\frac{\tan 30^{\circ}}{\tan \alpha_{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad \tan \alpha_{2}&=2.309 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \alpha_{2}&=66.59^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 320 In the context of collecting undisturbed soil samples of high quality using a spoon
sampler, following statements are made : I. Area ratio should be less than 10% II. Clearance ratio should be less than 1% With reference to above statements, which of the following applies ?
solution: Area ratio should be less than 10 % for a undisturbed sample. But in case of collecting a sample using split spoon sampler the area ratio is as high as 30%. So it is impossible to get a undisturbed sample with the help of a split spoon sampler. Also, the clearance ratio should be from 1 to 3 per cent.

options.B: Statements II is true but I is false
options.C: Statement I is true but II is false

question: Question 321 Using [latex]\phi _{u}=0[/latex] analysis and assuming planar failure as shown, the minimum factor of safety against shear failure of a vertical cut of height 4 m in a pure clay having [latex]c_{u}=120 kN/m^{2}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma _{sat}=20 kN/m^{3}[/latex] is
solution: The maximum height of unsupported cut [latex] =\frac{4 c}{\gamma \sqrt{K_{A}}}[/latex] For [latex]\phi_{u}=0 ; K_{A}=\frac{1-\sin 0^{\circ}}{1+\sin 0^{\circ}}=1.0[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum height of unsupported cu [latex] =\frac{4 \times 120}{20}=24 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Actual height of cut =4m Factor of safety [latex]=\frac{24}{4}=6[/latex]

question:
Question 322 A 6 m thick clay layer undergoes 90% consolidation four times faster under two-way
drainage as compared to one-way drainage. In an identical clay layer of 15
m thickness, two-way drainage will be faster as compared to one-way drainage by
solution:
The time required for any degree of consolidation, 
can be obtained from the Taylor's formula [latex]
T_{v}=\frac{C_{v} t}{d^{2}}[/latex] Now, [latex]C_{v}[/latex] is constant for same type of soils, [latex]T_{v}[/latex] will 
also remain constant for same degree of 
consolidation. Thus, t \propto d^{2} where d is length of 
drainage path. Hence, in the clay layer of 15m thickness, two 
way drainage will be four times faster in 
comparison to one way drainage.

question: Question 323 An infinite soil slope with an inclination of [latex]35^{\circ}[/latex] is subjected to seepage parallel to its surface. The soil has [latex]c'=100 kN/m^{2} \; and \; {\phi}' =35^{\circ}[/latex]. Using the concept of mobilized cohesion and friction, at a factor of safety of 1.5 with respect of shear strength, the mobilized friction angle is
solution: The factor of safety with respect to shear strength is given by [latex] F_{5}=\frac{\tau_{1}}{\tau}=\frac{c^{\prime}+\sigma_{n}^{\prime} \tan \phi^{\prime}}{\tau}[/latex] The shear strength mobilised, thus may be written as [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{C^{\prime}}{F_{s}}+\sigma_{n}^{\prime} \frac{\tan \phi^{\prime}}{F_{s}} \\ &=c_{m}+\sigma_{n}^{\prime} \tan \phi_{m}^{\prime}\\ \therefore \tan \phi_{m}^{\prime}&=\frac{\tan \phi^{\prime}}{F_{s}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \phi_{m}^{\prime}&=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\tan 35^{\circ}}{1.5}\right)=21.05^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 324 The figure given below represents the contact pressure distribution underneath a
Question 325 The undrained cohesion of a remoulded clay soil is 10 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. If the sensitivity of the clay is 20, the corresponding remoulded compressive strength is

Question 326 A unit volume of a mass of saturated soil is subjected to horizontal seepage.
The saturated unit weight is 22 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and the hydraulic gradient is 0.3. The resultant body force on the soil mass is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Volume of soil }=1 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \qquad \gamma_{\text {sat }}=22 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{array}[/latex] Hydraulic gradient =i=0.3 [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{\text {horizontal }} &=i{\gamma}_{w} \cdot \text { volume } \\ &=0.3 \times 9.81 \times 1 \\ &=2.943 \mathrm{kN}\\ F_{\text {verical }} &=\gamma \cdot \text { volume } \\ &=(22-9.81) \times 1 \\ &=12.19 \mathrm{kN} \\ F_{\text {resultant }} &=\sqrt{F_{n}^{2}+F_{v}^{2}} \\ &=12.54 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 327 Two circular footings of diameters [latex]D_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]D_{2}[/latex] are resting on the surface of the
same purely cohesive soil. The ratio of their gross ultimate bearing capacities is
solution:
We know that [latex]a_{u}=1.3 \mathrm{cN}_{\mathrm{c}}+\mathrm{qN}_{\mathrm{q}}+0.3 \gamma \mathrm{DN}_{\mathrm{y}} [/latex] where D is the diameter of the circular footing Now, for purely cohesive soils, [latex]\phi=0 [/latex] [latex]
 N_{c}=5.7, N_{q}=1, N_{\gamma}=0 [/latex] Therefore, the gross ultimate bearing capacity of 
a footing (of any shape) resting on the surface of 
a purely cohesive clay is constant irrespective of 
its size. Thus, the ratio of gross ultimate bearing 
capacities of the two circular footings will be 1.0.

question: Question 328 In an undrained triaxial test on a saturated clay, the Poisson's ratio is
solution: In undrained triaxial test on saturated clay, the volume change due to confining pressure is zere [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \varepsilon_{3}&=0 \\ \frac{\sigma_{3}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{1}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{2}}{E} &=0 \\ \mu &=\frac{\sigma_{3}}{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 329 A 10 m thick clay layer is underlain by a sand layer of 20 m depth (see figure
below). The water table is 5 m below the surface of clay layer. The soil above the
water table is capillary saturated. The value of [latex]\gamma _{sat}[/latex] is 19 kN/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The unit weight of water is [latex]\gamma _{w}[/latex]. If now the water table rises to the surface, the effective stress at point P on the interface will
solution: In first case, when the water table is 5m below the surface and the clay over water table is capillary saturated, the effective stress is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{1} &=\gamma_{\text {sat }} \times 5+\gamma \times 5 \\ &=\gamma_{\text {sat }} \times 5+\left(\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}}\right) \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \bar{\sigma}_{1} &=10 \gamma_{\text {sat }}-5 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \; \; \; \ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] In the second case, when water table rises to the surface, the effective stress is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{2} &=\gamma \times 10=\left(\gamma_{\text {sat }}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}}\right) \times 10 \\ &=10 \gamma_{\text {sat }}-10 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \\ &=\left(10 \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}-5 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}\right)-5 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \quad[\because \text { from (i) }) \\ \Rightarrow \bar{\sigma}_{2} &=\bar{\sigma}_{1}-5 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus in second case, the effective stress at the interface will decrease by [latex]5 \gamma_{\mathrm{w}}[/latex].

question: Question 330 The ratio of saturated unit weight to dry unit weight of soil is 1.25. If the specific gravity of solids ([latex]G_{s}[/latex]) is 2.65, the void ratio of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma_{\text {Sat }} &=\left(\frac{G+e}{1+e}\right) \gamma_{w} &\dots(i)\\ \gamma_{d} &=\frac{G \gamma_{w}}{1+e} &\dots(ii)\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\gamma_{\text {sat }}}{\gamma_{d}} &=\frac{G+e}{G} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.25 &=\frac{2.65+e}{2.65} \\ e &=0.663 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 331 Figure shows the geometry of a strip footing supporting the load bearing walls of
a three storied building and the properties of clay layer. If the elastic modulus and the Poisson's ratio of the clay layer are respectively
[latex]50 \times 10^{3}[/latex] kPa and 0.4 and if the influence factor for the strip footing is 1.75, the elastic settlement of the footing will be
solution: Elastic settlement is given by [latex] S_{i}=q B\left(\frac{1-\mu^{2}}{E}\right) I_{t}[/latex] where [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad S_{1} &=40 \times 1.2 \times\left[\frac{1-(0.4)^{2}}{50 \times 10^{3}}\right] \times 1.75 \\ &=1.41 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 332 Figure shows the geometry of a strip footing supporting the load bearing walls of
a three storied building and the properties of clay layer. If the pressure acting on the footing is 40 kPa, the consolidation settlement of the
footing will be
solution: Initial effective stress at the centre of compressible clay layer, [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma} &=18 \times 1+3 \times(20-9.81) \\ &=48.57 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] (Assuming load dispersion as 2V: 1H) Width of strip at mid of clay layer i.e.,4m from ground surface, [latex] B^{\prime}=1.2+2 \times 0.5 \times 3=4.2 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Increase in pressure at the centre of clay layer, [latex] \bar{\sigma}_{0}=\frac{40 \times 1.2}{4.2}=11.43 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Settlement of footing, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta H &=\frac{C_{c} H_{0}}{1+e_{o}} \log _{10}\left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}+\bar{\sigma}_{0}}{\bar{\sigma}}\right) \\ &=\frac{0.08 \times 6000}{1+0.4} \log _{10}\left(\frac{48+11.43}{48}\right) \\ &=31.8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 333 A canal having side slopes 1:1 is proposed to be constructed in a cohesive
soil to a depth of 10 m below the ground surface. The soil properties are: [latex]\phi _u=15^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]C_n[/latex]=12kPa, e=1.0, [latex]G_{s}[/latex]=2.65. If there is a sudden draw down of water in the canal and if Taylor's Stability
Number for the reduced value of [latex]\phi _v[/latex] is 0.126, the factor of safety with respect to
cohesion against the failure of bank slopes will be
solution: Even if there is a sudden drawdown of water in the canal, the soil remains saturated for sometime. Hence, unit weight of the soil will be the saturated unit weight i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma_{\text {sat }} &=\gamma+\gamma_{w}=8.09+9.81 \\ &=17.9 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Taylor's stability number, [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{n} &=\frac{C_{u}}{F_{c} \gamma_{s a t} H} \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{c} &=\frac{c_{v}}{S_{n} \times \gamma_{s a t} \times H} \\ \Rightarrow &=\frac{12}{0.126 \times 17.9 \times 10}=0.53 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 334 A canal having side slopes 1:1 is proposed to be constructed in a cohesive
soil to a depth of 10 m below the ground surface. The soil properties are: [latex]\phi _u=15^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]C_n[/latex]=12kPa, e=1.0, [latex]G_{s}[/latex]=2.65. If Taylor's Stability Number, [latex]S_{n}[/latex]
 is 0.08 and if the canal flows full, the factor of safety with respect to cohesion against failure of the canal bank slopes will be
solution: When the canal flows full, the canal bank slopes will be submerged under water. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \gamma &=\left(\frac{G_{s}-1}{1+e}\right) \gamma_{w}=\left(\frac{2.65-1}{1+1}\right) \times 9.81 \\ &=8.09 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taylor's stability number, [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{n} &=\frac{C_{u}}{F_{0} \gamma_{\text {sub }} H} \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{c} &=\frac{c_{u}}{S_{n} \times \gamma_{\text {sub }} \times H}=\frac{12}{0.08 \times 8.09 \times 10} \\ &=1.85 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 335 Match the items of List-I with List-II and select the correct answer.

Question 336 Match the List-I (Boring methods) with List-II (Field conditions) and select the
correct answer.

Question 337 For the [latex]\left ( 3\times 3 \right )[/latex] pile group shown in the figure, the settlement of pile group, in a normally consolidated clay stratum having properties as shown in the figure, will be
solution: Assume equivalent raft at a distance of [latex]\frac{L}{3}=\frac{5}{3} [/latex] from the bottom of the pipe and load dispersion at [latex]2 \mathrm{H}: 1 \mathrm{V} [/latex] Compressible layer thickness [latex] =7-5+\frac{5}{3}=3.667 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Average stress at the center of layer, [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{\sigma}_{0}=& \gamma_{\text {sub }} \times 5.17 \\ &=(20-10) \times 5.17 \\ &=51.7 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Increased width of equivalent raft at depth [latex] =1.2+\frac{\left(\frac{5}{3}+2\right)}{2}=3.03 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Pressure increase due to load on pile, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta \sigma &=\frac{500}{3.03^{2}}=54.34 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \Delta H &=\frac{C_{c} H_{0}}{1+e_{0}} \log \left(\frac{\bar{\sigma}_{0}+\Delta \sigma}{\bar{\sigma}_{0}}\right) \\ &=\frac{0.027 \times \frac{11}{3}}{1+1.05} \log \left(\frac{51.7+54.34}{51.7}\right) \\ &=15.07 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 338 At a reclamation site for which the soil strata is shown in figure, a 3 m thick layer
of a fill material is to be laid instantaneously on the top surface. If the coefficient
of volume compressibility, [latex]m_v[/latex] for clay is [latex]2.2\times 10^{-4} m^{2}/kN[/latex], the consolidation settlement of the clay layer due to placing of fill material will be
solution:
Increase in effective stress, [latex]
\Delta \bar{\sigma}=3 \times 21=63 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Consolidation settlement of the clay layer [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&=\mathrm{H}_{0} \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \bar{\sigma} \\
&=10 \times 2.2 \times 10^{-4} \times 63 \\
&=0.1386 \mathrm{m} \\
&=138.6 \mathrm{mm} \approx 139 \mathrm{mm}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 339 For the soil strata shown in figure, the water tables is lowered by drainage by 2 m
and if the top 2 m thick silty sand stratum remains saturated by capillary action
even after lowering of water table, the increase in effective vertical pressure in kPa
at mid-height of clay layer will be
solution:
In the capillary zone, pore pressure is negative. The total stress will not change due to lowering of water table because the stratum is still saturated. Thus, the increase in effective vertical pressure will be only due to pore pressure. Thus increase in effective stress, [latex]
=h \gamma_{w}=2 \times 10=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question:
Question 340 A braced cut, 5 m wide and 7.5 m deep is proposed in a cohesionless soil deposit
having effective cohesion c'=0 and effective friction angle, [latex]{\phi}' =36^{\circ}[/latex]. The first row of struts is to be installed at a depth of 0.5 m below ground surface and spacing between the struts should be 1.5 m. If the horizontal spacing of struts is 3 m and unit weight of the deposit is 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex], the maximum strut load will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} K_{a} &=\frac{1-\sin \phi^{\prime}}{1+\sin \phi^{\prime}} \\ &=\frac{1-\sin 36^{\circ}}{1+\sin 36^{\circ}}=0.2596 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Uniform pressure on side of cut [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.65 \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \gamma \mathrm{H} \\ &=0.65 \times 0.2596 \times 20 \times 7.5 \\ &=25.31 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area covered by strut [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 &=3 \times(0.5+0.75) \\ &=3.75 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area covered by strut 2 and downward struts [latex] =3 \times(0.75+0.75)=4.5 \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum force will be carried by strut 2 and downward struts [latex] \begin{aligned} &=25.31 \times 4.5=113.89 \mathrm{kN} \\ &\simeq 113.90 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 341 Compaction of an embankment is carried out in 500 mm thick layers. The rammer used for compaction has a foot area of 0.05 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] and the energy imparted in every drop of rammer is 400 Nm. Assuming 50% more energy in each pass over the compacted area due to overlap, the number of passes required to develop compactive energy equivalent of Indian Standard light compaction for each layer would be
solution:
As per Indian Standard light compaction test, a 
hammer of 2.6 kg is allowed to fall from a height of 
 310 mm and 3 layers are tamped 25 times in a 
mould of volume 1000 cc . [latex]\therefore [/latex] Energy imparted [latex] \begin{array}{l} =2.6 \times 25 \times 3 \times 9.81 \\ \times \frac{310}{1000}=593.01 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] For embankment compaction, the volume of soil covered by rammer [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.05 \times 10^{4} \times \frac{500}{10} \\ &=25000 \mathrm{cc} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Energy imparted in every drop of hammer [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left(1+\frac{50}{100}\right) \times 400\\ &=600 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] If 'n' number of passes are required to develop equivalent energy to Indian Standard light compaction test, then [latex] n \times \frac{600}{25000}=\frac{593.01}{1000}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad n=24.71 \simeq 25\text{( approx.)} [/latex] However, If the data of Standard Proctor Test are taken i.e. weight of hammer =2.495 kg; Volume of mould =944cc, then the value of 'n' will be close to 26.

question:
Question 342 A 25 kN point load acts on the surface of an infinite elastic medium. The vertical
pressure intensity in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex] at a point 6.0 m below and 4.0 m away from the load will be
solution: As per Boussinesq's equation, the vertical stress [latex] \sigma_{2}[/latex] at a point located at a depth 'z' and a horizontal distance 'r' from the point of application of point load Q is [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{z} &=\frac{3 Q}{2 \pi z^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{1+(r / z)^{2}}\right]^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad &=\frac{3 \times 25}{2 \pi \times(6)^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{1+(4 / 6)^{2}}\right]^{5 / 2} \\ &=0.132 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 343 In a plate load test conducted on cohesion less soil, a 600 mm square test plate settles
by 15 mm under a load intensity of 0.2 [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]. All conditions remaining the same, settlement of a 1 m square footing will be
solution: Settlement of footing in a cohesionless soil is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \quad S_{1}&=S_{p}\left[\frac{B_{1}\left(B_{p}+30\right)}{B_{p}\left(B_{1}+30\right)}\right]^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad S_{f}&=15\left[\frac{100(60+30)}{60(100+30)}\right]^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad S_{f}&=19.97 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 344 A granular soil possesses saturated density of 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex]. Its effective angle of internal friction is 35 degrees. If the desired factor of safety is 1.5, the safe angle of slope for this soil, when seepage occurs at and parallel to the slope surface, will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given }\phi^{\prime}&=35^{\circ}: \gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}=20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ F&=1.5 ; \beta=? ; \gamma=\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Factor of safety [latex] \begin{aligned} F&=\frac{\gamma^{\prime} \tan \phi^{\prime}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }} \tan \beta} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.5&=\frac{\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}-\gamma_{\mathrm{w}}\right) \tan 35^{\circ}}{\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}} \tan \beta} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \beta&=\frac{(20-10) \tan 35^{\circ}}{1.5 \times 20} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \beta&=13.14^{\circ} \simeq 13^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 345 A double draining clay layer, 6 m thick, settles by 30 mm in three years under
influence of certain loads. Its final consolidation settlement has been estimated
to be 120 mm. If a thin layer of sand having negligible thickness is introduced at
a depth of 1.5 m below the top surface, the final consolidation settlement of clay
layer will be
solution: Final settlement will not be altered. However, the rate of settlement of clay layer will increase.

question:
Question 346 A masonry dam is founded on previous sand having porosity equal to 45% and
specific gravity of sand particles is 2.65. For a desired factor of safety of 3 against
sand boiling, the maximum permissible upward gradient will be
solution: Critical hydraulic gradient, [latex] \begin{aligned} \quad \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{C}}&=\frac{\mathrm{G}-1}{1+\mathrm{e}}=(\mathrm{G}-1)(1-\mathrm{n}) \\ \therefore \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{C}}&=(2.65-1)(1-0.45)=0.9075 \end{aligned}[/latex] Factor of safety [latex] =\frac{\text { Critical hydraulic gradient }}{\text { Maximum permissible gradient }} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Maximum permissible gradient [latex] =\frac{0.9075}{3}=0.3025[/latex]

question:
Question 347 In a triaxial test carried out on a cohesionless soil sample with a cell pressure of
20 kPa, the observed value of applied stress at the point of failure was 40 kPa.
The angle of internal friction of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\quad \sigma_{1} &=\sigma_{a}+\sigma_{3} \\ &=40+20=60 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \text{Now,}\quad \sigma_{1} &=\sigma_{3} N_{0}+2 \mathrm{c} \sqrt{\mathrm{N}_{2}}\\ \text{Where }\quad c&=0\\ \frac{\sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{3}} &=N_{0}=\frac{60}{20}=3 \\ &=\tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\\ \tan \left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)&=\sqrt{3}=1.732 \\ 45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}&=60^{\circ} \\ \text{or }\quad \frac{\phi}{2}&=60^{\circ}-45^{\circ} \\ \phi&=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question:
Question 348 The time for a clay layer to achieve 85% consolidation is 10 years. If the layer was
half as thick, 10 times more permeable and 4 times more compressible then the
time that would be required to achieve the same degree of consolidation is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k &=C_{v} m_{v} \gamma_{w} \\ T_{v} &=\frac{C_{v} t}{h^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \text { and } \quad t_{1} &=\frac{h_{1}^{2} T_{v}}{k_{1}} m_{v} \gamma_{w} \\ \therefore \quad & t_{2}=\frac{h_{2}^{2} T_{v}}{k_{2}} m_{v} \gamma_{w} \\ & \frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\left(\frac{h_{1}}{h_{2}}\right)^{2} \times \frac{T_{v}}{T_{v}} \times \frac{k_{2}}{k_{1}} \times \frac{m_{v 1}}{m_{v 2}}\\ \frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}} &=\left(\frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}}\right)^{2} \times \frac{k_{1}}{k_{2}} \times \frac{m_{v 2}}{m_{v 1}} \\ &=\frac{1}{4} \times 1 \times \frac{1}{10} \times 4=\frac{1}{10} \\ t_{2} &=\frac{t_{1}}{10}=\frac{10}{10}=1 \text { year } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 349 If the effective stress strength parameters of a soil are c'=10 kPa and [latex]{\phi}' =30^{\circ}[/latex], the shear strength on a plane within the saturated soil mass at a point where the total normal stress is 300 kPa and pore water pressure is 150 kPa will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=c+\bar{\sigma}_{s} \tan \phi^{\prime} \\ &=10+(150) \tan 30^{\circ} \\ &=96.6 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 350 An infinite slope is to be constructed in a soil. The effective stress strength
parameters of the soil are c'=0 and [latex]{\phi}' =30^{\circ}[/latex]. The saturated unit weight of the
slope is 20 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] and the unit weight of water is 10 [latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex]. Assuming that seepage is occurring parallel to the slope, the maximum slope angle for a factor
of safety of 1.5 would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tan \phi_{\mathrm{w}} &=\frac{\gamma^{\prime}}{\gamma_{\mathrm{sat}}}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{d}}} \tan \phi^{\prime}\right) \\ &=\frac{10}{20}\left(\frac{1}{1.5} \tan 30^{\circ}\right) \text { or } \phi_{\mathrm{w}}=10.89 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 351 The observed value of the standard penetration number (N) at 10 m depth of a
silty sand deposit is 13. The unit weight of the soil is 16 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. The N value after
correcting for the presence of fines will be
solution:
Given SPT number [latex]N=13(\lt 15)[/latex] Correction of fines is not required as N is not 
greater than 15 [latex]N_{\text {corrected }}=13 [/latex]

question:
Question 352 The specific gravity and insitu void ratio of a soil deposit are 2.71 and 0.85
respectively. The value of the critical hydraulic gradient is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{c} &=\frac{G-1}{1+e}=\frac{2.71-1}{0.85+1} \\ &=\frac{1.71}{0.85}=0.924 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 353 The following data were obtained from a liquid limit test conducted on a soil sample. The liquid limit of the soli is
solution:
The liquid limit is the water content corresponding 
to 25 number of blows [latex]\therefore w_{L}=61.9\%[/latex]

question:
Question 354 The void ratios at the densest, loosest and the natural states of a sand deposit
are 0.2, 0.6 and 0.4, respectively. The relative density of the deposit is
solution: Relative density [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{e_{\max }-e_{\text {natuat }}}{e_{\max }-e_{\min }} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{0.6-0.4}{0.6-0.2} \times 100=50 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 355 Data from a sieve analysis conducted on a given sample of soil showed that 67%
of the particles passed through 75 micron IS sieve. The liquid limit and plastic
limit of the finer fraction was found to be 45 and 33 percents respectively. The
group symbol of the given soil as per IS:1498-1970 is
solution: % passing [latex]75 \mu[/latex] sieve [latex]\gt 50 \% [/latex] So the soil might be, silt (M) or clay (C) [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{p} \text { of soil } &=w_{L}-w_{p} \\ &=45-33=12 \end{aligned}[/latex] Equation of A line is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{p} &=0.73\left(w_{L}-20\right) \\ &=0.73(45-20)=18.25 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \because \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}\text{ of soil } \lt \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}\text{ of A-line}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] It will lie below A-line and also [latex]35 \lt w_{L} \lt 50 [/latex] So it is MI.

question:
Question 356 Identify the two TRUE statements from the following four statements. I. Negative skin friction is higher on floating piles than on end bearing piles. II. All other things being the same in footings on sand, the footing with
smaller width will have lower settlement at the same net pressure. III. The void ratio of soils is always less than 1.0. IV. For determining the depth of embedment of anchored sheet piles, net
moment at the anchor elevation is set to zero.

Question 357 A plate load test was conducted in sand on a 300 mm diameter plate. If the
plate settlement was 5 mm at a pressure of 100 kPa, the settlement (in mm) of a
5mx8m rectangular footing at the same pressure will be
solution: For cohesionless soil [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{t} &=S_{\mathrm{p}}\left[\frac{\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{t}}\left(\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{p}}+0.3\right)}{\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{t}}+0.3\right)}\right]^{2} \\ &=5\left[\frac{5(0.3+0.3)}{0.3(5+0.3)}\right]^{2}=17.8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 358 The coefficients of permeability of a soil in horizontal and vertical directions are
3.46 and 1.5 m/day respectively. The base length of a concrete dam resting in this soil is 100 m. When the flow net is developed for this soil with 1:25 scale factor in the vertical direction, the reduced base length of the dam will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} K_{x}&=3.46 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} \\ K_{y}&=1.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{day} l_{b}&=100 \mathrm{m} \text{(base length)}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] scale factor in vertical direction =1: 25 scale factor in horizontal direction [latex] =\frac{1}{25} \sqrt{\frac{K_{y}}{K_{x}}}=\frac{1}{37.969}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Reduced base length = scale [latex]\times l_{\mathrm{b}} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{100}{37.969}=2.63 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 359 The critical slip circle for a slope is shown below along with the soil properties. The length of the arc of the slip circle is 15.6 m and the area of soil within the slip circle is 82[latex]m^2[/latex]. The radius of the slip circles is 10.3m. The factor of safety against the slip circle failure is nearly equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { FOS } &=\frac{\text { Resisting moment }}{\text { Actuating moment }} \\ &=\frac{C L R}{W \times 2.3}=\frac{30 \times 15.6 \times 10.3}{20 \times 82 \times 2.3} \\ &=1.28 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 360 Identify the two FALSE statements from the following four statements. I. The consolidation of soil happens due to the change in total stress. II. When Standard Penetration Tests are performed in fine sands below the water table, the dilation correction is applied after the overburden correction is applied. III. Over consolidated clays will have predominantly cohesive strength as
compared to the frictional strength. IV. Compaction of soils is due to expulsion of water.
solution:
(I) Consolidation of soil takes place due to the 
 change in effective stress. (IV) Compaction of soil is due to expulsion of air.

question:
Question 361 With respect to a [latex]c-\phi[/latex] soil in an infinite slope, identify if the following two
statements are TRUE or FALSE I. The stable slope angle can be greater than [latex]\phi[/latex] II. The factor of safety of the slope does not depend on the height of soil in the slope

options.B: I is TRUE but II is FALSE
options.C: I is FALSE but II is TRUE

question:
Question 362 The void ratio and specific gravity of a soil are 0.65 and 2.72 respectively. The
degree of saturation (in percent) corresponding to water content of 20% is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{ll} \text { Given } & e=0.65 \\ & \mathrm{G}=2.72 \\ & \mathrm{w}=20 \% \\ \text { From } & \mathrm{e}=\frac{\mathrm{wG}}{\mathrm{S}} \\ \therefore \quad & \mathrm{S}=\frac{\text { wG }}{\mathrm{e}}=\frac{0.2 \times 2.72}{0.65} \\ & =0.8369 \approx 83.7 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 363 The width and depth of a footing are 2 and 1.5m respectively. The water table
at the site is at a depth of 3m below the ground level. The water table correction factor for the calculation of the bearing capacity of soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{y} &=0.5+0.5 \frac{\mathrm{D}_{t}}{\mathrm{B}} \\ &=0.5+0.5 \times \frac{1.5}{2}=0.875 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 364 The following two statements are made with reference to the calculation of net bearing capacity of a footing in pure clay soil ([latex]\phi =0[/latex]) using Terzaghi's bearing capacity theory. Identify if they are TRUE or FALSE. I. Increase in footing width will result in increase in bearing capacity. II. Increase in depth of foundation will result in higher bearing capacity.
solution: [latex]q_{u}=c N_{c}+\gamma D_{i} N_{q}+0.5 \gamma B N_{\gamma} [/latex] For pure clay, [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi &=0, N_{c}=5.7, N_{q}=1, N_{\gamma}=0 \\ \therefore \quad a_{u} &=c N_{c}+\gamma D_{t} \\ q_{n u} &=c N_{c}+\gamma D_{t}-\gamma D_{t}=c N_{c} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.C: I is TRUE but II is FALSE
options.D: II is TRUE but I is FALSE

question:
Question 365 The following two statments are made with respect to different sand samples
having the same relative density. Identify if they are TRUE or FALSE. I. Poorly graded sands will have lower friction angle than the well graded sands. II. The particle size has no influence on the friction angle of sand.

options.A: II is TRUE but I is FALSE
options.D: I is TRUE but II is FALSE
